## pa
 
 <i>n.</i> a type of fish hook, couta stick

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> BARRACOUTA (MANGA) <i>Leionura atun dentatus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) INCREDIBLE as it may seem these fish, with their well-armed jaws of sharp fang-like teeth, were usually caught on a slightly curved stick about four feet in length. Fastened to this stick was a piece of stout fishing line about three to four feet in length, carrying a piece of red-coloured wood - usually cedar - about five to six inches in length. A bent nail was secured to this piece of wood in the form of a hook but no bait was used. When a school of Barracouta was found the Couta stick, or paw, was brought out ready for fishing. From the cockpit of the launch the piece of wood with the nail was violently swirled with a circular motion in and out of the water, causing a disturbance of the water in a good imitation of a number of Sprats, Pilchards or other small fish jumping in and out of the sea. The Barracouta would swim for such a place. Seeing the piece of red wood moving rapidly through the water they would take it for a fish, snap at it or even jump out of the water for the lure and were caught by the crude iron hook. As the fish was hooked during the time the paw was being drawn through the water the fisherman would swing the fish over his head above the boat or launch and when the caught fish was midway in the air, more or less above the cockpit, would expertly give the stick a dexterous smart twist. As there was no barb on the hook the fish was released and fell into the cockpit. <i>Ibid.</i> 311 Should there be any Barracouta about the... Couta sticks were then set to work to paw the water and attract Barracouta to the spot. <i>Ibid.</i> 314 The Maori also knew he could catch Barracouta without bait and he, too, used a short piece of stick and line with a baitless hook and leaned over his canoe and threshed the water to and fro, which is known as `Kaihau manga!' When the European fisherman called his fishing outfit [315] `paw', the Maori uses the term `pa'. This fish was a great favourite with them and was caught in large numbers. On returning to the shore, the women cleaned the fish and then hung them up on racks to dry in the sun. Old Maoris of Opotiki told me they used a chip of Tawhai (<i>Nothofagus fusca</i>), which is dark red, in the making of a pa (paw). <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,310</i>)

## pack
 
 <i>n.</i> a backpack (and its contents); (tends to replace earlier swag, but usually refers to a shop-bought pack: cf <i>Bergan</i>) (See [flat pack](../F#flat-pack))

>  Food and gear have to be carried. Everyone in New Zealand..puts it in a pack. <i>(1958,Tararua,12: 27</i>)

>  Food and gear have to be carried. Everyone in New Zealand, almost everyone anyway, puts it in a <i>pack</i>, but probably no one stops to think that the word <i>pack</i> in this sense is not standard English. ... England since 1895 has borrowed <i>rucksack</i> from German dialect; New Zealand has preferred <i>pack</i>. Not that rucsac is not used here; it is noticeable that older Club members used it in several articles in early numbers of <i>Tararua</i>, and it still appears in advertisements. <i>Rucksack</i> seems a bit foreign, as is shown by the less correct but more foreign-looking spelling it is usually given. <i>Pack</i> as a synonym for <i>rucksack</i> is used in Australia to some extent at any rate. This sense of <i>pack</i> would most likely be in use long before it occurred in print. I remember having a home-made <i>pack</i> in Auckland in 1933. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,27</i>) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

>  With the following dawn two tigers stood by for a quick trip back to Maruia Springs while each pack was [40] searched and emptied. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,39</i>)

>  <i>(1967,Landfall,21/144</i>)

>  <b>MCKENNY</b> To still further eliminate this risk [of blood poisoning] it may be a good thing to dock each paddock-lot of lambs in a separate pen. <i>(1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,25</i>)

>  <b>MCKENNY</b> On hill country where there are paddock-lots of two or three hundred or more lambs, docking is often delayed till the sheep have finished lambing. <i>(1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,27</i>)



## paddocked
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of stock] enclosed in a paddock.

>  <b>FOSTER & WRIGHT</b> The night is clear and down below the paddocked cattle and horses dwindle into insignificance. <i>(1983,Stockman Country,40</i>)



## paddocker
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>CARR</b> Wages. ... - Stripper keeper and feeder ... Shaker 30s a week ... Paddocker 30s a week to 1s and hour. <i>(1913,Country Work,44</i>)

>  Wanted, for Flaxmill, Nelson district, Fly-boy, Cook, Scutcher, and Paddocker. <i>(May 21, 1907,Evening Post,1</i>)

>  Wages and rates of pay - Feeders, 1s per hour . . paddockers, 1s; assistant paddockers 11 1/2d ; .... <i>(Mar 17, 1910,Evening Post,4</i>)

>  The Department, in its wisdom, will send a clerk, a butcher, a baker, or a bootmaker away up in the backblocks road-making. Send him anywhere - get rid of him. .. He becomes a jack of all trades, a meandering nuisance, a paddocker, a navvy, a watersider, or a builders' labourer. <i>(Oct 17, 1914,Evening Post,11</i>)



## paddocking
 
 <i>n.</i> working a gold bearing area by excavating a paddock [goldmining] (See [paddock (goldmining)](../P#paddock-(goldmining)))

>  <b>SINCLAIR & HARREX</b> The method used to extract the gold from the gully was 'paddocking'. The top soil was removed off a section of the 'paddock' to expose the auriferous pay dirt. <i>(1978,Looking Back,75</i>)

>  <b>BRACKEN</b> The operations of `paddocking' and `sluicing' <i>(1879,NZ Tourist, The,24</i>)

>  Workings [at Mount Ida, Otago, in 1871] were for the most part alluvial, the distinctive process used being `paddocking'. [fn] Paddocking was the systematic sluicing of large areas of flat ground from which the surface layers were first removed to reveal the `wash-dirt' beneath. <i>(Apr 1953,NZ Geographer,29</i>) [NOTES: (Kibblewhite)]

>  <b>EVANS</b> Then they began `paddocking'. They marked off a strip of land and stripped off the soil down to the wash. ... When all this first area of wash had been put through the sluice box, they began on the second `paddock'. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,15</i>)

>  <b>MAY</b> During May, Haast saw miners on the outskirts of Hokitika, `actively at work paddocking at high-water mark, and cradling the wash-dirt of a thickness of 18 inches to two feet on the sea-beach' <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,169,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WOOD</b> More elaborate methods of winning gold include cradling, crevicing, setting up a sluicebox or `Long Tom' ..., sluicing, paddocking, and underwater dredging. <i>(1970,Gold Trails of Otago,81</i>)

>  <b>NOLAN</b> <i>Paddocking:</i> working alluvial gold in a dry region by storing the paydirt in a gully or bin and washing it when water is available; also, digging or sluicing a claim one section at a time methodically. <i>(1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,113</i>)

>  <b>NOLAN</b> Paddocking: A square of ground was dug down to the paydirt layer. The paydirt was either extracted and worked in a pan, cradle or sluice box, or the paddock had one open end and was sluiced. Paddocks were often waterlogged and had to be continually bailed or pumped dry. <i>(1976,Historic Gold Trails of Nelson & Marlborough,88</i>)

>  There are several parties of miners sluicing in the main gully of this basin, who are averaging about 12s (twelve shillings) per day each in shallow sinking or paddocking, the greatest depth not exceeding 3 (three) feet, with plenty of water. <i>(May 10, 1862,Otago Witness,8</i>)

>  The ground is of a loose shingly nature, and in paddocking, the sides are continually falling in... <i>(Oct 24, 1862,Otago Witness,4</i>)

>  The ground is being worked in the most desultory manner, - here a party paddocking - there a couple of men sinking a hole which they hope, if not swamped out, to be able to bottom... <i>(Apr 12, 1862,Otago Witness,3</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the drying of flax in paddocks. [flax]

>  Paddocking [of flax] is entirely superceded ... <i>(1906,NZ Farmer,128</i>)

>  .. colour and strength being much weaker as a result of the inability to properly breach the fibre, a defect emphasized by ther holidays interfering with the work of paddocking. <i>(Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,135</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the placing of stock on to fenced paddock areas of a property, usually after being on hill blocks. [farming]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Furthermore, the paddocking and turniping of sheep inclined to make them more difficult to muster. <i>(1949,High Country Days,182</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the systematic digging over of a gumfield in gumdigging. [gumdigging]

>  <b>KEENE</b> In later years, in some areas the more systematic 'paddocking' method of digging was introduced. A team of men worked together, digging over every square yard of gumfield thoroughly, and this method often proved fruitful in an already worked-over field. <i>(1977,To the Northward,123</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) making available a paddock for grazing or for stud purposes. [farming]

>  The reserves of 3 acres are necessary for the use of the linesmen whose duty is to keep the fence in repair, and who require a paddock for their pack-horses, the land throughout the line being chiefly bush with no convenience for paddocking. <i>(Nov 26, 1891,Letter</i>) [NOTES: from Hawke's Bay Rabbit District Board]

>  Paddocking free for four weeks, after which 2s. per week will be charged. <i>(Dec 1, 1880,Hawera & Normanby Star,1</i>)

>  Paddocking presented no worries for the first four days, for he had made his arrangements coming in. <i>(May 1933,NZ Farmer,367</i>)

>  Good paddocking provided at Kokonga at 1s per week. All care, but no responsibility. <i>(Nov 20, 1901,Otago Witness,44</i>)

>  Understood Mr. Cuthbertson to say to Mr. Exley that he was not responsible for the paddocking. <i>(Aug 28, 1902,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> the holding and feeding of stock in paddocks [farming]

>  Paddocking free for one month. <i>(Oct 1, 1879,Wanganui Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> On arrival, after arranging for a feed and paddocking for his horse George wandered into the hotel bar to enquire about accommodation for himself. <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,50</i>)

>  From experience of companies now working (in other countries), it is found that the operations can best be carried on by having the freezing works away from the port of shipment but adjacent to a line of railway, ... and where paddocking can be got for holding the stock until slaughtered. <i>(Dec 21, 1881,Report of Committee on Frozen Meat Trade</i>) [NOTES: 1881 Dec 21 Report of Committee on Frozen Meat Trade in 1957 Macdonald Canterbury Frozen Meat Company 77]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> working a gold bearing area by excavating a paddock [goldmining]

>  <b>MILLER</b> But even at that [sluicing] was going to pay me much better than paddocking. <i>(1946,There Was Gold,74</i>)

>  <b>STALLWORTHY</b> On the higher and drier lands, the here-and-there-pot-holing practice gave place to continuous digging, known as paddocking. <i>(1916,Early Northern Wairoa,54</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> the process of storing excavated washdirt [goldmining]

>  There are now eighteen parties paddocking dirt or preparing to paddock, and twenty-three on gold. <i>(Jan 15, 1891,West Coast Times,2</i>)

>  <b>EASTWOOD</b> They used a method called dry paddocking, i.e., storing dry material in a heap until they could get water for an hour, and then sluicing it through a box. <i>(1982,Brief History of Gold Mining, A,125</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> [wheat]

>  <i>Paddocking.</i> Sacks of headed wheat can stand in the field through a rain if they are stood on the seam end with the ears of the sacks tucked underneath, ... <i>(Jan 25, 1934,Press, The,11</i>) [NOTES: (Acland)]

## paepae
 
 <i>n.</i> (also pae) the threshold beam of a meeting house; a bench to seat orators at the front of a meeting house. [ORIGIN: Maori, The beam forming a bench at the threshold of a meeting house.]

>  <b>BUICK</b> `This looks like the <i>paepae</i> of a large house,' said Mr. Teviotdale, and the luxuriant growth of the tussocks seemed to justify the suggestion that the soil had been fed by human refuse. <i>(1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,203</i>)

## Pai Marire
 
 <i>n.</i> a 19th century semi-religious movement begun by Te Ua. [Maori PAI + marire[a-macron] gentle, appeased] [also Hauhau(ism), Ringatu also used as a cry when attacking] (See [also Hauhau(ism)](../A#also-hauhau(ism)),[Ringatu](../R#ringatu))

>  [Te Ua] sought consolation by praying tohis God, and Atua Pai Marire... Te Uasent out two prophets to the tribes ofthe Eats Coast to establish the PaiMarire doctrine, Kereopa and Patara. <i>(Jan 25, 1933,NZ Tablet,15</i>)

>  Before he was hit, Matene cried, "<i>pai marire, hou, hou!"</i> <i>(May 21, 1864,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3</i>)

>  This man, Rua, is a Hau Hau, which is a religion, so a Maori told me, based on the prophesies in the Bible, and he also told me that it was also called "Pai Mariri." <i>(May 14, 1906,Poverty Bay Herald,4</i>)

>  Te Ua made a long speech, chanting waiatas and "Pai marire" songs, the purport being that he was anxious to be at peace and to do no evil. <i>(Jul 2, 1864,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2</i>)

>  The contest eventuated about the middle of 1866, near Pungarehu, on the banks of the Waingongoro River, in Southern Taranaki, while the gallant soldier was serving as one of colonel M'Donnell's Bushrangers, who so nobly and strenuously followed the Hau Haus into the fastnesses of the New Zealand bush, and so stamped out the frightful creed of Pai Marire. <i>(Oct 21, 1911,Evening Post,14</i>)

>  Saw the wife of Epiha (one of the surrendered Taranakis) & got some further information about their new religion, the Pai Marire. <i>(Jan 27, 1865,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/148</i>) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

>  <b>BABBAGE</b> The great moving principle of Pai Marire is that it is a scheme which promises a successful termination of the war with which we are afflicted. <i>(1937,Hauhauism,21</i>) [NOTES: 1865 Mar 25 Annual Report of the Bishop of Waiapu, Dr. William Williams to the Secretary of the CMS in 1937 Babbage Hauhauism 21]

>  <b>CARBERRY</b> It has lately adopted a new feature as far as the natives are concerned namely fanatisism [sic] which is a bad characteristic in an enemy. ... They invented a new religion which they call `Pai Marire' or the good message. They have given up Christianity ... <i>(Mar 1865,Journal</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> The new faith was called <i>`Pai marire',</i> but afterwards, from the noise the votaries made in their devotions, resembling the barking of dogs, they acquired the name of <i>Hauhaus. </i> <i>(1868,Past and Present of NZ,147</i>)

>  <b>MEADE</b> ... We met a small party of [440] mounted natives, who brought news that an apostle of the new <i>Pai Marire,</i> or <i>Te Hau,</i> fanaticism had arrived at Taupo ... They are called <i>Pai Marire</i>, from the words which they subscribe to their signatures and use in greeting or parting from their co-religionists. The words literally mean `good! be appeased'; but the real tendency of the belief is to unite the Kingites of all sects in one common bond of fanatical hostility to the pakehas. <i>Te Hau </i>means only the <i>hau </i>(faith). <i>Ibid</i> 466 ... a host of perverts were chanting <i>Pai Marire </i>hymns round a <i>Hau-hau</i> post of worship, erected close to the late Christian church. <i>(Dec 26, 1870,Ride Through Disturbed Districts</i>) [NOTES: 1870 Dec 26 Meade Ride Through Disturbed Dists in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 439-440]

>  Down came the Hauhaus, a whole mob of them, armed, yelling "Pai-mariri!" and such-like war-cries. <i>(Jul 20, 1912,NZ Free Lance,4</i>)

It had messianic and millenarian aspects, and theologically combined traditional Maori religion and the Maori versions of Christianity with Te Ua's own innovations. ... The original form of Pai Marire may have died out as early as 1866, with the death of its founder, but related or similar cults developed around leaders such as Hakaraia, Te Whiti O Rongomai, Titokowaru, Te Kooti, and Tawhiao himself. <i>(1986,NZ Wars, The,204</i>)

They turned up in the end, of course, and, just to prove me prejudiced and wrong, subscribed more rigorously than anyone to `pakeha time'; but meanwhile I was driven to desperation trying to find the other twenty or so Maoris needed to complete the cast. <i>(1980,All My Lives,115</i>)

## pakihi
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a large, low-lying area of leached soils with scanty natural growth of scrub, fern and rushes.

>  The Collingwood pakihis are of limited extent, probably within 10,000 acres. 300 Thus the three dominant plants of the pakihi are the manuka, the Gleichenia fern and the sedge. <i>(Sep 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,297</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> pakihi: as it also a Maori word for barren land, we have adopted the word to refer to a certain Westland-type soil that has been leached by constant heavy rain and is difficult to bring in to good pasture. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,59</i>)

>  The pakihi seems to need further capital fertiliser after the fourth year, otherwise it starts reverting to yorkshire fog, lotus, native grasses and fine-stemmed pakihi rushes. <i>(Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,26</i>)

>  The home farm has 50 ha of alluvial ground and 80 ha of pakihi ... This farm is all pakihi but carried 217 cows to produce 25,748 kg last season. <i>(Feb 1990,NZ Dairy Exporter,4</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a barren area of land.

>  <b>STEVENSON</b> .. pakihi was used to describe any tussock covered flat ground. <i>(1947,Maori and Pakeha in North Otago,15</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> pakihi: a desert or barren land. <i>(1995,Reed Dictionary of Modern Maori,198</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> in English usage chiefly South Island, with two main applications: (a) West Coast, usually connoting heavy, swampy (originally bush) land; -->(b) open grass or scrub tract, often in bush country, or above the bush line.

>  <b>LEE & KENDALL</b> Pakii kura[u-acute]; Red land where fern root has been collected: name of a person. <i>(1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,188</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> We now advanced along the plain [towards Moeraki], which was covered with `patiti' and ... stunted fern and `tutu'. These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. <i>Ibid.</i> 311 PAKIHI, open country, bare of trees, covered with coarse wiry grass, stunted fern, and low shrubs. It does not necessarily signify `a plain'. The `a' is sounded long and broad in this word, by which it is distinguished from `pakihi,' to be low water, or to drain off as a river after a flood, in which the `a' has a sound both short and soft. `Kua pakihi te wai o Waitaki,' the water of Waitahi has become low. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,195</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 9 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 195-196]

>  <b>MONEY</b> In the afternoon we suddenly came out of the bush upon an open pakihi some miles in length, covered with short fern and rushes. <i>Ibid.</i> 70 ... we took a contract ... to clear a road twelve feet wide across a `Parkihi' or open piece of country, chiefly covered with fern and tea-tree (manuka) scrub, for a distance of three miles. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,63</i>)

 <i>v.</i>

>  Keith Snalam of Blenheim writes: "As an apprentice boy in the 50s, I frequently heard the term 'pannikin boss'. I'm sure it was used as a comment on the state of mind of the foreman or leading hand, that person having just had the big boss from the office on his hammer ... The foreman would be seen approaching the workers in a state which these days would be described as stressed out. Hence the term, 'here comes the panickin' boss'!" Maybe. Dave Bijoux of Mt Eden suggests: "The pannikin boss drank from the pannikin, as did all the workers: a boss who metaphorically drank from their cup, was part of the community, and was somewhat despised as a prostitute for the workers. Ronald Thomas of Pamlerston North adds: "Perhaps there is a connection between a metal cup that holds a little liquid and a trumped-up boss who holds little authority, but makes a lot of noise about it." <i>(Jun 26, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48</i>)

## paraerae
 
 <i>n.</i> Maori sandals of plaited flax. [Maori paraerae[a1-macron]] (felt as pl)

>  <b>BRUNNER</b> I had often looked forward with dread to the time when my shoes would be worn out, ... but now I can trudge along ... with a pair of native sandals, called y the natives <i>pairairai</i>, made of the leaves of flax, or, what is more durable, the leaves of the ti or flax tree. <i>(Oct 21, 1847,Journal of an Expedition</i>) [NOTES: 1847 Oct 21 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 288]

>  ... they [natives] wear shoes made of flax, which they call<i> paralas</i>; they are very humorous creatures ... <i>(Jul 20, 1848,Letters from Otago,16,1978 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> PARAERAE, a sandal formed from the plaited leaves of the <i>phormium tenax</i>,;or the `ti' (<i>Cordyline Australis</i>).;Three different descriptions of sandal are made by the natives. That called `paraerae hou' or `kuara' is made of a single layer of plaited leaves of flax; that called `takitahi' is similarly made from the leaves of the `ti;' the third, called `torua' is made of the leaves of the `ti,' but plaited in a double layer, so as to be very durable. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,311</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> The next day, ... the coast becoming very rocky, we exchanged our boots for Maori sandals (pereiras), which allowed better foothold on the smooth boulders. <i>(1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,48</i>)

>  Bill made `parara' or Maori sandals of flax. <i>(1896,NZ Alpine Journal,2/9/155</i>)

## paraha
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HYDE</b> [Island Bay, Wellington] But always ... [sic] the sand had splayed out in fawn-coloured drifts, the pale paraha bells had trembled their taut mauve silk, elastic to the touch, against the wind. <i>(1938,Godwits Fly, The,70,1970 ed.</i>)

>  <i>paraha,</i> a climbing plant (Calystegia sepium), a convolvulus. The far-famed Te Rauparaha took his name from this plant as a reminder that when the body of his father was eaten by his enemies they used the leaf (rau) of this plant as a relish. Another convolvulus (C. soldanella) is pohue. <i>(Jun 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/155</i>) [NOTES: J.C.Andersen]

>  [Te Rauparaha's] name signifies a food leaf, the paraha. <i>(Dec 22, 1898,Otago Witness,31</i>)



## paraiwhara
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HUNT</b> The aborigines term themselves Moriori, their conquerors still call them <i>paraiwharas</i>, or blackfellows - not from their complexions, ... - but, in their ideas, the term is synonymous with slavery. <i>(1866,Chatham Islands,29</i>)



## parakeet
 
 <i>n.</i> any of numerous usually small slender parrots with long, graduated tails. See also native parakeet [<i>Cyanorhamphus spp. (formerly Platycercus), KAKARIKI, BUSH PARAKEET (1843 Dieffenbach NZ) ee <i>C. malherbei</i> ORANGE-FRONTED P.; <i>C. auriceps</i>, YELLOW-FRONTED P.; and <i>C. novaezelandiae</i>, RED-FRONTED P.] (See [also kakariki](../A#also-kakariki))

>  <i>(Dec 4, 1907,Evening Post,8</i>) [NOTES: Those from the Auckland Islands closely resemble the New Zealand parakeet, but are much larger.]

>  The list covers the greater part of the indigenous birds, and practically includes the whole of the gulls and sea fowl, and all the smaller varieties of the land birds from the tui, huia, kiwi, and morepork downwards, such, for instance, as the fantail, wren, Robin, kingfisher, parrakeet, native lark, cuckoo, blue duck, etc., etc. <i>(May 16, 1906,Taranaki Herald,6</i>)

>  Within the last three years all these birds, and the morepork as well (I said "all," that is a mistake, as I did not see or hear the parrakeet, that I have not seen for years), I have seen in the thick part of the bush on the side of Mount Cargill. <i>(Nov 25, 1908,Otago Witness,86</i>)

>  Surely a bird had swept by him in the loose bush, and that was the egregrious cackle of a parakeet far off! <i>(Jun 6, 1891,Star, The,1</i>)

>  Other toasts, both general and local, followed, the agricultural interest, the pastoral interest,and a number of other interests besides, and one gentleman convulsed the meeting by a speech on the subject of the <i>parakeets,</i> which are the pests of Long Bush at the present time, and like the rabbits of the west, are playing sad havoc with the products of both gardens and fields. <i>(Oct 24, 1873,Southland Times,3</i>)

>  <b>FORSTER</b> In the morning ... I went ... to the Indian Cove, & shot there two new Kingfishers [[ed. fn] Now the new Zealand Kingfisher ...], some new yellow headed Flycatchers [[ed. fn] Now the Yellowhead <i>Mohoua ochrocephala</i> (Gmelin, 1789).], a fine large green and brown Pigeon [[ed. fn] Now the New Zealand pigeon ...] ..., a small Perrokeet, green with a red forehead ... [ed. fn] Now the Red-crowned Parakeet ... <i>(Apr 2, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/245,1982 ed.</i>)

>  <i>(1840,NZ Journal</i>)

>  <b>DOMETT</b> Let but a grass-green <i>parrakeet</i> alight/ To pluck from some wild <i>coffee</i>-bush in sight,/ And nibble .../ The scarlet berries; let some<i> kingfisher</i>/ Slip darting from the post .../ <i>(1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/154</i>)

>  <b>BULLER</b> ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail. <i>(1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/14</i>)

>  Platycercus pacificus. Kakariki. Parrakeet. Common. ... Platycercus auriceps. Parrakeet. Common. <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/160</i>) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

>  PLATYCERCUS NOVAE-ZEALANDIAE, <i>Sparrm</i>. - Parrakeet. <i>(1886,TrNZI,18/125</i>)

>  Of these birds there are two species, the larger of the two being the red-fronted paroquet and the smaller the yellow-fronted species. Of the two, the red-headed [*check] species is the better linguist. <i>(Sep 9, 1890,Otago Witness,39</i>)

>  One of the bones came from a parakeet - Campbell's lost parrot at last. <i>(May 2005,NZ Geographic,No 73 / 9</i>)

>  <b>PARKER</b> There are three species of parakeet, the red-fronted (<i>Platycercus Novae-Zelandiae</i>), the yellow-fronted (<i>P. auriceps</i>), and the orange-fronted (<i>P. alpinus</i>). The genus Platycercus is found in New Zealand, New Guinea and Polynesia. <i>(1889,Catalogue of Vienna Exhibition,118</i>) [NOTES: (Morris)]

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Parrakeet, n.</i> (various spellings) The New Zealand Green Parrakeet (called also <i>Kakariki</i>, q.v.) has the following species - Antipodes Island P.- <i>tycercus unicolor,</i>. Orange-fronted P. <i>alpinus</i>ller Red-fronted P.- P. <i>novae-zelandiae,</i> Sparrm. Rowley's Parrakeet <i>Platycercus rowleyi,</i> Buller. Yellow-fronted P.- <i>P. auriceps</i>, Kuhl. <i>(1898,Austral English,341</i>)

>  We have also no less than four species of parrakeets ... <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,196</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Kakariki. 1. </i>n. <i>Cyanorhamphus novae-zealandiae, small green parrot,</i> parakeet. <i>(1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,108</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> Parrakeets were very common, and developed a keen appetite for fat. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,11</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE</b> The liquid notes of tuis and moko-mokos rang out in unison, and kaw-kaws and [90] parakeets made splashes of colour as the sun caught their iridescent wings. <i>(1930,NZ Memories,89</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> Bush robins, parakeets, tomtits, grey warblers, riflemen, pigeons and the bush hawk are still to be seen. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,129</i>)

>  <b>REISCHEK</b> The birds I noticed were the bell-bird, the blight-bird, the yellow-headed tit, the ground lark, the little parakeet, the banded dotterel, and the native snipe. <i>(1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,275,1933 ed.</i>)

>  <b>JACKSON</b> In one [of Buller's aviary cages], there were parrakeets, yellow heads, New Zealand canary, fantails, robins and tom tits, and a pio pio (New Zealand thrush) one of our best songsters - ... <i>(1935,Annals of a NZ Family,129</i>)

>  <i>(Jun 1, 1966,Weekly News,17/1</i>) [NOTES: [OEDS]]

>  <b>HUNT</b> I heard a parakeet yesterday. <i>(1985,I'm Ninety-five</i>) [NOTES: (Wattie, Stewart I.)]

>  It (sc. <i>Copromea</i> scrub) was in fruit, and on the fruit were feeding two kinds of parrakeet, unknown in New Zealand. <i>(Mar 6, 1890,Otago Witness,11</i>)

>  <b>PATRICK</b> Parakeets were then very numerous in Karori. <i>(1990,From Bush to Jubilee,16</i>) [NOTES: Quote from HOLLARD ?1890]

>  'Twas in the year of fifty-six / When some odd million paroquets / Came practising their evil tricks / About the bush Green Island. <i>(1889,Lay of the Old Identities, The,29</i>)

>  THE CHATHAM ISLANDS [From the <i>Lyttleton Times</i>.] .. The land birds now found are a large kite, the pigeon, the tui or Parson Bird, .. the parakeet (<i> Platycerus Sp.</i>[sic]) .. all identical with the birds from the same genera found in New Zealand. <i>(May 5, 1866,Taranaki Herald,5</i>)

>  The parakeets were caught by dropping a hat on them . . . <i>(Dec 4, 1907,Evening Post,8</i>)



## paraki
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Retropinna retropinna</i>, smelt (freshwater)

>  <b>HULME & MORRISON</b> Whitebait in pristine condition are beautiful... There are local names for them, too - elephant ears and Don Doolin 'bait (which isn't true whitebait at all), and cucumbers (which are actually smelt, Retropinna retropinna, or paraki). <i>(1989,Homeplaces,104</i>)

>  <b>BRUNNER</b> December is a glorious month of dietary amongst the natives on the coast ... The rivers, large or small, abound in eels, <i>hawera, upukuroro, haparu, patiki</i> and <i>parauki;</i> ... [fn] ... parauki is <i>Paraki</i> smelt (<i>Retropinna retropinna</i>). <i>(1848,Journal of an Expedition</i>) [NOTES: 1848 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 293]

>  Paraki - this is the small fish now called the `silvery'. It was described to me as smaller than the minnow and of a lighter colour. <i>(1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,63</i>) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 63]

>  19 RETROPINNA RETROPINNA (Richardson). <i>Smelt.</i> Called `paraki' by the Maoris of Arahura, on the west coast of the South Island. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts. <i>(Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/1</i>) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

>  <i>Vernacular Name</i>.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> and <i>Retropinna retropinna.</i> At present Canterbury residents refer to <i>R. retropinna</i> as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.' <i>(1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/291</i>) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

>  <i>Retropinna retropinna:</i> [European Name] Smelt [Maori Name] Paraki. <i>(1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,73</i>)

>  <i>Retropinna retropinna</i> (Richardson). Smelt. <i>Paraki. </i> <i>(1938,TrRSNZ,68/40</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> In some other localities these young [smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus. </i> <i>(1940,Fishes NZ,54</i>)

>  <b>GRAHAM</b> SMELT (PARAKI) <i>Retropinna retropinna</i> (Richardson) ... They are often referred to as Silvery, while in other parts they are called Cucumber Fish. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,113</i>)

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> <i>Paraki</i>, a small fish like white bait, caught at the mouth of Waitaki. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,312</i>)

## parakoka
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>LINDSAY</b> In Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Koura<i>d</i>i,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North Island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. In the North [83] Island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.' <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,82</i>)

>  The principal sorts are large brown Parrots [ed. note [Kaka, <i>Nestor septentrionalis</i>.]] with white or greyish heads, green Parroquets, [ed. note [Red-fronted Parrakeet, <i>Cyanorhamphus novae-zelandiae.</i>]] with red foreheads, large wood Pigeons, ... <i>(Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/806,1967 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/806 (Queen Charlotte Sound) [also entered at parroquet]]

## paraoa
 
 <i>n.</i> the sperm whale

>  <b>POLACK</b> Among the leviathans, who sport in shoals around these shores, the para paraua [a's-acute], or <i>sperm-whale</i> (Physeter macrocephalus); the tohora, or <i>right-whale </i>(Balaena bysticoetus); the mungu nui, or <i>black physeter</i>; the sun-fish (Diodonmola); <i>fin-back</i> (Balaena physalis); the <i>musculus</i>, or large-lipped whale; ... <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/323</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> The paraoa or sperm whale, the pakake or humpback whale, and the black fish (a relative of the dolphin and the common porpoise) were used as food. <i>(1966,Maori Life and Custom,31</i>)

>  <b>LEE & KENDALL</b> Par|awa, s. A sperm whale; <i>(1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,190</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> Maori bread

>  bread - pahbah [paraoa] <i>(1835,Boultbee Journal,112,1986 ed.</i>) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 112]

>  <b>BAXTER</b> I saw the Maori Jesus/ ... His breath smelt of mussels and paraoa. <i>(1979,Collected Poems,347,1966 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> paraoa <i>bread </i> <i>(1982,Selected Poems,189</i>)

>  Even food is glorified by the transfer of its name to fresh morsels of humankind. Braving the rain there are Hukas (Sugars), there are sweet girls dubbed Winika (Vinegar), there is Ti (Tea), Miraki (Milk), Paraoa (Flour), Arani (Orange). <i>(Jun 9, 1906,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  <b>Patricia Grace</b> 'Mauria mai he riwai,' if they wanted spuds; 'Mauria mai he paraoa,' if they wanted bread. <i>(1980,It Used to be Green Once,46,Penguin 1986 ed.</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> an object made from whalebone, often a patu or weapon.

>  He then seized another gun, which he threw away, and took a whalebone (paraoa). <i>(Jun 5, 1863,Otago Witness,5</i>)

>  In keeping with the native traditional custom the following presents were made:- three korowai mats and one piu-piu by Mrs Mahuta, one korawai and two piu-pius by Mrs Ngakuru, one taiha, one patu paraoa (kotiatu). <i>(Aug 17, 1908,Taranaki Herald,5</i>)

>  .. Te Moro went after him in the water, and in closing with him Matene said "Pai Marie, Pai Marie," when Moro dispatched him with a paraoa (whalebone weapon). <i>(Jun 4, 1864,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)

>  These were brought down to Aramoho on Wednesday, together with a quantity of arms, guns, patu, paraoa, and grand mats, which were given up by the conquered tribes. <i>(Mar 18, 1865,Otago Witness,4</i>)

>  .. but that he had sent his parawa to the Governor in token of submission, and that in future there was to be peace on the Wanganui river [sic]. <i>(Apr 12, 1865,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3</i>)

>  [Reprinted from the Wellington <i>Spectator</i>, Sept.24.) .. The same ceremony was gone through by all the other chiefs present at the delivery, and was likwise performed on a patu paraoa, an instrument of war, also a very old heir-loom of Taratoa's tribe. <i>(Oct 8, 1853,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3</i>)

## parapara
 
 <i>n.</i> the bird-catching tree, a small tree of northern North Island, with long leaves and sticky fruit that sometimes entrap small birds. [Maori]

>  Commonly known plants that have insect-trapping defence mechanisms (usually sticky hairs) include tomato, potato, petunia, rhododendron, and our own notorious bird-catching tree parapara with its sticky seed pods. <i>(Aug 2002,Forest & Bird,305/14</i>)

>  Parapara, also known as the birdcatcher tree, often snares fantails on its sticky pods. <i>(Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/84</i>)

>  In our little bush, we have the parapara, or bird-eater <i>(Dec 16, 1924,Otago Witness,6</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Pisonia Sinclairii, <i>Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Parapara',</i> Col. <i>(1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 209</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Para-para, <i>Col[enso]. Pisonia Sinclairii. </i> <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),767</i>)

>  <i>The Parapara. Pisonia umbellifera</i>, Seeman. ... This plant is found in several localities north of Whangarei ... <i>(1884,TrNZI,16/367</i>)

>  <b>CHEESEMAN</b> <i>P[isonia] Brunoniana, Endl</i>. ... A glabrous shrub or small tree ... [576] <i>Parapara.</i> <i>(1906,Manual NZ Flora,575</i>)

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>Pisonia Brunoniana (The Parapara)</i> ... Maori name <i>Para-para;</i> sometimes called by the settlers the <i>Bird-catching plant</i>. North Island: Auckland province chiefly. <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,159,1940 p. 165 ed.</i>)

>  <i>parapara</i>, a tree (Pisonia Bruniniana), bird-catching tree: its sticky leaves are liable to entrap small birds; the tree does not eat them as the sundew does entrapped insects. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/155</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>MARTIN</b> 4. Parapara (<i>Heimerliodenron brunoniana</i>) leaves opposite, 4-15 in. long; ... fruits long thin, very viscous. [north N. Island]. <i>(1961,Flora NZ,163</i>)

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i>PISONIA BRUNONIANA.</i> Parapara is a small tree of quick, rather soft growth carrying leaves up to 40cm long, of dark glossy green ... Nodular ridges down the length of the `fruit' ... secrete a glutinous substance ... Most spectacular is the ability of this tarry substance to hold small birds. ... anyone who has seen a waxeye struggling to free itself from amongst a cluster of these fruits can easily understand why parapara has earned the name `bird-catching tree'. ... Where it grows with pukanui (<i>Meryta sinclairii</i>) two of our largest-leaved trees come together. <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,60</i>)

>  <b>DAWSON</b> On the mainland as well as on islands, and extending to East Cape and beyond, are the small trees parapara or the `bird catching tree' (<i>Pisonia brunoniana</i>) and tawapou (<i>Planchonella costata</i>). <i>(1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,110</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  The Poor Knights are home to.. theparapara plant which traps small birdson its sticky seed pods. <i>(Apr 26, 1993,Evening Post,21</i>)

## parara
 
 <i>n.</i> the broad-billed prion, a sea-bird.

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> We also got four kinds of Petrel in their burrows,- the Mutton Bird, Parara, Titi Wainui, and the Kuaka. <i>Ibid.</i> 201<i> Prion Vittatus</i> - Broad-billed Petrel - Parara or Parera. The latter word is elsewhere applied to the Grey Duck - Anas Superciliosa. <i>(1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,16</i>)

>  <b>HOWARD</b> These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: <i>Pelicanoides Urinatrix</i>, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: <i>Prion Turtur</i> or Dove Petrel. Parara: <i>Prion vittatus</i>, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: <i>Puffinus Griseus</i> or Mutton-Bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches. <i>(1940,Rakiura,205</i>)

>  <b>DEMPSEY</b> ... I ... came upon Arthur , who'd just dug out two adult parara, another species of petrel, also called the broad-billed prion. <i>(1964,Little World of Stewart island,53</i>)

>  <i>47. Pachyptila vittata vittata</i> (Forster, 1777) <i>Broad-billed Prion(Parara) </i> <i>(1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,24,1980 ed.</i>)

>  <i>Broad-billed Prion Pachyptila vittata vittata</i> (FORSTER, 1777) ... OTHER NAMES: <i>Whalebird, scooper, blue-billy, parara. ... Body blue-grey with conspicuous black open-pattern across upper wings.</i> <i>(1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,85</i>)

## Parihaka
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The Parihaka prisoners faired better onthe whole than their counterparts. <i>(Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31</i>)

>  It has even been said that Gandhi heard the Parihaka story and was suitably inspired... "Why do we celebrate Guy Fawkes Day? Why not have Parihaka Day?" <i>(May 1, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  [Hdg] Could Guy Fawkes Day become Parihaka Day? <i>(Dec 14, 2003,NZ Catholic,6</i>)

>  The district has been invaded by a partyof Parihaka Maoris, some 80 strong, inpursuit of that commercially mysteriousproduct known as fungus, and once styledin derision "Taranaki wool." <i>(Mar 23, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The story of the Taranaki village of Parihaka and its two visionary leaders, Te Whiti o Rongomai and Toku Kaka, whose campaign of passive resistance culminated in 1881 in the invasion and destruction of Parihaka by 1500 militia, has been a lightning rod for cultural and political energy in this country... The exhibition brings together for the first time the wealth of artwork inspired by Parihaka. <i>(Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32</i>)

>  As the author rightly says in his preface, Parihaka has achieved an "almost mythic status in our national consciousness"... Even his defiantly impartial hero, reading about Parihaka, is reminded of "what he had seen and experienced as a child and a youth in Ireland; the dawn horror of eviction; red skies and the smell of burning hovels; lamentations and anger; riots and his father dead on the waterlogged road." <i>(Aug 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41</i>)

>  <b>IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.)</b> Again we gather in this place, here at Parihaka, on the marae of peace, to hear the word of God - we listen, we pray, we sing. <i>Ibid.</i> 37 The rape of Parihaka - a peaceful, and almost unarmed, defenceless village - was to be carried out not by British Imperial Forces but by true New Zealanders, and the invasion plans were hurried up because the Governor was out of the country. <i>(1982,Into the World of Light,33</i>)

>  No one put up a fight - indeed, it was against the rules to have a weapon of war in Parihaka - but the passive gestures had their own power and poetry, as simple and effective as a Vietnam war protestor sliding a flower's stem down the barrel of a gun. <i>(May 1, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  This stone was deeply significant, astone by which to remember the pain ofthe land wars in Taranaki that culminatedin the destruction of Parihaka in 1881. <i>(Aug 8, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30</i>)

>  Paarihaka is new Zealand's legendary village of peace. ... It's no secret Parihaka is the crown jewel as far as tourism is concerned here in Taranaki, and probably the whole country. <i>(Nov 20, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C1</i>)

>  Those acquainted with the story will know how both Te Whiti and Tohu - the prophets of Parihaka - were imprisoned by the colonial authorities and how their lands were subsequently taken and confiscated. <i>(Dec 14, 2003,NZ Catholic,6</i>)

>  Scott stumbled onto Parihaka when he was in bed with chickenpox and happened to be reading a British high court law report. "A place called Parihaka was in it, and I couldn't believe it, it was all about libel action." <i>(Aug 10, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57</i>)

>  Parihaka under Te Whiti is, in fact, a splendid example of a successful communistic settlement - held together, as "New Australia" could not be held, by "the religion of the thing." <i>(Apr 4, 1899,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  [Walker] believes that Parihaka was an immensely crucial event, a great symbolic moment not only in our history but in world history. <i>(Jul 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59</i>)

>  There you have the whole process of how the Maori preserved his albatross, ready to be shipped to Parihaka, a donation from the Chathams to feed the yearly March 18 gathering of the tribes to hearTe Whiti's latest message to his race. <i>(Sep 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,18</i>)

>  One of the things I'd like to see come out of this [exhibition] is the awareness of people generally throughout Aotearoa, their understanding of what Parihaka means, and why it's so significant to the people of Taranaki. Many people really don't know much about Parihaka and its early history, or the implications of Parihaka. <i>(Nov 16, 2000,City Voice,Parihaka Supplement : [4]</i>)

>  At this time.. bands of native fanatics..were massing themselves together atParihaka, and singing paeans to thepseudo prophet Te Whiti. <i>(Jun 2, 1883,Auckland Weekly News</i>)

>  The passive resistance carried out by Te Whiti and the other brave people in this small Taranaki settlement of Parihaka against the might of the British and settler armies was a major event in colonial history... Hinchcliff's <i>Parihaka</i> brings to life the personalities and events of the 1880s. <i>(Jul 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C7</i>)

## Parkhurst boy
 
 <i>n.</i> a reformed juvenile offender sent from Parkhurst prison in the Isle of Wight to Auckland in the 1840s [ORIGIN: British dialect, also erroneously Parker's boy]

>  But while we wish never to see the face of another Convict, or Parkhurst Boy, arrive in this colony, we are still persuaded that it is quite practicable to convert these pests of society into benefactors of their race. <i>(Nov 25, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,2</i>)

>  Then there were the Parkhurst boys, who had committed petty crimes, were reared, and then the people at Home sent out here a shipload of those boys. <i>(May 19, 1888,Te Aroha News,6</i>)

>  Curious enough we find, in a parallel column with the notice of the arrival of the Parkhurst boys, which we are glad to say was the only importation of the same class of characters, the following paragraph in reference to the 'Jane Gifford' and 'Duchess of Argylle,' the immigrants by which ships so recently celebrated the twentieth anniversary of their arrival in the colony. <i>(Oct 31, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,9</i>)

>  THE PARKHURST BOYS.Among the circumstances which have contributed to the popularity of New Zealand as an emigration-field with intending colonists at home, its total freedom from the baneful effects of "Convictism" is, probably the most powerful. <i>(Dec 10, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3</i>)

>  <b>PHILIPS</b> A great deal of mischief was done ...by the importation of `Parkhurst Boys, as they were termed, who were sent out from home a reformatory. <i>(1886,Memoirs of the Post,11</i>) [NOTES: [1850s] 1897 [? pub 1886] Philips Memoirs of the Post 11]

>  <b>ANGAS</b> A number of boys, reformed juvenile offenders, from the Parkhurst prison in the Isle of Wight, [286] have from time to time been sent out to Auckland, for the purpose of being apprenticed to such of the settlers as would take them; ... <i>(1847,Savage Life,1/285</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> [In 1842] when the secretary of state appointed a judge and as attorney general for New Zealand, he sent out one hundred Parkhurst boys as emigrants; and these reformed prisoners, in one year after their arrival, doubled the felony cases in the colony, ... <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/65</i>)

>  <b>BEASLEY</b> Runaway sailors, escaped convicts from Sydney, (locally known as `Parker's Boys' on account of the association of some of them with Parker's Gaol in Sydney) and others of a similar type provided the principal labour supply [in Auckland] <i>(1936,Pioneering Days,18</i>) [NOTES: [c1840] 1936-7 Beasley Pioneering Days 18]

>  Another party of natives had set out along the coast, and towards evening returned, having succeeded in overtaking and capturing two more of the gang, "Wilson," [sic] <i>alias</i> Hicks, and a <i>Parkhurst</i> boy. The three former were committed to take their trial, and the Parkhurst boy remanded for further examination. <i>(Dec 14, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,2</i>)

>  The prisoner, George Smith, who was sentenced to thirty days' imprisoment [sic] for the assault, is a Parkhurst boy, and came from Auckland. <i>(Jul 18, 1846,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2</i>)

 <i>n.</i> (informal) a paradise duck [ORIGIN: abbreviation, also pari]

## partial impact
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Partial Impact explains light, heat, electricity, gravitation, Freethought, Socialism, epidemic diseases, - explainds in short everything in the heavens above, the earth beneath, and the waters under the earth, except the unwillingness of the world to receive thte theory itself. <i>(Jul 31, 1880,Otago Witness,17</i>)

>  At the meeting of the members of the Philosophical Institute last evening, Professor Bickerton read a paper "On temporary and variable stars," in which he treated of the partial impact of two large bodies as a possible frequent occurence, and as giving a perfectly satisfactory explanation of temporary and variable stars, of double stars, of all kinds of nebulae, of comets, and indeed of all the varied phenomena of the universe. <i>(Jul 5, 1878,Star, The,2</i>)

>  This appears to be the position of Professor Bickerton's theory of Partial Impact, and we should say that he is justified in asserting that, "The fact that astronomers are working without it has already caused irreparable loss to science ..." <i>(Feb 12, 1894,Timaru Herald,4</i>)

>  Putting on full steam ahead, Hoani steered straight for the electric freight car, and disregarding Professor Bickerton's partial impact theory, he crashed full into Trow's wagon. <i>(Dec 31, 1921,NZ Truth,6</i>)

>  In 1878 Bickerton revealed his partial impact theory of the creation of new stars which formed the basis of his theory of cosmic evolution. The notion that the oblique collision of two stars produces a new, hot, rapidly expanding body without destroying the original two in the process explained virtually all astronomical mysteries for Bickerton, but provoked only indifference or scepticism from scientists. <i>(Sep 13, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  Partial impact appears competent to explain the occurrence of temporary, double, and variable stars, nebulae of various kinds (the kind depending on the nature of the impact), comets, and finally stars or suns accompanied by bodies of smaller size. <i>(1879,TrNZI,XI/121</i>)

>  The hypothesis I am about to describe suggests that this is the case, but especially says further, that if they do knock against each other that the blow may be a mere graze of the two outside, or sometimes a large piece of each may be struck off, and in extremely rare cases they may meet fair; but as this latter isso extremely rare, the other cases are those chiefly considered, and so the theory is called Partial Impact. <i>(1880,TrNZI,XII/191</i>)

>  <b>JENKINSON</b> It was on 4 July 1878.. that Bickerton read before the Philosophical Institute of Canterbury his paper "On Temporary and Variable Stars" in which the main facts of the theory of partial impact were first announced. <i>(1940,New Zealanders & Science,00</i>) [NOTES: Pages needed]

>  <b>von HAAST</b> This was the first occasion upon which the Professor was to enunciate publicly his theory of "Partial Impact" which was to become an obsession with him. <i>(1948,Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast,235</i>)

>  <i>Partial Impact: a possible Explanation of the Origin of the Solar System, Comets, and other Phenomena of the Universe</i>. By Professor A.W. Bickerton, F.C.S. ... <i>(1879,TrNZI,11/125</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> The hypothesis that I am about to describe suggests that this [collisions] is the case, but especially says further that if they do knock against each other, the blow may be a mere graze of the two outsides, or sometimes a large piece of each other may be struck off: and in extremely rare cases they may meet fair; but as this latter is so extremely rare the other cases are those chiefly considered, and so the theory is called <i>Partial Impact.</i> The effect of the collision of our two stars will be to strike a piece off each other where they touch, and each star will travel on with a slice cut off the side of each. The parts of each which met will be left behind by both the retreating bodies, and will probably remain where the collision occurred. But, owing to the way it has been struck off, the two sides being impelled in opposite directions, it cannot help revolving, and it is not unlikely that nearly all the thousands of rotating bodies and systems in the universe may have thus been set spinning by partial impact. At partial impact, rotation must ensue. The matter will tend to spread out more or less in a flare, with frequently gas at the poles and the middle body produced by the collision will generally be very hot, proportional to the mass. <i>(1948,Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast,236</i>) [NOTES: 188? A. W. Bickerton to the Canterbury Philosophical Institute quoted in 1948 Von Haast Life and Times of Sir Julius Von Haast 236]

>  <b>LEE</b> As a youngster I remember the New Zealand press talking of Bickerton and his theory of partial impact. <i>(1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,110</i>)

>  I want to know.. why your theory of partial impact is not being recognized and accepted in the scientific world. <i>(Jul 11, 1910,Triad, The,XVIII(4) : 49</i>)

>  He will never get weary / Of answering any query / On the partial impact theory; / Will you, Bick? <i>(1923,College Rhymes,14</i>)

>  It is most singular that this first, this fundamental, this absolutely basic idea of a third body, has for a quarter of a century been missed by astronomers. They have been bombarded with tens of thousands of papers and pamphlets. Diagrams showing the third body have been broadcasted before them by thousands and by hundreds. A new term - "Partial Impact" - was specially coined to express the idea for their benefit and guidance. But there they sit in their specialized turrets, regardless; and this prime idea, that the parts struck from grazing suns are welded into a third body, has failed to impress them. <i>(Apr 1, 1908,Progress,188</i>)

>  The Cabinet has decided to aid Professor Bickerton, of Christchurch, to proceed to England and Europe to lay before scientists there his "partial impact theory," subsidising up to GBP300 any amount that may be raised by subscription. <i>(Mar 19, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,8</i>)

## pass
 
 <i>n.</i> a narrow or small aperture, down which the quartz is passed from the upper to the lower tunnels

>  Clad in trousers and singlet, they are bust shovelling the quartz down a "pass" to the level below. <i>(1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(8) : 20</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> As the mine workings reached greater depths the ground generally became more solid and stable and more and more shrinkage stopes were worked, until this method became the principal one in use for stopes up to about forty feet in width. The method consisted of putting in the level timbers in the usual way, with short chutes or `passes' installed every other set to allow all the ore in the stope to be lowered evenly as it was worked. <i>Ibid.</i> 209 ... including ... chutes for ore-handling, or `passes' as they were generally known. <i>Ibid.</i> 315 <i>Chutes or passes</i>: Chutes for running the broken ore out of the stopes into the hand-trucks were, for shrinkage stopes, placed between alternate sets (about 10 ft centres). They were about three feet wide, mounted three inches above the truck, and fitted with top and bottom doors. The bottom door was removed and the flow of ore into the truck controlled by jambing a pass-bar across the chute. (This was a short bar about three feet long with a D-shaped handle). The bottom of the chute was inclined at about 50 degrees from horizontal. For filled stopes, the chute was installed at the bottoms of the cribbed ore passes, leading up through the filling to the face of the stope; the ore passes were usually spaced from 18 to 25 ft apart along the stope, this being a convenient distance for men to shovel the ore. <i>Ibid.</i> 329 <i>Passes:</i> See chutes. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,193</i>)

## Patent Slip
 
 <i>n.</i> a slip for ship repair at Evans Bay

>  There was a fierce beauty about its scale, the precision of its movements, the way everything meshed to deliver the raw power to haul ships out of the water at the old Patent Slip in Evans Bay... Wellington Provincial Council let a contract for a slip in Evans Bay in 1868 but wrangling between the council and contractor stalled progress and the job was completed by the Wellington Patent Slip Company in 1873. For the next 96 years the slip hauled 6000 ships up the rails on its concrete incline - a total of more than two million tonnes deadweight. <i>(Jun 9, 2001,Evening Post,29</i>)

## patiti
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) tall tussock; a kind of grass. [ORIGIN: Maori]

In one southern dialect, <i>wi</i> was used for silver tussock (further north the same word was applied to rushes) and <i>patiti</i> seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with <i>maania</i> an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular. <i>(Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40</i>)

These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. <i>Ibid.</i> 312 PATITI, a coarse grass growing in tufts (<i>tritium scabrum, Raoul</i>).; <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,10</i>)

>  The battle then became general. A number of women were in the heat of the action, among whom was Tippahee's old wife, not much less than seventy years of age, and Duaterra's wife bearing in her hand a patoo about seven feet long, made out of the jawbone of a whale. [fn] This weapon, the <i>hoeroa</i>, was made almost invariably of whale bone. All specimens extant are made from the lower jaw of the sperm whale. Both ends are rounded, one end being elaborately carved; there is often, also, some carving about the middle. About five feet in length, it seems to have been used, for the most part, as a missile weapon. - <i>Vide</i> Elsdon Best, <i>The Maori As He Was</i>, p.276 <i>et seq. </i> <i>(1814,Letters & Journals,92 and fn [=hoeroa],1932 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> Some of his officers stood up and regulated all their movements both by word of command and signal made by their large pattoes ornamented with feathers which they held in their hands and kept in constant motion. <i>(1814,Letters & Journals,91,1932 ed.</i>) [NOTES: [=taiaha or tewhatewha]]

>  <b>ELDER</b> <i>(1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,86</i>) [NOTES: [(for Patus) PATU; with useful note] (Griffiths Collection)]

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> The chiefs were all seated on the ground, according to their custom, and their warriors standing up with their spears fixed upright which were from 15 to 20 feet in length and upwards. They were armed also with their pattooes (<i>patus</i>). [fn] The root idea of the word <i>patu</i> is `to strike.' The word is applied by the Maoris to all weapons, and also, with a qualifying adjective, to pounders and beaters of flax, fern-root, etc. The early explorers, e.g. Cook, restricted the term to weapons of the <i>mere </i>type, and, as a generic term for this group of weapons is useful - in fact necessary - the usage, though not strictly a Maori one, has been followed by modern ethnographers. <i>(1814,Letters & Journals,86 and fn</i>)

## pavlova
 
 <i>n.</i> a meringue dessert cake, for which the first recipe was published in 1929 in New Zealand. [Note on conversation with Deidre Macken (60 yrs) about her mother's story (86 yrs). She was in the Wellington Ballet Company in 1926 and on news of Pavlova's tour wrote to her manager enquiring how they could help make her tour and reception more pleasant, her favourite colours, foods, etc. She expressed a great liking for meringue (cakes) so they consulted a chef who produced 3 attempts (e.g. a square cake was rejected in favour of a round one); finally the `soft-centre' variety was chosen. In her honour they named it Pavlova (?cake) and they presented this to Pavlova (? at a gathering) and she liked it a great deal. D. Macken is to research this - ? Ballet company records, etc. Deidre Macken (04) 384-6073 - H.D. Macken, Nairn St.]

>  The Editor,The DominionPavlova - Name and NatureSir, -- In spite of silly claims regularly surfacing especially in Australia (Dominion 2/2/99), the facts of the development of the confections and the date the name `pavlova' was applied to them have been reasonably well known for some years now. They may be found in the Dictionary of NZ English (1997), the Australian National Dictionary (1988), and the writings of Professor Helen Leach of Otago University.The name `pavlova' post-dated the ballerina Pavlova's Australasian tour of 1926, and was first applied in New Zealand by the Davis Gelatine Company in 1927 to a jelly dessert whose moulded multicoloured shape may have suggested a tutu. It was next (in 1929) applied independently (and only in NZ) as `pavlova cake' or `sponge' or `meringue' to the previously well known so-called `meringue cake' or `sponge'. The recipe change to the legendary pavlova icon is usually reputed in NZ to be the addition of vinegar to give the soft centre, and in Australia, the trademark of passionfruit in the topping. (The name `pavlova' does not occur in either the Futter book (1926) or the Terrace Tested Recipes (1927) mentioned in your report.)The elliptical simple form `pavlova' for the meringue is recorded earliest in Australia from 1940 (so AND, two of whose quotations acknowledge NZ as the originator) and in NZ from 1953 (DNZE).There is no evidence that the name `pavlova' was applied in Australia before 1940. Both countries share the earliest recorded date 1966 (and the same quotation) for the abbreviation `pav'.The New Zealand Dictionary Centre at Victoria University (Box 600, Wellington) would be glad of any pre-datings of any of the above, with author, title, date, and page references.Harry Orsman <i>(Feb 2, 1999,Dominion,00</i>) [NOTES: Check date of publication. "Terrace Tested Recipes collected by the Ladies of Terrace Congregational Church" was published by Whitcombe & Tombs in 1927 (191 pp). There were three editions in 1927; the first is held by Turnbull, the 3rd was held by Te Papa (Hector Library) but recent report (HO) says they no longer have it.]

>  Contrary to what they'll tell you in Perth, Western Australia, Bert Sache, a chef at the Esplanade Hotel did not invent the pavlova. All he did, in 1935, was to make a meringue and cream cake that he said was "light as Pavlova", the Russian ballet dancer who six years earlier had stayed at the hotel. but the name stuck and thus was born the myth about its origins. The truth is that the large meringue with the marshmallow centre - the heart of the pavlova - was common in New Zealand in the early 1930s, even earlier. In 1927, for instance, there was a recipe for a meringue cake submitted by a Mrs McRae in the second edition of <i>Terrace Tested Recipes</i>, collected by the ladies of the Terrace Congregational Church in Wellington. <i>(May 18, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,5</i>)

 <i>n.</i> multi-coloured and layered jelly mould, having the appearance of a tasteless tutu [[Could this have been both in the jelly and meringue varieties originally an Otago-conceived dish? cf SOUTHLAND SURPRISE mentioned in ?MORE magazine]]

>  <i>Pavlova</i> [heading below a coloured picture of a fluted (`pleated' or `tutued') turned-out moulded jelly mound, coloured in layers from top to bottom green, white, orange-yellow, and red, and standing on a plain dish, with no background] <i>Ingredients </i>1 1/2 cups hot water/ 1 cup orange juice/ 1/2 cup milk/ 3 dessertspoons Davis gelatine/ 6 dessertspoons sugar/ Flavouring/ cochineal - sap green colouring <i>Directions </i>Dissolve all but a teaspoonful of Gelatine ... [arrange orange or other fruits around base: serve with cream or custard] <i>(1927,Davis Dainty Dishes,11,6th ed.</i>)

>  <i>Pavlova 8-10 servings.</i>[The coloured picture is now larger, the background, and directions, more complex] 8-10 Servings <i>(1937,Davis Dainty Dishes,39,13th ed.</i>)

>  <i>Pavlova 6 Servings</i> [Picture essential;ly same as 1937: added directions for use of refrigerator.] <i>(1943,Davis Dainty Dishes,57,reprint ed.</i>)

>  <i>PAVLOVA </i>... hot water ... orange juice ... milk ... Davis Gelatine ... sugar ... Flavouring ... Cochineal - sap green ... serve with cream or custard ... <i>(1928,Davis Dainty Dishes,11</i>)

>  Pavlova. 6 Servings. Ingredients. Davis Gelatine, Hot water, Sugar, 1/4 cup milk, Slices of oranges, 3/4 cup orange juice, Lemon essence, Vanilla essence, Cochineal, Green colouring, Citric acid. Method. First layer: Dissolve 1-1/2 teaspoons gelatine and 1 dessertspoonful sugar in 1/2 cup hot water; add a pinch of citric acid and lemon essence to flavour. Divide the mixture, colour one half red and the other green. Pour the green into a mould. Second layer: Dissolve 1 teaspoon gelatine in 2 tablespoons hot water. Add 1 Dessertspoon sugar to 1/4 cup milk; stir until dissolved. Flavour with vanilla essence. Add gelatine. Carefully pour on to the green layer, which must be firm. Third layer: Dissolve 1 dessertspoon gelatine in 1/4 cup hot water, add 3/4 cup orange juice, 3 dessertspoons sugar or more. When the milk layer is firm, arrange orange circles round the mould and add the orange jelly, which should be thickening a little at a time. Fourth layer: Re-melt the red jelly, if it has set, by standing in hot water. When cold pour over the orange layer, which should be firm. <i>If setting in an ice-chest or refrigerator, use less gelatine - First mixture: 1 teaspoon. Second mixture: 3/4 teaspoon. Third mixture: 3/4 dessertspoon. </i> <i>(1937,Davis Dainty Dishes,57</i>) [NOTES: 1937 Davis Gelatine Organisation Davis Dainty Dishes [editions 1-8 1922 to 1936] 57]

## peelie
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,Yesterdays in Maoriland,288</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

Divide into balls; make a hole in each ... insert ... jam; ... dip in beaten white of egg, in sugar ... bake .. They should crack and show the jam. <i>(1915,Bungalow Recipe Book, The,9</i>)



## peewee
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble (cf. piss-wee)

>  <b>SCANLAN</b> `Reverend Mother talks of when she used to give you marbles for being a good little boy - pee-wees and agates, and stonies and glassies and a big tor. And once she tried to play with you, and you said she funked because her knuckle was inside the ring.' <i>(1933,Tides of Youth,153</i>)

>  <b>FRAME</b> `Treasure' I played ringie and holie. I played funs and keeps. I had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And I won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... <i>(1951,Lagoon, The,116,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,Yesterdays in Maoriland,288</i>)



## peg
 
 <i>n.</i> a boundary marker

>  RURAL SECTIONS CHOSEN ... E. Wright. 50 acres in the Christchurch district, commencing on the sixth mile peg, ... <i>(Apr 26, 1851,Lyttelton Times,3</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> This boundary was always debatable ground - it was always imperatively necessary that claims should be `pegged out', and this rule was of necessity `more honoured in the breach than in the observance.' Pegs were not to be had, unless imported, and when introduced stood a great chance of helping to boil the neighbour's `billy'.' <i>(1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago,80,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <i>peg n.</i>-peg out' v.t. to mark out a claim as required by law. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> In the matter of a claim he told me that there was a piece of terrace above his top pegs that hadn't been worked out and might be worth a trial. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,88,1963 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a shilling

>  He dreamt he'd got his 14 `peg' / And buttoned it `Down South'. <i>(May 16, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,137</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Peg.</i> 5. A shilling: Scottish c.: 1839, Brandon; Jennings, 1926. Also among New Zealand soldiers in G.W. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,615</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> policeman?; a police spy; a pimp

>  Fine. Diggers passing all day [to rush at Molyneux]. Keddell & two pegs came and stayed all night. <i>(Aug 25, 1862,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> notice, watch, survey

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> A few guys came in and pegged me, but they didn't do anything so I guessed they'd dropped their guts. <i>Ibid.</i> 176 The screws used to peg heavily for heaters during the months of winter.<i>Ibid.</i> 252 PEG (n) Notice, watch, survey. USA, from 1920s, or earlier. Origin too involved for explanation here. See Partridge. <i>Dictionary of the Underworld,</i> for an interesting derivation. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,117</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to mark out

>  <i>Peg</i> (p&ebreve.g),<i> v. t. 3. [Add.]</i> (Usually with<i> out</i>.) To mark out (a miner's claim or an agricultural selection) by pegs at the four corners, each bearing the claimant's name in conformity with Act of Parliament. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2028</i>)

## Pelorus Jack
 
 <i>n.</i> the name of a famous dolphin that escorted ships through French Pass near Pelorus Sound (1882-1912)

>  "Pelorus Jack," the well-known denizen ofthe French Pass.. has been missing forthe last couple of months. <i>(Jul 3, 1912,Otago Witness,33</i>)

>  <b>BARR</b> Passing through the home of "PelorousJack" [sic] several members of the teamremained in deck to catch a sight of thecurious white pilot. <i>(1908,With the British Rugby team,80</i>)

>  Various suggestions are ventured as to the species of the finny mystery, and it is suggested that it is a cousin to "Pelorus Jack," the mysterious white fish of the French Pass. <i>(Feb 28, 1901,Wanganui Herald,2</i>)

>  One or two five- or six-feet members of the finny [t]ribe were caught by caterers for the camp at School Bay, and it is reported that " Pelorus Jack" has forsaken his old haunt outside the Heads, where for many months he has patiently awaited a victim, to forage in Queen Charlotte Sound; at any rate passengers from Nelson to Picton no longer see the curious creature disporting itself at the heads, and, so the story goes, a huge black fin like a cross cut saw leaves a long wake in divers places in the Sound. <i>(Jan 18, 1897,Marlborough Express,2</i>)

>  While many believed he was guiding ships safely through the treacherous waters of French Pass, Mr Webber said Pelorus Jack didn't enter the pass at all... For Maori, the dolphin's history goes even further back than the 1880s. It is believed Pelorus Jack, known as Kaikaiawaro (food of the deep) to Maori, escorted descendants of Ngati Kuia into Pelorus Sound hundreds of years later. <i>(Dec 14, 2000,Evening Post,27</i>)

## penny doctor
 
 <i>n.</i> the larva of the tiger beetle [The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti).]

>  <b>ANDERSEN</b> The larva [of the tiger beetle] is also known as the penny-doctor among boys, [who catch them by putting grass straws in their burrows]. <i>(1942,Maori Place Names,451</i>)

>  <i>Penny Doctor</i> beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game. <i>(1951,Journal of the Polynesian Society,60/93-107</i>) [NOTES: 1951 JPS 60/93-107 (Sutton-Smith) in 1972 Sutton-Smith Folkgames of Children 328]

>  <b>NATUSCH</b> In summer [tiger beetles] are seen on sunny clay banks; holes in the ground contain the voracious larvae (`penny doctors'). <i>(1967,Animals of NZ, The,148</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> The little `penny-doctor' that is winkled out of its hole with a grass stalk may therefore be a descendant of the first settlers. fn] The `penny-doctor' is the larva of the tiger beetle <i>Cicindela tuberculata. </i> <i>(1977,Treasury of Maori Exploration,15</i>)

>  <b>HILLIARD</b> `See those holes in the ground?' ... `When we was little we use [sic] to stick dry grass-stalks down them to catch penny-doctors.' <i>(1978,Glory and the Dream, The,9</i>)

>  They would go fishing for "pennydoctors". <i>(Aug 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,80</i>)
