## pepino
 
 <i>n.</i> The cultivated tropical South American shrub <i>Solanum muricatum</i>, fam. Solenaceae, with sweet juicy, pale cream to orange fruit with longitudinal purple stripes; also known as Peruvian melon, melon shrub, melon pear; introduced into NZ before 1940.

>  A tropical species that is gaining in popularity in the milder districts of New Zealand is the Pepino (Solanum muricatum). <i>(Jan 1950,NZ Gardener,363</i>)

>  The word pepino is also used for the cucumber in Latin America... To distinguish between the two plants the pepino as we know it is referred to as pepino dulce, meaning "sweet". <i>(Dec 1979,Orchardist NZ,349</i>)

>  Among the lesser known and more exotic fruit bearing plants.. are.. jujube.. pepino.. and sapodilla. <i>(May 1979,Orchardist NZ,112</i>)

>  The subtropical South American pepino or 'melon shrub' has been developed.. especially to suit Canterbury conditions. <i>(Jun 1982,Orchardist NZ,143</i>)

>  Two more pepino cultivars have recently been released.. by.. D.S.I.R. <i>(Apr 1983,Orchardist NZ,88</i>)

>  This fruit is most commonly known as 'pepino' (the Spanish word for cucumber), but also as melon shrub or melon pear. <i>(1980,Aglink HPP,208/1</i>)

>  He cites the economic potential of the pepino on a par with the tamarillo. <i>(Jun 1982,Orchardist NZ,143</i>)

>  Pepino is a small shrub three feet in neght belonging to the same family as the tomato and producing egg-shaped fruits, yellow streaked with purple lines. <i>(1943,Whitcombe's Complete NZ Gardener,270</i>)

>  Pepino (Solanum muricatum)... The fruits have a delicious flavour and may be eaten like a melon, or made into jams or preserves. <i>(1949,Brett's Gardening Guide,253</i>)

>  The pepino is known botanically as Solanaceae Solanum muricatum Ait, although it is commonly referred to as pepino dulce, pepino melon, melon pear, melon shrub and pear melon. (In New Zealand, we mostly just call it pepino). <i>(Aug 12, 1999,Evening Post,19</i>)

>  <b>MATTHEWS</b> The pepino, Solanum muricatum, has oval shaped fruits of delicious flavour, the taste and aroma reminiscent of musk melon. <i>(1986,NZ Garden Book,241</i>)

>  For the future, keep your eyes open for kiwanos, okra, pepino, bitter melons and asparagus beans. <i>(Dec 1990,Cuisine,98</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> ... New Zealand horticulturalists have been on expeditions to the Andes and brought back other sub-tropicals to test under New Zealand conditions. These fruits include casanas, naranjillas, cherimoyas, casimiroas, carambolas, toronchis and pepinos. The last named are now available commercially. <i>(1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,138</i>)

>  /p |pi:n u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp. (Peru).] (See quot. 1968.) 1968 J.C. Th. UPHOF <i>Dict. Economic Plants</i> (ed.2) 490/2 Solanum muricatum Ait. Pepino (Solanaceae). Herbaceous plant. ## pepite
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Stray notes on Australia and the Diggings (Griffiths Collection) Origin of the word `Nugget'. - This word, now so common amongst our population, is a strange sounding word, and destitute of any apparent entymological meaning. It originated at the Ophir diggings in New South Wales, and is probably a corruption of `ingot', which is itself a corruption of `lingot', a little tongue. The wedge of gold which Achan purloined is called, in the original Hebrew, a `tongue' of gold, as a reference to a Bible with marginal readings will show. In California, the word `lump' is generally used, and sometimes the Spanish word `pepite.' <i>(Sep 1852,Leisure Hour, The,640</i>)

## Percy
 
 <i>n.</i> (humorous) Geol., see cit.

>  1980 saw the introduction of a new stratigraphic parameter, the Percy. No longer do geologists illustrate the scale of the outcrop photographs with such mundane objects as hammer, lens caps, 2 cent pieces and bananas. If in the forefront of geological technique they now take as an essential item of field equipment, Percy Strong. Such is Percy's usefulness as a unit of stratigraphic thickness, and so great is the magnetism of his image on screen, that one lecturer introduced his choicest slide with the pronouncement "that's Percy", and only then proceeded to describe the rocks. It is understood that Cathy, with callous disregard for the visual effect on her husband's figure, is knitting for Percy a cap-a-pie jumpsuit with 100 horizontal stripes so that thin-bedded sequences may be measured in centi-Percies (cPe); and further that Percy himself now steers clear of field trips in areas of steeply-dipping strata, to avoid the necessity of being photographed in a horizontal position in stream beds. <i>(Feb 1981,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,51/21</i>)

## peripatus
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  His slug is not a slug, but aperipatus... The peripatus is like a slugin general appearance. <i>(Dec 11, 1912,Otago Witness,68</i>)

>  "We would find wetas and peripatus. Do you know peripatus?... It's a very pretty creature with a crushed velvet body, greyish green - its whole body undulates beautifully - it's the missing link between the worms and the anthropods [sic] like crayfish or woodlice. It's segmented but each segment has a pair of small stumpy legs with two tiny claws." <i>(Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42</i>)

>  It is most commonly called peripatus - from the same Greek root as <i>peripatetic</i>, meaning itinerant or wandering... The animal is also called the velvet worm or walking worm - references to two of its more obvious traits. Peripatus are found largely in the southern hemisphere - in Australasia, south-east Asia, Africa and Central and South America. <i>Ibid.</i> 66 I have to roll my peripatus onto its back again to view the circular, lobe-lipped mouth with double pair of sickle-shaped mandibles, and the two lumpy "gun turrets" - oral papillae - used to such effect in the capture and consumption of prey. Both the jaws and oral papillae, as well as the antennae, are pairs of modified limbs. Peripatus are opportunistic and will scavenge in preference to expending energy on hunting. <i>Ibid.</i> 74 Peripatus may boast a lineage more ancient than that of New Zealand's other, more famous, "living fossil," the tuatara. Early marine animals, such as this 500-million-year-old fossil from the Burgess Shale in British Columbia, appear remarkably similar to living onycophorans... <i>P. novaezealandiae</i> females.. have been found to carry embryos at all stages of development at all times of year, and to give birth regardless of the season, albiet more abundantly in summer. <i>(Apr 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 46/60</i>)

>  It was generally remarked by the ladies present that the picaninny and the ladies of the Court looked very much better and better clothed than on the occasion of the former visit. <i>(Aug 9, 1881,Waikato Times,2</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>a little child</i>. The word is certainly not Australian. It comes from the West Indies (Cuban <i>piquinini</i>, little, which is from the Spanish <i>pequeno </i>small, and <i>nino</i>, child). The English who came to Australia, having heard the word applied to negro children of the aborigines. After a while English people thought the word was aboriginal Australian, while the aborigines thought it was correct English. It is pigeon-English. [1696: Aust 1830] <i>[351] used as adj. and figuratively, to mean little</i> <i>(1898,Austral English,350</i>)

>  <b>NICHOLAS</b> This fellow [a native servant] ... met me ... telling me that Mrs. King had got a <i>pickeeninnee</i>, (a child) he began to describe her groans ... while ... under the pains of labour; ... <i>Ibid.</i> 1/280 All the inhabitants flocked around us ... and the mothers, pointing to the children they carried in their arms, called out to us repeatedly, <i>homi pickeninnee wow,</i> which means, give the child a nail; ... <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/171</i>)

>  <b>LEIGH</b> They [Maoris] observed they could not let me have it, for if they did all their pickaninnies (their children) would die, ... . <i>(Aug 4, 1830,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1830 Aug 4 Rev. S. Leigh in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/709]

>  <b>MARSHAL</b> [A Maori says] `Mitter King ... teach picaniny so high' <i>(1834,Narrative of Two Visits,6</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Meanwhile the `pickers up' were busy gathering up the fleeces as they fell from the bereft sheep and carrying them to the sorting table, where they [173] were stripped of the `pieces', which were thrown aside, while the best of the fleece was quickly classified, rolled together, and deposited in a kind of bin, according to its quality, whether `clothing' or `combing.' <i>(1881,Waitaruna,172</i>)

>  <b>REES</b> The shearing and picking and culling - picking out the fat sheep to send to the freezing works, and culling the old ewes from the young ones. <i>(1924,Heather of the South,183</i>)

>  [Maori] carry their picaninees on their backs <i>(1841,NZ Journal,2/32/92</i>) [NOTES: (John Pierce)]

>  Richards and Mould returned yesterday with some traps, his woman, and the Picaninnies. <i>(May 18, 1842,Piraki Log,129,ed. Anson 1911 ed.</i>)

>  <b>EARP</b> [The natives] are very fond of horses ... They will buy nothing but mares, having a great desire to have `pickaninny' horses of their own. <i>(1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),145</i>)

>  Most of the picaninnies have been `down with the measles' as the people here phrase it. <i>(Nov 24, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/159,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

>  <b>WILY & MAUNSELL</b> Arriving at the Purapura landing-place, we found three large canoes filled with natives - men, women, and picaninnies - all covered with green leaves, the mourning costume of the Maoris. <i>(1867,Robert Maunsell,187,1938 ed.</i>)

>  <b>COTTLE</b> ... little Maori pickaninny ... <i>(1891,Frank Melton's Luck,97</i>)

>  <b>OWEN</b> ... me the ole man's pickaninny [here a half-cast] [fn] Quite common, meaning, in first instance, little child; and subsequently, offspring of any age. <i>(1909,Philip Loveluck,28</i>)

>  On being hauled out [of the lilipi gruel] the [Maori] child was handed over to the women ... very little stuff from the picannini was wasted. <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,116</i>)

>  Incidentally, the wahines and `Picanninis' invariably joined in the free-for-all Donnybrook with which [the Maori football match] ended. ho;1925 Mander Allen Adair (1971) 85 He loved to carry her about in a shawl on his back as the Maoris did their picaninnies, ... <i>(Jun 10, 1920,Quick March,41</i>)

>  <b>GRIEVE</b> `The kids at them school he the cheeky brat ...', volunteered a lady with a piccaninny fastened to her back ... <i>(1939,Sketches from Maoriland,43,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <i>piccaninny ... n</i>. small abo. child [Adopted from W. Indies]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),15</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> Johnny said yes, and did Dave know what Rangi and Eileen and the pickaninnies would do when they got to town? <i>(1949,I Saw in My Dream,229,1974 ed. Rhodes ed.</i>)

>  <b>TINNE</b> Fancy these <i>tamariki</i>, piccaninnies or brats of one or two years old, indulging ... in the herb nicotiana. <i>(1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,9</i>)

>  Another aged chief, who might easily be mistaken for him, sat beside him, tattooed almost exactly the same. The latter had the head of a piccaninny sticking out from under the mat. <i>(Feb 9, 1878,Otago Witness,9</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  Most of the picanninies have been `down with the measles' as the people here phrase it <i>(Nov 24, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/156,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]



## picarel
 
 <i>n.</i> red baitfish

>  <b>WILSON</b> BAITFISH, RED <i>Emmelichthys nitidus:</i> A less common species in New Zealand waters this fish turns up unpredictably in vast schools that give the water a red appearance - and the fish its name. Grow up to about 16 inches and known also as picarel, pearl fish and red herring. Colours light pink to dark red. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,35</i>)



## Piccadilly
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MILLER</b> At about 11.15 every morning we go through a piece of agony known as `Piccadilly'. All the New Zealanders in [? Sling] camp, three to four thousand strong, march along a certain section of the road in column of fours. On either side are about sixteen Sergeant Instructors, beautiful fellows, their superb figures almost bursting through their London tailor-made tunics. Their duty and pleasure it is to blast us up in a loud voice for any little irregularity of deportment they may notice or think they notice ...... The camp Commandant and half a dozen of the sherangs dressed in their best ... take the salute. <i>(Mar 31, 1917,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,49</i>) [NOTES: nf OED. P5.]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [(Is this the same usage as in 1; or an independently developed sense of `hyper-smart, formal marching'. ? )]

>  <b>SLATTER</b> [The Pongo sentry] was in full gear with blancoed web and anklets and rifle sling and he did the full Piccadilly up and down outside the door slapping salutes right left and centre. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,185</i>)



## Piccadilly stunt
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Of course we still get plenty of"Picadilly Stunts." <i>(Aug 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/51 : 57</i>)



## pick
 
 <i>v.</i> to guess rightly

>  When one comes to think of it, instead of saying `Rightly, sir,' Connelly would have remarked, `They picked it, my oath,' or words to that effect, and instead of saying, `I alone killed Bourke,' he would probably observe, `I was on my lonesome, boss.' [Explanatory sentence for `They picked it, my oath' `Have you been rightly or wrongly convicted?' asked the discredited 'Tec. `Rightly,sir,' said Connelly.] <i>(May 29, 1909,NZ Truth,205/5/2</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> The boss ... exclaimed, `why blow me down if here isn't His Excellency and party now!' Clarrie glanced up. `Well; by crikey old chappie; how quickly you picked us,' he responded. [1900's] <i>(1959,Tales of the Mails,14</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (informal) reckon, predict (esp. as I'm picking)

>  <b>GORDON & DEVERSON</b> <i>pick</i> (for example, <i>I'm picking</i> - I reckon <i>the All Blacks will win</i>) <i>(1985,NZ English (Gordon & Deverson),48</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a cattle snack

>  <b>STEWART</b> We drove around ... and had a good leisurely look at the stock while tossing a bit of hay about - just to `provide a pick'. <i>(1985,Gumboots and Goalposts,65</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to peck [ca1935 Havelock <i>Pick</i> and <i>peck</i> used apparently indiscriminately]

>  Roosters pick you sometimes when you try to catch, they'll turn around and pick you. <i>(1965,Speech and Idiom of Maori Children,Appendix B. xix,1963 ed.</i>) [NOTES: Speech and Idiom Maori Children Appendix B. xix [Standard III-IV Children]]



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [drafting] to select stock for sale or slaughter.

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> I remember .. watching the well-known dealer, Andrew Grant, picking 'fats.' <i>(1921,Tutira,362</i>)

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Brought sheep in, picked out the tops, then drafted up some odds and ends. <i>(Feb 26, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  <b>PATOKA REUNION COMMITTEE</b> Mr Mason Waterworth who was one of the first to pick fat lambs in this area ... <i>(1985,Podocarp to Pasture,26</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a selection or draft of stock for sale or slaughter.

>  The first pick of lambs can be taken and the remainder spread as lightly as possible. <i>(Mar 1955,NZ Journal of Agriculture,299</i>)

>  <b>PATOKA REUNION COMMITTEE</b> Of the three thousand, eight hundred lambs, six hundred and fifty went off their mothers at the first pick ... <i>(1985,Podocarp to Pasture,29</i>)

 <i>v.</i> to nag (at); to pick on [cf P: Chaff, annoy: Aust coll: -1916 (from dial. <i>pick on</i>) ca1940 (Havelock) eg Stop picking at me. I'm not going home yet. ca1951 Wellington The landlady's always picking at me - won't get off my back.]

## pick the eyes out of
 
 <i>phr.</i>

## pick up
 
 <i>v.</i> sc. fleeces (See [cf. picker-up](../P#picker-up))

>  <b>WALKER</b> My job at first was picking up fleeces <i>(Nov 10, 1862,Journal</i>)

>  I was picking up and rowling the fleeces <i>(Jan 30, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,75,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> His work was to pick up fleeces. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,46</i>)

>  I then muster for Brown and Engst shears last. I put Manuel and Lyne on to shear to. ... I press. The general hand Hobbs picks up and rolls fleeces. <i>(Dec 9, 1884,Chudleigh Diary,331,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS & REEVES</b> I'm engaged in the baling and pressing of wool, / And when picking up fleeces my hands are quite full. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,9</i>) [NOTES: [`A New Chum's Letter Home']]

>  <b>PERRY</b> A boy or man to five shearers is sufficient for picking up the fleeces, but the operations at the wool table will be described in the chapter on wool-classing. <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,83</i>)

>  When a shearer finishes a sheep, the <i>f</i>. is left lying on the <i>board</i> (q.v.). It is <i>picked up</i> by a boy (the <i>f.-p.</i>), who carries it to a table throws it out flat to be skirted, rolled and classed. The verb, to<i> f.-pick</i>, means `to be a fleece-picker'. To <i>p. up</i> is to do the actual <i>job. </i> <i>(Oct 21, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>MIDDLETON</b> There was nothing new to me in picking up fleeces. ... I had often given a hand in the smaller woolsheds at shearing time, either penning up with the shepherds or picking up and helping the presser. <i>(1964,Walk on the Beach,167</i>) [NOTES: -->1964 Middleton Walk on the Beach 167 (Not for a Seagull)]

>  <b>SARGESON</b> picking up fleeces: the rouseabout (shearer's hand) picks up the newly-shorn fleece, throws it so that it lands spread out on the table, pulls off the short and dirty wool which had been under the belly (<i>bellies</i>), rolls the fleece and puts it into the press. Nowadays the shearer usually shears the belly separately before starting on the fleece. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,302</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> ... I was allowed to miss school to help in the shed by picking up the bellywool and removing the pizzle stains from the wether bellywool. I was also `tar-boy', which meant putting dabs of Stockholm tar on any cuts inflicted by the shearers. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,55</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to collect wool from around a shearer's stand on the woolshed board.

>  <b>STRONACH</b> The fleecies whose job was to pick up the fleeces ... <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,30</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> The fleecie picks up the fleece in such a way ... <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,32</i>)

>  <b>ASPINALL</b> It was always my job to turn the grindstone for them (shearers); to shed up, pick up, pen up, press up and be there pronto with the tar pot ... <i>(1993,Farming Under Aspiring,93</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i>

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> The naked feet of the brown women `picking up' from the shining greasy floor. <i>(1926,Butcher Shop, The,11</i>)

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> `I don't need a shearer, but I need shed hands. Can you pick up?' <i>(1965,Skippers Road,89</i>)

>  <b>CHARLES</b> Jack Frost ... was `picking up'. and I was the rouseabout - penning up the sheep, sweeping the shearing board and bailing [sic] the wool. <i>(1981,Black Billy Tea,72</i>)

## pick-up
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [rodeo riding] the person who plucks a fallen rider out of danger from his mount or retrieves a rider from the back of a beast, when his time is completed.

>  The whistle indicated that a rider had ridden the specified time. If he was still aboard, the pick-up man came forward on his quick, obedient horse and plucked him expertly from his turbulent mount. A rider could find himself down across the saddle...or with back hard against the shoulder of the pick-up's horse. <i>(Jan 30, 1963,Weekly News,40</i>)



## pick-up boat
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>GRADY</b> <i>Pick-up boat </i>- The boat used for picking-up whales killed by whale-chasers. The pick-up boat would then tow the whales to the whaling station for processing. Sometimes, if the mother ship was not available for pick-up work, a spare chaser or the one with the least work on hand would take on the task of picking up. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers,228</i>)

## picker
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>CARR</b> Fleece-picking. - As soon as a shearer has taken the fleece off and let the sheep go through the port-hole to the counting-out pen, the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that she or he can on getting to the rolling table, throw it out with the breech part at the right end. <i>(1913,Country Work,14</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a person employed to pick foreign matter out of scoured wool.

>  <b>BREMNER</b> Picker - hand who picked residual foreign matter out of scoured wool before packing. <i>(1985,Woolscours of NZ,9</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) [shearing] the picker-up of fleeces from the board.

>  WANTED - 16 SHEARERS and 2 Fleece Pickers, at the Orari Gorge Station. <i>(Nov 13, 1869,Timaru Herald,1</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> .. the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that he or she can on getting to the rolling table, throw it ... <i>(1913,Country Work,14</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a fat stock buyer.

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> Pickers of stock for the frozen meat trade ,too, are suspicious of blacks. <i>(1921,Tutira,379</i>)

>  <b>MOWAT</b> Miller took horse to ferry for Borthwick's picker. <i>(Apr 1, 1932,Alexander Mowat Diaries</i>)

>  When a fat stock picker comes into a flock of lambs he may pick 30 per cent to 70 per cent of the mob. If..the picker has come in a little too late, then a high proportion of the lambs will be overfat. <i>(1966,NZ Journal of Agriculture,58</i>)

>  <b>HUTCHINSON</b> He had been employed as a picker for many years and many thousands of sheep and lambs had been felt and appraised by his experienced hands. <i>(1981,Hutchinsons of New Zealand, The,105</i>)

>  <b>FARAM</b> He used to buy in young cattle to fatten, and in 1916, one Brown, a picker, got 86 bullocks and 20 more a month later, so that Dad promptly bought another 90 weaners at the fair. <i>(1987,Jonathon Hutchinson of Parihohonu,32</i>)

>  <b>WATT</b> I knew Jack didn't want to lose a fat-lamb picker and understood ... <i>(1990,Wild Horses & Me,148</i>)



## picker-up
 
 <i>n.</i> farming: a person who clears fleeces from the shearing board. plural:pickers-up

>  First, clean all the points, the crutchand the belly wool, and let this be sweptaside and taken away at once by the"picker-up". <i>(Sep 18, 1864,Otago Witness,18</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Meanwhile the `pickers up' were busy gathering up the fleeces as they fell from the bereft sheep and carrying them to the sorting table, where they [173] were stripped of the `pieces', which were thrown aside, while the best of the fleece was quickly classified, rolled together, and deposited in a kind of bin, according to its quality, whether `clothing' or `combing.' <i>(1881,Waitaruna,172</i>)

>  Evidence was given for the [shearers'] Union by Messrs. J. Ormiston (picker-up and woolroller), Charles Pearce (woolroller), C. Armstrong (woolpresser), W. Redyard (cook), and F. Waddell (Secretary of Canterbury Union). <i>(Dec 15, 1910,Maoriland Worker,4/3/1</i>)

>  Why shouldn't the `picker up' get as much as the wool-roller? Surely running up and down the board all day is as hard work as standing at a wool table. <i>(Mar 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,7/15/</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> `Them yella dogs ain't no good anyway,' said a `picker up'. <i>Ibid.</i> 57 The pickers-up gathered the fleeces as they fell intact from the shears and bore them to the sorting table where they were quickly `skirted' and `classed'. <i>(1913,Sodger Sandy's Bairn,50</i>)

>  <b>SMITH</b> There are also baskets for the bellies and locks ... The `picker up' is the name given to the young man or boy whose duty it is to [75] carry the wool from the shearer to the skirting table ... <i>(1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,74</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> At shearing time [at Benmore, 1892] about 55 men were employed in the shed: 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,208,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MEEK</b> PICKER-UP: One who picks up the fleece, and carries it to the wool-table. <i>(1952,Station Days in Maoriland,111</i>)

>  <i>picker-up n. NZ & Austral</i>. person who gathers fleece when it is shorn from sheep. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,567</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  The picker-up, commonly called the "fleece-o," collected the shorn fleece, carried it to the rolling table, where the wool roller, after pulling off and tossing the skirts on one side, rolled it and passed it in his turn to the wool classer. <i>(Sep 23, 1924,Otago Witness,54</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a member of a shearing team who picks up fleeces from shearing board.

>  15s to GBP1 is the general wages paid to pickers up, and a boy usually has to pick up, sweep and tar, for eight shearers. <i>(May 12, 1893,Timaru Herald,3</i>)

>  In a shearing shed a number of boys are required as 'pickers'-up' [sic] of the wool as it is shorn, and appear to be as necessary to the shearer as his shears. <i>(Jan 21, 1903,Otago Witness,7</i>)

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> eight shearers, one packer, one fleece roller and one picker-up. <i>(1865,Chudleigh Diary,23</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Meanwhile the 'pickers up' were busy gathering up the fleeces as they fell from the bereft sheep ... <i>(1881,Waitaruna,172</i>)

>  <b>BISLEY</b> By retaining hold at the points originally gripped and throwing the rest of the fleece gently away from him, the picker-up should be able to spread it neatly, tip uppermost, on the wool tables, without causing any break in it. <i>(1897,Practical Treatise on Wool and Sheep Breeding,36</i>)

>  The picker-up must be shown how to lift the fleece from the board and how to deliver it upon the rolling-table. <i>(Oct 1902,NZ Farmer,567</i>)

>  The picker-up should keep his broom going sweeping to one side of the boards ... <i>(Nov 1917,NZ Farmer,1238</i>)

>  <b>MCKENNY</b> As soon as the fleece is shorn off, the 'picker up' or 'fleece O' should be ready to take it up immediately. <i>(1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,16</i>)

>  <b>MEEK</b> Joe was shearing in the woolshed on his pat. As shearer, roller, picker-up and broomie all in one. <i>(1952,Station Days in Maoriland,21</i>)

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> The picker-up was raring to go. [picker up] <i>(1965,Beyond the Skippers Road,93</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Pig-face, Pig-faces</i>, and <i>Pig's-face</i>, or <i>Pig's-faces</i>. Names given to an indigenous `ice-plant,' <i>Mesembryanthemum aequilaterale</i>, Haw., <i>N.O. Ficoideae</i>, deriving its generic name from the habit of expanding its flower about noon.[1834] <i>(1898,Austral English,352</i>)

>  <b>KIRK</b> <i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i> pig's faces <i>(1899,Students' Flora</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>Mesembryanthemum australe (The Southern Mesembryanthemum)</i> ... Called by the colonists, <i>pigs' faces</i> or <i>ice-plant. </i> <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,160,1940,p. 167 ed.</i>)

>  <i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i> pig's face <i>(1909,AJHR</i>) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> <i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i> pigs-face <i>(1909,NZ Naturalist's Calendar</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>COCKAYNE</b> The ice-plant (<i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i>, pig's-face, horokaka), which so frequently drapes the coastal cliffs ... <i>(1910,NZ Plants,63</i>)

>  <i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i> pigsface <i>(1911,AJHR,C-13</i>) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on the Dune-areas of NZ]

>  <i>Mesembryanthemum australe</i> pig's-face <i>(Jul 1920,Victorian Naturalist</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <i>A popular name for the fleshy-leaved `ice-plant' or mesembryanthemum. </i> <i>(1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),301</i>)

>  <b>MARTIN</b> Bare clay banks free from other vegetation commonly have sheets of the pink-flowered ICEPLANT or PIG'S-FACE (<i>Disphyma australe</i>) ... . <i>(1961,Flora NZ,244,1929 ed.</i>)

>  <i>pigface n.</i> indigenous creeper, with bright purple flowers pigfaces, the five-sided fruit. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),622</i>)

>  <i>pigface n</i>. indigenous creeper with bright purple flowers <i>pigfaces</i>, the five-sided fruit. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),15</i>)

>  <i>Pig&#769;.face&#769;.</i> (p&ibreve.g&#769;.f&amacr.s&#769;.), <i>n.; pl. PIGFACES. } </i>(Bot.) <i>The Pig's&#769;. face&#769;.</i> (p&ibreve.gz&#769;.-); pl. PIGS' FACES. } fruit of the Australian ice plant (<i>Mesembryanthemum sequilaterale</i>) : - called also <i>canajong</i>. In form it resembles a pig's head and face. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2028</i>)

>  Further away from the sea .. the weather-beaten sea-cottages, with .. their mounds of the dark green mesembryanthemum - "pig's-face" - give place to more pretentious villas and two-storeyed houses. <i>(Jun 7, 1894,Otago Witness,41</i>)

>  Our house was never in much danger, as it was erected on a small flat close to a creek, the ground being covered with weeds called "pigface" and hayweed, which were always green, proving an effectual protection to our homestead. <i>(Jun 24, 1903,Otago Witness,9</i>)

>  On large stretches of country there is no grass at all, but innumerable weeds, such as .. pig-face .... <i>(Aug 15, 1874,Otago Witness,17</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a fence usually made of wire netting 1.07 m high

 <i>n.</i>

## pig-jump
 
 <i>n.</i>

 <i>v.</i>

## Pigroot
 
 <i>n.</i> (the Pigroot) the inland road (State Highway 85) from Palmerston, north of Dunedin, into Central Otago, originally a trail followed by 19th-century goldminers. [probably from the presence of wild pigs in the area] [1889 cit. l.c. a kind of hill, cf. hogback]

>  Some gravelling between the Pigroot and Red cutting was required, and from present end of metal at Daddy's Pinch towards Pigroot. <i>(Nov 30, 1888,Otago Witness,23</i>)

>  Palmerston folk, I notice, intend to endeavour to prevent us from getting out rights; but it won't do, dear friends; Mrs. Partington could not keep back the Atlantic, neither can you keep Craig and Co. on the Pigroot line. <i>(Feb 25, 1892,Otago Witness,20</i>)

>  <b>Owen Marshall</b> Dansey's Pass often had heavy snow at that time of the year, so Theo took the route through Oamaru and then up the Pigroot from Palmerston. <i>(2007,Drybread,265</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS & REEVES</b> Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... <i>Negro-heads</i> shall be re-christened. I for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,3</i>)

>  No map the collector has consulted has shown Pigroot Hill or hotel, and yet it is the most prominent and most used name between Palmerston and Kyeburn. Again and again the collector has heard the remark, `I am going into the Central by the Pigroot,' or `I came down by the Pigroot.' So frequently is it used that one might imagine that certain people used it thinking that the word `root' is in reality `route,' but be that as it may, common usage is the deciding factor in place-names, and Pigroot, with its associations back into the fifties, has come to stay. The name was originally [9] bestowed because the wild pigs rooted up the hillside looking for the roots of the taramea, or speargrass, which they enjoy eating, and which is probably one of the main reasons why speargrass is so rare nowadays. <i>(1944,Maori Place-Names of Otago,8</i>)

>  (Reprinted from the <i>Molyneux Mail</i>) Mr. Kilgour.. has called for tenders to remove and re-erect his premises from the Pigroot to this place. <i>(Oct 15, 1864,Otago Witness,8</i>)

>  On the Waihemo road the Shag River has similarly prevented the coach from reaching the Pigroot. <i>(Sep 27, 1873,Otago Witness,11</i>)

## pigweed

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> PORTULACA (<i>Portulaca oleracea</i>), called also pig weed, hog weed, purslane, and ice plant, is very common on garden paths etc., in Auckland, becoming less and less common as far south as Nelson. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,72,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <i>pigweed [=] redroot: rhagodia: twin cress: wart cress: wild portulaca: willow weed: wireweed</i> [s] <i>(1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,58</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> wire weed

>  Polygonum aviculare Pigweed <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/126</i>) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> WIREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, `pig weed,' and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed'). <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,1967,66 ed.</i>)



 
<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> red root

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> RED ROOT (<i>Amaranthus [hybridus</i> and <i>A. retroflexus</i>), also called red shank and pig weed, is found in gardens and waste places all over the North Island and as far south as Nelson [Canterbury]. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,70,1967 ed.</i>)

## pikau
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to carry on one's back. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  The whole of the stolen articles.. were placed upon the prisoner's back, and he was compelled to pikau them to the Hill Farm, whence he had taken them. <i>(Jul 1, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,5</i>)

>  The winding nature of the river makes the distance up to where the reef was found very long and wearisome, all the stores, &c., necessary on such an expedition having to be carried "pikau," as there is no means of getting horses in. <i>(Apr 5, 1890,Taranaki Herald,2</i>)

>  <b>MARKHAM</b> I crossed a Stream a dozen times, mostly on a Mans back called a Pekow (pikau). <i>Ibid.</i> 72 He picked out two of the strongest of the Boys about the place to carry "Pekow" us over the River. <i>(1834,New Zealand (Heaphy),42</i>) [NOTES: 1963 edition]

>  "You pikau te canoe, quick." <i>(Apr 15, 1931,Aussie (NZ Section),XI</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> ... nay, he may with due deference to public opinion, carry (<i>pekau</i>) pickback, the said foreigner, be his dimensions long or short, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 1/171-172 The flax in a basket generally weighs about from [172] eighty to a hundred pounds, and is either carried (<i>pikou</i>), on men's shoulders or in canoes, to the house of the purchaser. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/59</i>)

>  They do not need to pikau, or carry, their produce to the town. <i>(Oct 8, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7</i>)

>  It will scarcely be argued that exhibitors will <i>pikau</i> the result of their labours 10 or 15 miles to a show when they have neglected one at their own doors. <i>(Apr 2, 1892,Auckland Weekly News,30</i>)

>  <b>J WILLIAMS</b> Henry plastered it [the gash] under my directions and we sent for a couple of his mates to pikau him home. <i>(Oct 10, 1840,Journal,133</i>) [NOTES: in Porter (1974) Turanga Journals]

>  <b>HAY</b> Both men and women are able to pikau ( hump, or carry on the back and shoulders ) great weights. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,II 94</i>)

>  News arrived that 200 men are expected to be down from the Waikato, to "pikau" these guns across the country. <i>(Oct 3, 1863,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  Many of them continue for years to pikau their provisions over roads that can never be made passable for drays. <i>(Jun 14, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,5</i>)

>  <b>MARKHAM</b> ... Jake exerted himself and got five Boys to Pekow the Traps across at 2lb [tobacco] each to Kiddy Kiddy. <i>(1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),61,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MANING</b> `I tell you what we must do ... we will not carry (<i>pikau</i> ) the provisions, we will <i>hiki</i> them' (<i>Hiki</i> is the word in Maori which describes the act of carrying an infant in the arms.) <i>(1863,Old New Zealand,(viii) 129</i>)

>  <b>A TRAMP</b> `Tommy' and Rairaina <i>pikaued </i>the swag. <i>(1891,Casual Ramblings,79</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> Three grand days in the saddle, the last winding down the bush road that skirted the ... Ohura ... then `pikau' and foot-slog for the great roadless forest. <i>(1916,Bush Explorers,6</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> [ca1950 (North Island Trampers') NCC Small]

 <i>n.</i> [2 x attrib. pikau burden, pikau straps]

 <i>n.</i> [in relation to piggy back but not quite! ca1950 (North Island Trampers') Pickaback NCCS.]

>  <b>MARKHAM</b> I crossed a Stream a dozen times, mostly on a Mans back called a (Pekow [<i>pikau</i>] is to carry Upanga [<i>hapainga</i>], lift me up.) [1963 fn] Though the meaning of this sentence is fairly clear, punctuation and syntax are even more defective than usual: <i>pikau</i> means to carry on the back; <i>hapainga</i> is the passive form of <i>hapai,</i> lift up, raise. <i>(1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42,1963 ed.</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [Ma.] a back pack. [also refers to a packed lunch often carried in a pikau]

>  <b>BAKER</b> Once somebody asked him where he was going, pikau on his back, rifle slung over his shoulder and axe in hand. <i>(2000,Kokopu Dreams,45</i>)

>  <b>MALCOLM</b> Deceased had a pekau on his back. <i>(1982,Where it all Began,6</i>)

>  When Harry first came to these hills hecarried his supplies in a sugar sackpikau over his shoulder. <i>(Jan 9, 1994,Sunday Times (NZ),19</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> I left some of my pikaus with Mr. Duncan. <i>(1849,Journals and Correspondence,6/9 ed.</i>)

>  The Maoris .... made up all our packages ... into three pikaws or bundles of about 35lb. each which they tied up and slung over their shoulders with strips of native flax leaf. <i>(Feb 23, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/82,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (H.R.Richmond)]

>  <b>ABRAHAM</b> My <i>pikau</i> (or burden) weighed 30lbs. <i>(1856,Walk with the Bishop</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAM MORGAN</b> One [Maori prisoner] ... had on an oilskin, a hat, and carried a small `pikau', his wardrobe I suppose. <i>(Nov 1863,Journal,123,1963 ed.</i>)

>  On his return fron Rangatiki, the blue blanket pikau was gone. <i>(1869,McLean Papers,30/147</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> These Ngati-Mutunga ... mde up small casks of powder in flax-basket <i>pikaus</i> or back-loads, and transported them through all the forests and ranges of Pukerua and along the northern shore of the bay. <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/122</i>)

>  <b>LYON</b> .. this huge midden [of shellfish] .. had been brought by pikau on the backs of old Maori women ... <i>(1952,Faring South,80</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> [He] sat down with his pikau, in which he had a freshly-slain leg of pork, strategically placed in his lap. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,70</i>)

>  <b>HOGAN</b> Days of Billy-can and Pikau,/ Horse and Buggy, sleet and snow,/ Railway camp and crowded `Boozer',/ <i>(1962,Billy-Can Ballads,1</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> pikau: sugar-bag used for carrying food or other things, shouldered by means of ropes attached to the corners. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,302</i>)

>  <b>MOORE</b> As we leave the hut for the day's work we each have on our backs a `pikau' - a sugar-bag rucksack containing tucker for our lunch and `smoke-o's'. <i>(1969,From Forest to Farm,88</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> The pikau (load for the back) was a half-sack, with a strap attached to each of the bottom corners and joined at the middle of the top - in the manner of a knapsack. <i>(1972,Gumdiggers, The,50</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> I had on my shoulders my few items of clothing ... all packed into a sugar bag transformed by a loop of light rope into that handy pack for trampers which the Maoris called <i>pikau</i> . <i>(1977,More Than Enough,25</i>)

>  Stories are still told of the prodigious loads they would carry over the hills in their pikaus. <i>Ibid.</i> 33 Still another sack made the standard haversack type of container with shoulder straps for carrying loads on the back. ## piker
 
 <i>n.</i> a wild bull

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> The roaring tangle of pikers, steers and fierce old scrub bulls. <i>(1905,Sons o' Men,24</i>)

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> [The wild cattle] were a mixed haul: two-year-olds, poddies and pikers. <i>(1907,Tracks  We Tread,52</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a shirker, dodger

>  Don't be a Piker! A Piker is a man without appreciation, without gratitude, and without the ability to change old habits for better ones, No! let us live with the times, and be fitted out by the leading Tailor and Mercer, Main street, Otautau. <i>(Oct 8, 1912,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,5</i>)

>  Then they start operations and when it comes to betting they are by no means pikers. <i>(Mar 1, 1928,NZ Truth,11</i>)

>  I would include among New Zealand English words: <i>piker </i> <i>(May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> `I gotta get away.'`Ya bloody piker! A man oughta wooden ya out. I spose you're tearin off to see some sheila if the truth's known.' <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,43</i>)

>  <b>MACKAY</b> Bill had never heard of Baron Munchausen but, as the most cheerful liar of this or any age, he made that titled gentleman look a mere piker. <i>(1961,Puborama,72</i>)

>  <i>piker ... n</i>. ... one who loses courage at the last moment. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),15</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> `I'm browned off, boy,' he replied ... `Go on, you piker,' Joe said with a laugh. <i>(1976,Pacific Star,94</i>)

>  <i>piker</i>: person who lets you down <i>(Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <i>piker</i>: one who does not pay his way or slyly tries to get out of paying; e.g., `Come on mate, your shout or are you a piker.' <i>(1981,NZ Police National Headquarters</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <b>SHERWOOD</b> The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. `Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. A `Queen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. `Skite' and `drongo' were terms of abuse. A `cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to a `runholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ... <i>(1985,Botanist at Bay,26</i>)

>  <i>piker n. NZ & Austral. sl</i>. one who avoids doing his fair share, a shirker. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,569</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 858]]

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> So to cope with the rituals of tramping ... a slang language has developed to suit. ... `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936 ...[Not so: HWO]), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather) ... <i>(Mar 1988,Hills, The</i>) [NOTES: [page proofs: Reed Publishing]]

>  <b>KEINZLY</b> `Aw, come on. Have a beer.' 'No thanks.' `Piker! Ya old man will.' <i>(1960,Tangahano,114</i>)

>  <b>PICKERING</b> So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more. <i>(1988,Hills, The,8</i>)

## pikopo
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> [He] said he was there alone amongst the heathen and pickapo tribe ... <i>(Jul 1, 1846,Journal,4/68</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> an old word for Roman Catholic (bishop).

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> Conversation with some who had attended `Pikopo' (The Roman Catholic Bishop). [Bishop Pompallier arrived on 10 Jan 1838] <i>(Oct 6, 1839,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,446,1961 ed.</i>)

>  `Pikopo' is the name given to the Roman Bishop. <i>(1839,Journeys</i>) [NOTES: 1839 Colenso. M.S. Memo. Journeys amongst Natives 50]

>  <b>BRIGHT</b> M.Pompaliere; the natives call him <i>Pikypo</i>, for what reason I know not. <i>(1841,Handbook for Emigrants,126</i>)

>  <b>COLENSO</b> `If Pikopo and his priest go in, we [Colenso et al.], for the sake of our position among the Natives, should go in also.' [fn] The common Maori name by which the Roman Catholic bishop and the priests were known. <i>(1890,Treaty of Waitangi,13</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a (Roman) Catholic

>  A few of the people here are missionary natives, some are pikopo, or catholics, but the majority are heathen. <i>(Jul 11, 1846,New Zealander, The,3</i>)

>  [Tapu] has been laid on by an old Pikopo Chief, who lives up in the interior, about 100 miles from this place. <i>(Apr 11, 1846,New Zealander, The,3</i>)

>  (Reprinted from the <i> Auckland Herald </i> ) "I am a Pikopo," (the Maori word for Catholic) Scott replied. <i>(Mar 24, 1886,Taranaki Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>HEBERLEY</b> [The Missionaries] told [the natives] we were all Pickopoes. <i>(1839,Autobiography,37,1874 ed.</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> ... encamping close by the sea by a beautiful amphitheatre of powa takawa trees ... Mr Williams addressed a party of Pickapos the best part of the afternoon <i>(Oct 17, 1842,Journal,4</i>)

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> Protestant natives regard their Roman Catholic brethren as belonging to the devils: they are called pikipo, which M. Pompalier explained as being derived from <i>episcopus</i>, which seems to me the most probable derivation. The Protestant missionaries however, say that it means piki-po - always bowing [370] - (piki, bend - po, night). The Protestants, therefore, call their bishop pihopa, while the Roman Catholics have retained the title pikipo for theirs. <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,1/369</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> We were Pikapo (the Maori corruption of episcopoi, or Roman Catholics) <i>(1845,Adventure in NZ,1/168</i>)

>  The natives at Taupo are nearly all <i>pikipoi (episcopoi)</i> as they call themselves. <i>(1844,NZ Journal,127/621</i>) [NOTES: (R.Harrison)]

>  <b>ANGAS</b> Mungahaku [of Tongariro], the chief of this pah, is a <i>pikopo</i>, or Roman Catholic; several of his people have also embraced Popery, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 2/152-153 Those natives who are still heathen are generally styled `devils' by the Christianized people; and they themselves adhere to the [153] appellation. Hongi Hongi, ... in answer to my inquiry as to whether he was a `mihorari' or a `pikopo'(Catholic), confessed with evident delight that he was a `devil'. <i>(1847,Savage Life,2/121</i>)

>  <b>ANGAS</b> Mungahaku [of Tongariro], the chief of this pah, is a <i>pikopo</i>, or Roman Catholic; several of his people have also embraced Popery, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 2/152-153 Those natives who are still heathen are generally styled `devils' by the Christianized people; and they themselves adhere to the [153] appellation. Hongi Hongi, ... in answer to my inquiry as to whether he was a `mihorari' or a `pikopo'(Catholic), confessed with evident delight that he was a `devil'. <i>(1847,Savage Life,2/121</i>)

>  <b>BULLER</b> They took the name of Pikopo. This no doubt was maorified from the Latin word <i>episcopos</i>; but, unfortunately for them, it had the ominous meaning in the Maori tongue, - <i>creeping in the dark.</i> <i>(1878,Forty Years in NZ,295</i>)

>  <b>PINFOLD</b> Even their name [sc Roman Catholics] may have hindered their progress. They were called Pikopo; the Maori attempt to reproduce the word <i>episcopos</i>. Unhappily for them, the word also means `creeping in the dark' : an idea which would not be helpful. <i>(1930,Fifty Years In Maoriland,99</i>)

>  <b>BUICK</b> In his discussions with the Maoris, Bishop Pompallier had stresed the point that he held the advantage over the Protestant missionaries in that he was a member of the Episcopacy. The best attempt on the part of the natives to render into their own language the word Episcopos, in its varied forms, was <i>pikopo</i>, hence the Bishop and his converts became known as <i>Pikopo</i>. <i>(1936,Treaty of Waitangi,118fn</i>)



## pilchard
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Sardinops neopilchardus </i>mohimohi, Picton herring

>  <b>PAUL et al.</b> [index to common names 283-293] pilchard 515-40 <i>(1987,Fishes: A Bibliography</i>)

>  There are plenty of mackerel here, but no nets to catch them, and there are pilchards; please to bring one good pilchard net. <i>(Feb 10, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,1968 ed.</i>)

>  There are large shoals of the pilchard at the head of the Sound. They are from 6 to 10 inches long. <i>(1884,TrNZI,17/486</i>) [NOTES: (Sutherland)]

>  ...<i> large numbers of aua or kataha</i> (Agonostoma forsteri); <i>about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi (Clupea sagax),</i> two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (<i>Lotella bacchus</i>), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (<i>Percis colias</i>). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long. <i>(1903,TrNZI,35/319</i>) [NOTES: Mair Fish in Piako River]

>  There appear to be three species of fish belonging to the family Clupeidae in New Zealand waters, viz., <i>Engraulis antipodum</i>, or anchovy; <i>Sardinia neopilchardus</i>, or pilchard, and <i>Harengula antipoda</i>, or sprat. <i>Ibid.</i> 316 The sprat is the smaller of the two, but in the numerous notices of these fish, the name `sprat' probably includes in many cases immature pilchards. <i>Ibid.</i> 319 In the case of fish-stomachs examined at the station, sprats have been found in red cod, blue cod, southern king-fish, barracouta, and spined dog-fish; and pilchards in barracouta. <i>(1926,TrNZI,56/314</i>) [NOTES: (Young and Thomson)]

>  <b>SORENSON</b> <i>ANCHOVY </i>(a) Scientific name: <i>Engraulis australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Anchovy. (c) Other common names: the following names of related Clupeids and Engraulid fish are sometimes applied to anchovy - Herring, Sprat, Sardine, Pilchard, although the true Herring of European waters (<i>Clupea harengus</i>), does not occur in New Zealand. ## piler
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MAY</b> It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access. <i>(1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,244,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HEINZ</b> <i>Pilers</i>: See CLAIMS below.(?) ... <i>CLAIMS </i>Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. ## pillar
 
 <i>n.</i> [mining]

>  <b>HAWES</b> To get the coal out, you divvied the seam up into 'pillars' a square chain wide. Then you drove alleyways called 'bords' to the very back of the pillar and you worked back towards the main shaft, taking 'lifts' off the pillars as you went... As you worked at the pillar - picking, shotfiring, shovelling an' that - it got thinner an' thinner until in the end it looked like a big black tornado, or a tree holding up the sky. That's why the last strand of the pillar is called a 'mahuta'. <i>(2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,85</i>)

>  When the seam is worked out in this way the question of taking out the remaining blocks of coal, or pillars arises. <i>(1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,4/612</i>)

## pin dip
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Pin dips were also another popular amusement. `A pin or a bull or a button, To see a rary rary show show show!' (1875; Tahataki). A piece of glass backed by cardboard was covered with a piece of paper that could be flicked up to show the `rary rary show' or had a slit in it through which one could peep. One saw through the glass a variety of colors, pieces of colored paper, flower petals, pictures, and later pieces off cigarette boxes. Sometimes these had been arranged in some pattern, at other times they were kaleidoscopic only, and the perceiver had himself to add the configurations of intelligibility. The price for the view was always a pin `which we did not want anyhow but always accepted,' a relic from an age when such things were rare. Pin dips were known also as `poppy shows' (perhaps it was the similar flash of color that gave the same name - `the poppy show' - to the exciting experience of seeing a girl's dress blown upward by the wind; pins were not charged for flowers of this sort). In fact, the pin dip or the prick book may have developed from the poppy show. The poppy show was common before 1900 and the prick book after that date, a fact connected with the ever-increasing stock of picture cards and magazine pictures available to children. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,223</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> <i>Pinch an Inch</i>. Gallipoli Peninsula: New Zealand soldiers': 1915; ob. Cf. <i>Pen and Ink </i>and <i>Inch and Pinch</i>. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,631</i>)



## pinch bar
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Then we would get on with pushing the waggons of wheat along the siding to the grain store doors. Using the pinch bar to get them started and putting our backs to it and shoving with our heels on the sleepers. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,20</i>)



## pinch out
 
 <i>v.</i> of a lead, to thin out and disappear

>  <b>LYON</b> This mine ... had a habit of pinching out, which meant the payable block of stone or running reef vanished without warning ... . <i>(1952,Faring South,172</i>)

>  <i>Pinch</i> (p&ibreve.nch), <i>v. i. [Add.] To pinch out (Mining),</i> to taper rapidly to a point and thus fail utterly; - said of a vein of auriferous quartz. <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2028</i>)

>  <i>pinch out</i> v.t.-pinch out' v.i. of a seam, to thin out and disappear. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,9</i>)

>  <b>LYON</b> The stone was in about 400-ton blocks and then pinched out with no lead to show where to pick it up again. <i>(1952,Faring South,169</i>)



## pinch time
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a season or part of a season when pasture feed is short. (See [feed pinch](../F#feed-pinch))

>  It's the pinch time for most farmers now so it means I can run eight extra sheep on every acre that's not idle. <i>(Oct 10, 1974,NZ Farmer,59</i>)

>  The feed pinch time under early lambs comes at any stage from August to mid-September. <i>(Aug 8, 1996,NZ Farmer,05</i>)



## pincher
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a disoriented unlambed ewe that attempts to steal the lamb of another ewe.

>  <b>GORDON</b> A few ewes in this build up period, can get a bit confused and decide they've had their lamb; they'll choose a youngster that's nearby and try and walk off with it. Many's the happy group that's been split by an old 'pincher.' <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,60</i>)

>  Ewe that tries to adopt the lamb of another: pincher. <i>(2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB)</i>)



## pinchers
 
 <i>n.</i> have the pinchers into one: variant of put the nips into q.v.

>  They've got the pinchers into me. Don't you think I ought to buck. When the Union won't take action. <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,11</i>)

## pine
 
 <i>n.</i> indigenous pine unspecified [kauri pine, screwpine, etc. In general Maori-derived names have been replacing the -pine names, at a slower rate for the South Island, and probably slower for the names of the timbers as distinct from the trees.] (See [kauri pine](../K#kauri-pine),[screwpine](../S#screwpine),[etc](../E#etc))

>  <b>SHEPHERD</b> [?a podocarp] Some of the timber trees are of large growth, particularly three sorts; the first is of the pine tribe and is known by the name of Pimise (Pinus??) in three varieties on the north. The second is something like the Lucombe Oack, and the third is called the Red Gum or Eucalipticus I have seen it in England. ... The three varieties of pine are very tall and handsome, and one in appearance like the Lucombe oak grows tall but not so straight, the Eucalipticy grows to a great thickeness in the stem and frequently not less than fifteen feet in girt but not more than 15 or 20 feet in height before it spreads its large branches in every direction, ... <i>(1826,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1826 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 356]

>  <b>NICHOLAS</b> [?white pine] Another species of the pine, but much inferior to the one I have described, and the same that Captain Cook mentions as bearing a berry with a leaf like that of the yew, presented itself in great abundance upon the banks which bordered the sides of the cove, but its size was inconsiderable, and its wood knotty, and only fit for carpenter's work, such as window-frames, mouldings, &c. ... <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/233</i>)

>  <b>BOOTH</b> ... the roof [of the station buildings, Canterbury c1859] were of round pine framing covered with rickers (young pine plants) and thatched with snow grass. <i>(1912,Five Years in NZ,24</i>)

>  <b>BRUNNER</b> We had a little better walking ..., passing over about a mile of very good pine forest, but again came to our black birch country <i>(Feb 26, 1847,Journal of an Expedition</i>) [NOTES: 1847 Feb 26 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 268]

>  <b>BARKER</b> Blazing logs of pine and black birch made every room The oysters and pine apple he stowed away in the box ...] <i>(1866,Station Life in NZ,78,1870 ed.</i>)

>  The flat land and low spurs are covered with the common species of Pines and Birch, such as Rimu, ...Weinmannia (Karmahi), and Fagus (Tawai) ... <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/111/4</i>) [NOTES: (Hector)]

>  English Name Native name Botanical Name Red Pine Rimu .. White Pine Kahikatea .. Silver Pine Monoao Dacrydium Intermedium Black Pine Maitai[sic] .. <i>(1889,Catalogue, Canterbury Court Exhibition,35</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>The Pines are widely distributed in Australasia ... The name, with various epithets, is given to a few other trees besides those of</i> the Natural order <i>Coniferae. ... </i> <i>(1898,Austral English,354</i>)

>  <i>~ Black p</i>. Podocarpus spicatus. Called <i>matai</i> in the North Island and, I am told, <i>red pine</i> in Nelson, Our <i>r.p. (Dacrydium cupressinum)</i> is <i>rimu</i> in the north and our white (<i>Podocarpus dacrydioides)</i> is <i>kahikatea</i>. (C).) eg 1841 Stephens Letters 22 Red and white pine. <i>(Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>TURNER</b> <i>The word</i> pine, <i>with various colour adjectives, is used for so many native trees in the South Island of New Zealand that a builder who wants to refer to timber which is really pine (Pinus radiata)<i> has to call it</i> pinus. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,60</i>)

>  <b>ELDER</b> Loads of excellent pine are to be found. <i>(Jun 17, 1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,63,1934 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1814 June 17 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 63]

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> Our way lay through a wood composed of various kinds of timber together with the noble pine. <i>(1815,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,99,1932 ed.</i>)

>  <b>NICHOLAS</b> The timber in this grove [up the Kawa Kawa] was not large, nor could I observe any trees of the pine species, though there were several that appeared of an excellent quality, ... we entered a noble forest of pines, growing to the height of eighty and a hundred feet, before they branched out, and all of them as straight as if they had been [225] shaped by nature, for no other purpose then to shew [sic] her regularity. <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/224</i>)

>  <b>MANDER</b> He was delighted with the houses in the pines and the suggestion of old and rambling gardens about them ... It was small enough to please him, just a little place, a kind of depot for the settlers and the camps of the diggers out back. <i>(1925,Allen Adair,41,1971 ed.</i>)

>  [The mountains in Caswell Harbour] are for the most part covered with trees, such as iron-wood, pine &c, ... <i>(1826,Boultbee Journal,161,1979 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1826 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 161]

>  The trees are easily cleared away, being either pine or other soft wood; except the iron wood, which grows to a large size, the wood of this tree is a dark red colour, ... <i>(1835,Boultbee Journal,103,1986 ed.</i>)

>  There are several varieties of the pine [at Akaroa]; all the trees, however, appear to be evergreens. <i>(1841,GBPP,(No.311) 106</i>) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841]

>  Fine forest, totaras, pines &c. <i>(Mar 26, 1849,Torlesse Papers,70,1958 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> The greater portion finely timbered with totara, pine, hinau, &c., ... <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,240</i>)

>  <b>HOCKEN</b> Two or three hundred yards beyond begins an irregular fringe of native bush, broadleaf, veronica, fuchsia, pittosporum, and tangled supplejack; beyond these rise the lofty pines and other forest giants. <i>(1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,79</i>)

>  <i>Pine</i> (p&imacr.n), <i>n. (Bot.) [Add.]</i> ... In New Zealand the word<i> pine</i> is applied to many trees, some of which also bear other names. Thus, -<i> black pine</i> (see MATAI and MIRO), <i>celery-topped pine (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), kauri pine,</i> called also <i>cowdie pine (Dacrydium pine, or Westland pine (Dacrydium Westlandicum), white pine</i> see KAHIKATEA <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2029</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> a pineapple [[check Constable edition text here; and check Aloe text]]

## pineapple
 
 <i>n.</i> a mortar bomb

>  PINEAPPLE. - A German trench mortar bomb of small size. <i>Ibid.</i> 16 ... even if it's rainin' pineapples an' dud three-ought-threes. <i>(1917,New Zealand At the Front,xi</i>)

>  <b>STEWART</b> At 5.45 a.m. ... a perfect tornado of shells `rumjars' and `pineapples' burst afresh on the same section of the line. <i>(1921,NZ Division,152</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> `There's a pineapple gun that's dropping pineapples around here,' someone said as I went out to take my turn on watch. ... [69] A pineapple exploded nearby and the candle went out and my mates cursed. <i>(1976,Soldier,68</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> Then the Hun let fly with whizzbangs, pineapples and the most dreaded of all - with minenwerfers. <i>(1978,Twilight Hour,58</i>)

>  <b>SMALL</b> Also <i>pineapple</i> used in WW1 by NZ soldiers as slang for grenade. My grandfather's diaries have: `Fritz sent us a pineapple today' = `The Germans bombed/grenaded us today.' <i>(Dec 5, 1986,Personal Communication</i>)

>  PINEAPPLE. - A German trench mortar bomb of small size. <i>Ibid.</i> 16 ... even if it's rainin' pineapples an' dud three-ought-threes. <i>((6/0/1917),New Zealand At the Front,xi</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> The Kiekie, a creeping thing, called by some the `New Zealand Pine-apple', fruits every third year. <i>(1849,Settlement of New Plymouth,18</i>)

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> The Kie-kie (New Zealand's pine-apple) ... is a vegetable impostor, like a sweet artichoke flavoured with turpentine. <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/136</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> The <i>tawheras</i> that had been missed had dried and shrivelled, and the white of the <i>tiore</i> had decayed, but the fingers of the `gentlemen' had swollen considerably and now provided us with New Zealand `pineapples.' The really good ones were eight inches long and two-and-a-half inches in diameter. They were wrenched out in the same way as giggies. These `pineapples' were never very much sought after by the general public. They needed what might be called an acquired taste. They were tricky eating too. You bit off all the outside hard, nobbly but not prickly covering, and then gnawed the soft, sweet flesh to the bone. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,117</i>) [NOTES: 1880 Taranaki in Sutton-Smith History of Children's Play (1981) 117]

>  He also left a small sample of fibre, prepared from the leaf of the tawera plant - New Zealand pine-apple, - but the tawera fibre does not appear to be of any commercial value. <i>(Jun 7, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

 <i>n.</i> biddy-bid [bidibidi See also biddy-bid, hutuwai, utuwai] (See [bidibidi](../B#bidibidi))

>  A problem which faces our sheep farmersis that of the native "piripiri" or"utuwai" in late shorn wool. <i>(Nov 27, 1917,Levin Daily Chronicle,2</i>)

>  A problem which faces our sheep farmers is that of the native "piripiri" or "utuwai" in late shorn sheep. <i>(Nov 29, 1917,Press, The,3</i>)

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> The common <i>Acaena</i> was called by the Maoris Piri-piri, but colonists frequently [usually] corrupt the Maori name, and call the plant Bidi-bidi. As a general rule, the Maori names are more incorrectly pronounced as we go southward from Auckland to Otago. This is largely due to the fact that, in the north, Europeans have been brought into closer contact with the Maoris than in the south. In some few cases, the difference in pronunciation may be due to differences in the Maori dialects. The changes that take place often follow phonetic laws - thus the Maori `p' is softened into the European `b' as above, while `r' is replaced by `l' or `d'. Poro-poro (<i>Solanum aviculare</i>) becomes Bulli-bulli, and Puriri becomes Boradi. This also explains such a form as `Kowdie' pine for Kauri pine. Korari - a flax-stalk - similarly becomes Koradi or even Kaladi [1907 edn ?mistakenly, <i>Kalladi</i>]. `K' is also sometimes altered into `g,' this Kie-kie (<i>Freycinetia Banksii</i>) becomes ghi-ghi. The last vowel in a reduplicated syllable was faintly pronounced in Maori, and often disappears altogether in the European form of the word, <i>e.g.</i>, Poro-poro gives Bulli-bull, and Piri-piri gives Bidi-bid. <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,202,1940 p 211 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> PIRI PIRI (<i>Acaena ... sanguisorbae</i>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. It is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,99,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <b>LEVY</b> Attuned to the geographical region were some particularly troublesome growths, and of these, the hard fern (or ring fern) became a special pest difficult to control and to guard against. ... ## piss-wee
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [peewee](../P#peewee))

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

## pit-sawing
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>EASTWOOD</b> The only means of getting sawn timber was to cut it yourself, by what was called pit sawing. Dad used to make a pit about 20 ft long, and 6 ft deep, place logs around it, roll the logs he wanted sawn into position in the middle... Dad's mate used to go into the pit and dad, who was the taller, stood on top of the log. Dad had to drive the saw downwards, and his mate pulled it, and up and down they sawed, squared the log, cut boards and four by two and so on until they had sufficient timber for rafters, uprights and floor joists. <i>(1982,Brief History of Gold Mining, A,107</i>)

## plant-caterpillar
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MORRIS</b> name given in Australasia to species of caterpillars which are attacked by spores of certain fungi; when chrysalating in the earth the fungus frows inside the body of the caterpillar, kills the latter, and then forces its way out between the head joints, and sends an upgrowth which projects beyond the surface of the ground and gives rise to fresh spores. Many examples are known, of which the more common are <i>Cordyceps robertsii</i>, Hook., in New Zealand; <i>Cordyceps gunni<i>i, berk, in Tasmania; <i>Cordyceps taylori</i> Berk, in Australia.<i> See</i> Aweto. <i>(1898,Austral English,360</i>)

>  <b>COOKE</b> `The New Zealanders' name for this plant-caterpillar is `Hotete,' `Weri,' and `Anuhe'... The interior of the insect becomes completely filled by the inner plant, or thallus (mycelium): after which the growing head of the outer plant or fungus, passing to a state of maturity, usually forces its way out through the tissue of the joint between the head and the first segment of the thorax ... it is stated that this caterpillar settles head upward to undergo its change, when the vegetable developes [sic] itself.' <i>(1892,Vegetable Wasps and Plant Worms,139</i>)

>  <b>HILGENDORF</b> PLANTAIN (<i>Plantago lanceolata</i>) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass'. From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie"-that is `Charles and George"- a souvenir of 1745. <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,161,1967 ed.</i>)

## Plimmer's Ark
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  [Hdg] Plimmer's Ark back from the dead. A new chapter in the eventful saga of the <i>Inconstant</i> - the ship that became a building - has started following the recent opening of the new Plimmer's Ark Gallery on Queens Wharf... For many years life in Wellington basically revolved around the hulk of the <i>Inconstant</i>... Built in 1847 and launched on 3 Jan 1848 at Cape Breton in Nova Scotia, the <i>Inconstant</i> sailed to England and there had her hull clad with copper...On entering Wellington Harbour [in 1849] the ship ran on to the rocky beach between Pencarrow and the point now named Inconstant Point. The <i>Inconstant</i> was towed across the harbour to Te Aro. John Plimmer bought the by then derelict ship and had it moved in 1850 to Lambton Beach where he built a pitched roof over the mid section. It became known as Noah's [<i>sic</i>] Ark because of its appearance. <i>(Jun 2001,Absolutely Positively Wellington,10</i>)

>  Plimmer's Ark is one of the most significant pieces of maritime history entrusted to the Maritime Archaeological Association. In 1977, construction workers digging in the old Bank of New Zealand building on Wellington's Lambton Quay discovered a slab of wood. Archaeologists identified it as part of the <i>Inconstant</i>, a ship that was towed into Wellington and was eventually bought by John Plimmer who dragged it ashore and modified it for use as business premises. The ship became known as Plimmer's Ark. <i>(Sep 2003,NZ Heritage,No. 90/6</i>)

## plough
 
 <i>n.</i> [[entries at swing, lever, stilt]]

>  When the first settlers came to New Zealand, they didn't bring many ploughs with them from their home countries. ... [Blacksmiths] set up their smithies and began making implements more suitable for the terrain. One of the first of [the New Zealand made ploughs] was a long sleek job known as a swing plough. Just why is hard to say ... The furrows were the result of the accuracy of the ploughman's eye, as it had no wheels whatever. The depth was graduated by the bridle adjustment but was corrected in uneven ground by leverage from the long handles, or stilts as they were called. If the the share struck anything these [swing ploughs] had a kick like a run cow. It is said that a good man could land on his feet six yards in front of the horses ... The next development was the lever plough which ran on three wheels and had no handles except a stubby one at the back. <i>(Oct 30, 1963,Weekly News,[farming page]</i>)

## plurry
 
 <i>adv.</i> `stage-Maori' representation of <i>bloody</i>, occasionally used as a general euphemision (from Maori transposition of English /B/ as /P/ and /D/ as /R/) [also used as an adj. a plurry mess]

>  A Greytown Maori describing the Lydite shell and its effects to a brother Maori, said: "By cripes! he the plurry boy to kill the Poa. When he burst, as soon you hear the smell, you dead!" <i>(Aug 4, 1900,New Zealand Free Lance,10</i>)

>  <b>FERGUSON</b> [Tom, the Aust black speaks] `You one plurry fool', he said angrily, `you one big plurry fool' <i>(1913,Marie Levant,23</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  PLURRY. - The great Australian adjective as expressed in the more mellifluous language of the Maori. <i>Ibid.</i> 161 He t'e plurry Porangi, I t'ink. <i>(1917,New Zealand At the Front,xiv</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> `<i>Plurry pakeha</i>, eh? You got the skin like the Maori, but you're not <i>tangata</i> Maori. There isn't any Maori who doesn't eat the <i>hou-hou.'</i> <i>Ibid.</i> 183 [Maori speaks] `Up at Wairoa, that Sergeant Wace, he's so plurry frightened he gets under the table and hides when he hears Starkie's coming.' <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,148</i>)

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> <i>(1938,Brown Man's Burden,29</i>)

>  <b>BAKER</b> If, as appears to be suggested by raconteurs and cartoonists, the Maori finds <i>plurry</i> (bloody) and <i>py korry</i> necessary ingredients of normal conversation ... <i>(1941,NZ Slang,71</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> He could speak beautiful English but often he put on the plurry Maori eh just to have a crack at us ... <i>Ibid.</i> 240 Rata was right. I'll go round the plurry bend. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,206</i>)

>  <b>MUIR</b> `Anyway, it's no bloody good for a title. No one would know how to pronounce it [a Maori name]. Let's get right away from this plurry native stuff.' <i>(1960,Word for Word,109</i>)

>  <b>McCALLUM</b> The boss who owns the big flash Jaguar looks plurry crook because the production manager has just bought the Cadillac. <i>(1963,Half-Gallon Jar,53</i>)

>  <i>plurry n. NZ sl.</i> bloody. [M corruption of BLOODY] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,579</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>LATHAM</b> ... and we made our own hats. Believe me, there were some beauts! One Maori girl's remark summed it up in a lot of cases - `Call that plurry thing a potae (hat)? Looks more like a mimi pot!' <i>(1986,WAAC Story, The,3</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>plurry</i> bloody; pidgin in Australia and New Zealand; Partridge says it is from Aboriginal's natural use of the word, OEDS says NZA slang, Turner thinks it a convention of journalists rather than Maori, in support of which was the slanguage of the character Hori in the bestselling book <i>The Half-Gallon Jar. </i> <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,85</i>)

>  [A] Maori was asked on the Athletic Park, "You think New Zealand wins to-day?" The astonishing answer was: "No plurry fear! Englishmen he te win, heesy!" <i>(Aug 15, 1904,Evening Post,2</i>)

## pocket
 
 <i>n.</i> wool pack, often slung in pairs over a pack-horse [sheep farming]

 <i>n.</i> a crevice or cavity in rock, holding gold [gold mining]

>  On proceeding to examine the lods in the No. 2 level, I find it is what is generally called the Dauntless leader, and a rich pocket was in sight; ... <i>(Mar 8, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> The heaviest gold always lies in `pockets' or rock-holes ... Our cradle was set, ... and we began to take up the ground in the bed of the creek to get down to the bottom, where the heaviest gold always lies in `pockets' or rock holes, and crevices. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,16</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> The Dunstan gold workings were of two kinds - technically known as `beach claims' and `bank claims'. The latter were on the gravelly river banks which the miners sluiced away bodily for the golden grains ... The former were on the sandy margins of the river, and were often extended by means of `wing-dams' and other ingenious devices far into the rushing waters. In these claims the gold was found lodged in `pockets' or fissures formed by the slate bars ... <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk I iv 17,1889 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> Gold lay in a series of rich `pockets' (as the crevices were termed) <i>(1874,George Washington Pratt,51</i>)

The `poha,' which I have called a cask - as it performs the office of one - is constructed by the natives in an ingenious manner, worthy of description.  <i>n.</i> [<i>Metrosideros excelsa</i>]

>  Ten Pounds Reward .. will be paid for such information as will convict the person or persons who within the last month have been cutting and removing the roots or branches or both of the pohutukawa from my land near the Watchman. <i>(Mar 9, 1858,Daily Southern Cross,1</i>)
