>  <b>CARMAN</b> Pohutukawa are our remarkable trees - the symbol of New Zealand, as the oak is the emblem of England. Like the oak, the pohutukawa has a short, stout gnarled trunk that becomes beautifully gnarled with time, the wide-spreading branches forming a most stately and memorable tree... The name "pohutukawa" comes from "hutukawa" (a head-dress of red feathers) and "po" which has meany meanings, including night or underworld. Governor Grey interpreted this as meaning "the tree with red adornment near the sea", but "po" could equally be a reference to the traditional tree at Cape Reinga where the spirits of the dead descend via the pohutukawa tree to a secret cave, the entrance to Te Reinga, the spirit or underworld [sic]. A small, scrubby version still clings to the cliff edge at the leaping-off place of the spirits. In Maori, to say someone "has slid down the pohutukawa root" is a lyrical way of saying he has joined the ancestors. <i>(Jan 23, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52</i>)

 <i>n.</i> [Jim says definitions in British dictionaries relate <i>point</i> to the seacoast (headland, cape, promontory - "a high point jutting out into the sea"). NSOD gives as <i>chiefly US</i> "a tapering extremity of land etc.. constituting a geographical feature". This echoes the common use of point in NZ in <i>inland</i> placenames e.g. Arthur's Point, Awakino Point, Pleasant Point, Titoki Point, Ti-tree Point." I have not noticed any inland "Points" in England or in a cursory skim through British gazetteers. This use of the word may be worth followng up.]

## Pokarekare Ana
 
 <i>n.</i> a popular Maori song

>  The documentary <i>Pokarekare Ana: A Maori Love Song</i>.. on the origins of the song, surrounds the contributions made by Sir Apirana Ngata and Paraire Tomoana with a misleading element of mystery... For a number of reasons, "Pokarekare" is unlikely tobeen the original work of either of these men. (1) "Pokarekare" was published in sheet music form in 1926 (twice), in 1927, 1936 and 1940 prior to Paraire Tomoana's death in 1946. The two 1926 versions are said to have been arranged by "Hemi Piripata" and "Alfred Hill": respectively. the 1927 version is said to have been arranged by "P H Tomoana and Archie Don". The 1936 version is said to have been "collected and sung by Ernest McKinley" and the 1940 version is again said to have ben arranged by "Hemi Piripata". in short, no published version of the song, including the 1919 booklet entry, gave any credit to either Apirana Ngata or to P H Tomoana for composing the song in their lifetimes... The most likely conclusion would seem to be that what has affectionately become "New Zealand's unofficial anthem" originated in the far north of New Zealand circa 1900 and was adapted. modified and developed in its journey through the country by a number of gifted Maori composers of the day. <i>(Apr 20, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6</i>) [NOTES: David Smith (Mandeville North, Kaiapoi)]

>  ...Tomoana explains the song's origin: "7. Pakarekare. These ditties emanated in the North of Auckland and were popularised in Narrowneck Camp, and eventually drifted to ... the East Cape. There they took the present form ... and acquired close association with the last drafts of single men from the East Cape and Wairoa districts ... the 19th and 20th Maori Reinforcements." <i>(Apr 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)

>  In 1978 I went with a Hamilton Teachers College kapa haka student group on a tour of Aboriginal settlements in Australia's Northern Territory... The group refused to include "Pokarekare Ana" in their repertoire because in their eyes the song had become a parody of the original, with "squashed banana" lyrics... At the Adelaide Festival, Rolf Harris asked us to accompany him in his latest hit, "Pokarekare Ana."... Anyone from Dame Kiri Te Kanawa down can sing "Pokarekare". It adds to the popular culture of New Zealand. <i>(Apr 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)

>  On hearing "Pokarekare" for the first time George Bernard Shaw immediately identified the music as a Swiss cradle song. <i>(Apr 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9</i>)

>  ...all too often what happens is someone gets sentimental and the song somehow stumbles on to become a mumbled medley involving "Pokarekareana". The full lyrics to which are "Pokarekareana Something Something Roto-rua". <i>(Apr 19, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  <b>WHEELER</b> The severed 'pole' is planted in a dam site or in ground that requires stabilising, and quickly shoots up to become a tree. >  (Corresp. col) Sir, - Your correspondents are incorrect regarding the origin of the term `Pommie', meaning English immigrant. The term is of Australian origin, of a period long ago when the military and other authorities of the time called the men of the penal settlements, `Prisoners of Mother England', which was shortened to P.O.M.E. and later made `Pommie'. The New Zealand term was `Homie' until superseded by the Australian adjective. And even now Pommie is being superseded by the term `Pongo'. The term certainly was derisive in origin, and as to whether it is still derisive depends entirely upon the individual addressed as such. The writer is of the fourth generation (N.Z. with Austr. connections). Winther Pedersen. <i>(1951,Evening Post</i>) [NOTES: ? Jan?]

>  I was amused by your reply to `T.P.P.' There is no obscurity about the origin of `Pommy'. The origin is the obvious one - `Emigrant'. The emigrants themselves corrupted this to `pomegranate'. From 1914 to 1925 I frequently heard and used `pomegranate' to describe a new arrival. Over recent years this has become abbreviated to `Pommy'. Thick-Skinned Pommy. <i>(1951,Evening Post</i>)

>  A Tasmanian gave the origin definitely as being `pomegranate', the colour of that fruit being similar to the high colour of the complexions of the English, and very noticeable against the sun-dried appearance of the Aussie complexion. This has been acceptable to many knowing the Aussies' susceptibility to using phrases such as `plates of meat' for feet and `trouble for strife' for wife. Pommy to many has become a most objectionable word owing to the way it has been used with other words. Only the most ignorant use of such terms, not thinking that their forefathers came from that same brave country. If my comrades of the Homeland, newly arrived, who use the nom-de-plume, or refer to themselves as `Pommies', read this they will now understand why it is objectionable even when used in a friendly manner. British and Proud of it. <i>(1951,Evening Post</i>)

>  Sir, - Fifty years ago a shipload of passengers arrived in Australia. Coming through the tropics, they got badly burned and their faces were scarlet. The word `Pommie' was derived from a well-known Australian fruit at the time, the scarlet pomegranate. So the Australians named the new arrivals `Pommies' (just fun), and `Pommie' is still used occasionally. -E.M.W. <i>(Dec 31, 1951,Christchurch Star-Sun,2</i>)

>  Sir, -A correspondent wishes to know the origin of the word `Pommie.' The famous war correspondent, the late Ashmad Barlett, in his book, `Despatches from the Dardanelles,' written at the time of the campaign, says that the term `Pommie' was applied by veteran troops of the campaign to newly arrived troops from Britain. Their fresh pink complexions were likened to the fruit pomegranate, in contrast to the bronzed features of the veteran troops. They were referred to as `Pommies.' The term, therefore, was not applied by Dominion troops in particular to those from Britain, but by veteran troops, both British and Dominion, to new arrivals. -KIWI. <i>(Jan 2, 1958,Christchurch Star-Sun,2</i>)

>  Sir, - In reply to O.J. Davis and `Very Interested' relating to the origin of the word `Pommie.' The word apparently came into being during the 1914-18 War and is derived from the French word pommes, meaning, I believe, potatoes. During the war the front line troops of the British Army were very seriously short of food, except for potatoes, on which they subsisted for many weeks. Hence on the fields at Flanders this peculiar and, I might say, very controversial word came into being. I am sure that any British World War I veteran could affirm this explanation.-W.J.BRACKS. <i>(Jan 4, 1958,Christchurch Star-Sun,2</i>)

>  Sir, - It is `POM-E,' not `Pommie.' These four letters originated in the old sailing ship days. Migrants leaving the British Isles were issued with a permit of migration certificate which was headed, `Permit of migration-Ireland,' `Permit of migration-England,' depending on the part of the British Isles one was from. The first letters in these four words `Permit of migration-England' are `POM-E,' spelt now, as pronounced then, `Pommie.' -SAILS. <i>(Jan 6, 1958,Christchurch Star-Sun,2</i>)

>  Sir, - The red coat of the soldier gave rise to the sailors' nickname for him of `Pommy,' a corruption of the French `pomme.' This derivation is far more likely than `Prisoner of Mother England.' The derogatory nickname would be more likely to stick to the guards than to the convicts. If my explanation is incorrect am I entitled to call our trans-Tasman cousins (and others) `Pommies?' - I am, etc., A PENSIONER OF MOTHER ENGLAND. <i>(Feb 23, 1962,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  Sir, - Unfortunately previous correspondents have been confused by the spelling of `Pommy.' I understand the correct spelling to be P.O.M.M.I.E., this being derived from the initial letters of the phrase, `People of Many Magnificient Immortal Epics.' This derivation was given in the Australian R.S.L. magazine several years ago. - I am, etc, DRONGATUS PONGORUM. <i>(1962,Evening Post</i>)

>  EVERY now and then some one puts forward a new theory on why Englishmen are occasionally referred to in these southern latitudes as `Pommies'. The following note from Mr. G.T.M., of the coastal motor vessel Squall, at Wellington, may clear things up: `I first visited Aussie in 1911-Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, and Queensland. Immigrants were variously termed-Immygrant', `Jimmy grants', and up among the bananalanders, quite often `Pommy grants' (pomegranates). Very soon this became `Pommy'; and this, I think, would be the true derivation.' <i>(Sep 3, 1964,Dominion,4</i>)

## Pongo
 
 <i>adj.</i> British, Pommie [Pongolia, a fanciful and derogatory name for the British Isles. Pongolian, adjective.]

>  Those guys in D company might not understand if we talked to them with a Pongo accent. <i>(Dec 18, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/182 : 4</i>)

>  <b>THE SARGE</b> "You can call me 'chum', lad," he added, breaking into a broad Pongo dialect. <i>(1950,Excuse my Feet!,130</i>)

>  <b>DAVIN</b> Like that pongo cobber of yours, the home. <i>(1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,165</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> We strolled up the main <i>strada</i> in the evening ... and the Pongo red-cap stopped us to demand where our hats were. Bloody cheek said Mick, as if we're in their damned Pongo army ... The poor old Pongos in their hairy battle-dress, on skimpy rations and poor pay, the poor old Pongos with their white skins, calling their sergeants sir and saluting right left and centre all over the place. And nattering in incomprehensible dialects and county idiom. <i>Ibid.</i> 95 A real Pongo outlook because he'd only been out a few years when the war came and he went into our army. He didn't belong. He had that Pommie accent and that Pommie outlook. It's in the book he'd say. Do it as per the book. <i>Ibid.</i> 219 `Bloody Reginald. What a name to give a kid. A real sissy Pongo name.' ... `This Pongo business annoys me. You haven't even got it right. Pongo's the naval word for soldiers or marines. Out here they use it as just another form of Pommie.' <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,93</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> `You may think I'm a bit of a drongo,' said Ivan surprisingly. `Letting that big Pommy bastard horn in on me and Mollie. ... If I turfed that Pongo bastard out of the house she'd go with him.' <i>(1962,Horse,35,1985 ed.</i>) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 35]



 
 <i>n.</i> a Pommy (soldier)

>  It's about the young pongo of Bari.. / Who tried to commit hari-kari. <i>(May 22, 1944,NZEF Times,III/152 : 4</i>)

>  A big bronzed Pongo came in. <i>(Sep 7, 1942,2NZEF Times,5</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> An elderly quiet-spoken Pongo ... <i>(1945,Gunner Inglorious,148</i>)

>  <i>Pongo</i>: Anyone unfortunate enough not to be a New Zealander - generally a Tommy. <i>(1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a British soldier; occas. derog. for a base-wallah, =bludger, =red arse (perhaps, from the military figurative connection between (field-officers red tabs etc developing) RED-ARSE with play ape's arse, and PONGO `ape'.)

>  Talking to mere Pongos. <i>(Jan 11, 1943,2NZEF Times,81/5</i>)

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> The [supply] vehicles were obviously driven by `base-wallahs' - `pongoes' is the expression. <i>Ibid.</i> 151 Hear about the Pongo up in the blue for the first time. <i>(1944,Troop Target,127</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a Pommy [ca1950 (R.Barraclough) An Englishman; disparagingly.]

>  <b>WILSON</b> You can't do this, yer bloody Pongo. <i>Ibid.</i> 33 `How long does a bloke have to be in this country before people stop calling you a Pongo?' <i>(1957,Strip Jack Naked,25</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> `A real Pommie eh? Imagine that.' `Yes, we're all Pommies here.' `A real bloody Pongo.' `This Pongo business annoys me. You haven't even got it right. Pongo's the naval word for soldiers or marines. Out here they use it as just another form of Pommie.' `Oh well, it's all the same to me.' ... `They're all right really. The Pommies, I mean. The Homeys, the Chooms, the Pongos.' <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,219</i>)

>  [Correspondent writing on the word POMMIE signs himself] Drongatus Pongorum. <i>(Feb 23, 1962,Evening Post,8</i>)

>  Mortimer looked a real nong. `This here is Mortimer,' said Fred. `He's a pongo, but he can't help it.' <i>(1977,Listener Short Stories,147</i>) [NOTES: 1973 Grant `NZ Short Story']

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>pongo</i> British person; originally used by British sailors to describe marine or soldier they were required to join forces with in WWI, probably not unaware that the word meant `monkey', though derivation credited to forage cap resembling that worn by the dog Pongo in a Punch and Judy show; brought back by Anzacs as name for their British counterpart. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,86</i>)

## Poor Jenny
 
 <i>n.</i> a children's game

>  <b>LAWLOR</b> ...Tom says I am a sheeler for playing Poor Jenny ... My spelling cannot have improved much with the years for I had to look up the dictionary to find whether one spelt the word `sheila' or `sheilagh'. Of course `Poor Jenny' or `Poor Sally', as it is perhaps better known, was and no doubt still is a girl's game. As I had three doting sisters I cheerfully joined their games when my boy friends were not looking. Remember the words of the song? Poor Sally is a-weeping, a-weeping, a-weeping, Poor Sally is a-weeping, On a bright summer's day. On the carpet she shall kneel While the grass grows in the field - Stand up, stand up, upon your feet, And choose the one you love so sweet. Then followed `the moment of truth' and with girl and boy standing demurely in the middle of the ring of children, the circle danced around them singing: Now you're married I wish you joy, First a girl and then a boy. I forget the final words, if any. Usually this game was followed by `Ring-a-ring a rosie, Pop down a posie.' Strange, though, how the love-making aspect would come into many of these old games. I must have been a pronounced `sheeler' about this time because I also remember joining in the singing of I sent a letter to my love And on the way I dropped it, Some of you have picked it up And put it in your pocket. Dropped it - dropped it! And so on. A year or two later at the mellowing age of 10 years I abhorred all these `sissy' games though I still had a hankering to play `Oranges and Lemons', even at the great age of 12. <i>(Jun 27, 1903,Diary</i>) [NOTES: (1903 June 27) Pat Lawlor Wellington Diary in 1977 Aug. 27 Dominion 6 June 27 1903]

## poor pretences
 
 <i>n.</i> the grass Poa pratensis [folk etymology]

>  I saw some man sowing grass seed the other day on one of the public roads, and to satisfy an innate curiosity I asked him what it was. "It's what they call 'poor pretences,'" he said, "and bedad, sir, it's a very good name, for it is that same, for divil a one of it iver comes up that ivir I sees!" <i>(Apr 27, 1880,Hawke's Bay Herald,3</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRIE-SMITH</b> In the early 'eighties occurred two dry seasons during which grass fires were run over the hot western and northern faces of certain portions on eastern Tutira; on the blackened ground then and once again seedlings of brome-grass (<i>Bromus mollis</i>) appeared in so great profusion that other grasses were temporarily submerged in hillsides of waving hay. [284] `Poor Pretences' was then the name by which this brome-grass was known on the east coast : it may be worth putting on record a suggestion as to how the plant came by such a curious designation. It was a `poor pretence' compared with ryegrass, cock's-foot, and white clover, the mixture sown then almost as a religious duty on Hawke's Bay runs, good and bad alike. So much for the sense; as regards the sound, `poor pretences' can, I think, only be a corruption of <i>Poa pratensis</i>; the Latin name of the one plant done into English has been fitted to another. The reader will recollect how this grass - more widely known as goose-grass - was sown wholesale over the trough of the run. <i>(1926,Tutira,283</i>)

## popper
 
 <i>n.</i> a pneumatic tunnelling drill [ca1951 R.Gilberd (Northland) quarrymen's]

As the men's hands steadied the poppers (the tongues of flame eating into rotten sandstone ...), you could watch their taut arms vibrate, their bodies tremble. <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,151</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> It was not until considerably later that the `swing type' stoper with its pneumatic-feed-leg for drilling uppers, and known as the `popper', came into use. In it the drill was rotated in the hole by swinging the machine handle backwards and forwards. At first the miners did not like it, as they considered it `shook up' the roof too much, causing falls of ground, but it was light and easily transportable and was fast in good ground. It remained in use in the stopes for many years, until the much later introduction of the rotary stoper. At one stage the popper was given the rather undeserved name of the `widow-maker'. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,185</i>)

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> For the first time in my life I saw, and heard, pneumatic drills at work. They were referred to as `poppers'. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,85</i>)

>  Sir Arthur Guinness interviewed the Prime Minister this morning, and urged him to appoint a Royal Commission to enquire and report whether the "popper" drill could with safety, and especially in regard to the health of the miners, be worked by one man. <i>(Jul 22, 1912,Evening Post,7</i>)

## poppy show
 
 <i>n.</i> a girl's show of underwear [ca1950s (Kath Walls) ca 1930s DEH]

>  When I was a child, a well-used term for any female accidentally showing too much underwear was "poppy show" - just saying the two words ensured a rapid hitching of petticoat or smoothing of rumpled skirts. <i>(Jan 29, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> For example, when a girl's dress blows in the air, boys will claim they have seen a `poppy show'. This is a widespread term. <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/665</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Pin dips were also another popular amusement. `A pin or a bull or a button, To see a rary rary show show show!' (1875; Tahataki). A piece of glass backed by cardboard was covered with a piece of paper that could be flicked up to show the `rary rary show' or had a slit in it through which one could peep. One saw through the glass a variety of colors, pieces of colored paper, flower petals, pictures, and later pieces off cigarette boxes. Sometimes these had been arranged in some pattern, at other times they were kaleidoscopic only, and the perceiver had himself to add the configurations of intelligibility. The price for the view was always a pin `which we did not want anyhow but always accepted,' a relic from an age when such things were rare. Pin dips were known also as `poppy shows' (perhaps it was the similar flash of color that gave the same name - `the poppy show' - to the exciting experience of seeing a girl's dress blown upward by the wind; pins were not charged for flowers of this sort). In fact, the pin dip or the prick book may have developed from the poppy show. The poppy show was common before 1900 and the prick book after that date, a fact connected with the ever-increasing stock of picture cards and magazine pictures available to children. <i>(1981,History of Children's Play,223</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> The poppy shows with the Robertson tart in the pine plantation behind the hospital ... . <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,51</i>)

## porch
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jim writes: The question is whether the <i>British</i> use of porch is also wider than the dictionaries suggest. The absence of the terms sunporch etc from these dictionaries may be significant. I have noticed two (apparently) wider uses in Humphrey Carpenter's biography of Tolkien p.246 - "Now they had time simply to sit and talk especially on summer evenings after supper, on a bench in the front pocrch of Sandfield Road." [This is interesting for the author's phrase <i>in the porch</i>, whereas we would normally say <i>on the porch</i>. Also in Ruth Rendell, <i>Harm Done</i> p. 213. A 1987 Midlands Property Supplement has porch only in the sense of entrance porch (and then seldom); one or two ads have the term <i>storm porch</i> which was new to me. (Although porch and verandah are partly interchangeable, I think that the covered entrance to a meeting house - whare tipuna, wharenui - is always in English "porch", although it extends for the full width of the building.)]

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Many of the old station cooks, with the assistance of an `offsider' (mate) found no difficulty in cooking for fifty or sixty men. ... it has to be remembered that ... bread cost only 6d. or 7d. a 4lb. loaf, and tea (post and rails) could be bought for 1/- per lb. Some of these contract cooks were great fossickers and managed to find quite a lot of green stuff for vegetables ... <i>(1940,Te Waimate,91,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <i>Post </i>(p&omacr.st),<i> n</i>. [Add.] <i>Post and rail tea, or Posts and rails, </i>a decoction of coarse tea; - so called because the floating leaves resemble sticks or rails.<i> [Colloq., Australia] </i> <i>(1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2029</i>)

>  <i>post-and-rails (tea)</i> strong, coarse, inferior tea made in a billy (q.v.) with pieces of stalk or leaves floating in it. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a coarse drinking tea with pieces of leaves and stalk floating on the surface.

>  <b>MORRIS</b> Post-and-Rail Tea, slang name for strong bush-tea: so called because the large bits of the tea, or supposed tea, float about in the billy, which are compared by a strong imagination to the posts and rails of the wooden fence so frequent in Australia. [1851] <i>(1898,Austral English,367</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> I forgot tea, 4s. .. but the quality; we used to call it Posts and Rails [on the diggings c1860s]. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,43</i>)

>  <b>BURTON</b> ... the tea was `of the commonest kind'. The brand was Young Green Hyson, but the [missionary] settlers nicknamed the foul brew `post and rails'. This was a reference to the twigs which floated about on the surface, large enough to form the posts and rails of a wooden fence. <i>(1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,16</i>)

>  But even that sparkling individual himself must be aware that "post and rail" tea and roasted corn coffee are "filth;" and sugar impregnated with arsenic is unfortunately "poison." <i>(Dec 23, 1869,Wellington Independent,5</i>)

>  Even Madame Melba is alleged to have imbibed smoking "post and rail" tea, but I expect the billy was silver, encrusted with diamonds. <i>(Apr 25, 1903,New Zealand Free Lance,19</i>)

>  <b>JAMIESON</b> In those days of my childhood it was all China tea, the common kind went by the name of post and rail. 'Post and rail' meant it was more stem and very little leaf. <i>(1911,Diary,27</i>) [NOTES: in Jamieson (1916) Old Memories]

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> .. bread cost only 6d. or 7d. a 4lb. loaf, and tea (post and rails) could be bought for 1/- per lb. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,91</i>) [NOTES: from 1954 edition: Many of the old station cooks, with the assistance of an `offsider' (mate) found no difficulty in cooking for fifty or sixty men. .. it has to be remembered that .. bread cost only 6d. or 7d. a 4lb. loaf, and tea (post and rails) could be bought for 1/- per lb. Some of these contract cooks were great fossickers and managed to find quite a lot of green stuff for vegetables ...]

>  <b>VANCE</b> 'post and rail tea' - tea stalks floating on top of the tea brew. <i>(1965,High Endeavour,52</i>)

## poukai
 
 <i>n.</i> any of a round of annual hui attended by the Maori King (or, formerly, Queen) in Kingite territory [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  Home in Waikato, Tawhiao sought solutions to Maori problems through the establishment of Maori institutions to deal with them. In 1885 he initiated the institution of Poukai, where the King would pay annual visits to King movement marae to encourage people to return to their home marae at least once a year. The first Poukai (originally called Puna-kai, or 'source of food') was held at Whatiwhatihoe in March 1885. It was a day for the less fortunate to be fed and entertained. The Poukai developed into an event which would later ensure direct consultation of the people with the King. <i>(1993,Dictionary of NZ Biography,2</i>) [NOTES: from the DNZB entry on King Tawhiao (R.T. Mahuta) (updated online version 2007)]

>  KOKOHINAU Marae in Te Teko had the honour of hosting, for the first time in the Mataatua area, the Maori King, Tuheitia on Sunday.... Mr Eruera said the king was attending a poukai, or assembly, and this was the 44th year it had been held at Kokohinau. ... A copy of a publication celebrating the 44 years of the poukai being held at Kokohinau was also given to the king by Katerina Waiari. Teriaki Amoamo, on behalf of Whakatohea and Te Whanau-a-Apanui, presented a ceremonial hoe waka (canoe paddle).Mr Eruera said the open debate session, which is what a poukai is all about, raised a few issues. One of those issues was brought up earlier in the day by Whakatohea and Te Whanau-a-Apanui who requested to share the poukai in the future. Mr Eruera said the request would have to go to hapu members to consider.A restored flagpole was also erected - hapu members, under the direction of carver Graham Junior Niao, carried out the restoration on the carved pole - and the special poukai flag was flown. <i>(Jan 18, 2007,Whakatane Beacon,1</i>)

## pound
 
 <i>v.</i> impound

 <i>n.</i> used in various transf. uses and fig. senses (often graded between 1 and 19) to express various conditions of alleged intellectual handicap, mental bankruptcy, implying that a person is not all there; see also bob, quid, shilling; the formula is usu.: to be/pay (only) [x] bob (shillings) in the pound or not to be 20 shillings in the pound; cf. not the full quid; ?a synonym from punting for to be a shingle short, be two bob in the pound, to be sixpence in the shilling [1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 2 POUND, NINETEEN AND ELEVEN IN THE]

 <i>n.</i> [ca1941-45 p.c. Riverside Community `Where one is kept preparatory to sentence']

>  <b>HAMILTON</b> ... it's a pretty rare specimen who won't do anything for a man in the pound. <i>Ibid.</i> 83 The exercise yard of the pound is the place where they used to hang and flog. <i>(1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,72</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> solitary confinement; a punishment cell or area

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> The day before the following weekend I was locked up in the pound. A pound is for locking up animals. If only we'd been animals the RSPCA and all the animal lovers would have caused a public outcry - but we were only humans so no one worried. There had been no reason for punishing me - the official reason given was that I was put there as an assistant cleaner. The cleaner already there had virtually nothing to do. So the whole deal was hell of an unusual - in fact no crim I met had ever before heard of a situation in which an inmate who'd committed no offence had been sent to the pound - especially as an assistant cleaner. <i>(1971,Bullshit and Jellybeans,15</i>)

>  <b>MacKENZIE</b> The punishment block, known as the `pound' or the `dummy', was a prison within the [Mt Eden] prison. In the basement, through a steel grille and a wooden door, it was a dimly lit and silent annexe leading at its far end to the tiny execution yard. <i>Ibid.</i> 98 <i>pound</i> punishment block <i>(1980,While We Have Prisons,14</i>)

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> You're in <i>jail now, son!</i> Another peep from you and you'll be down the fookin pound. <i>Ibid.</i> 145 So I settled back to do my bird. Callander came up and found I was in the pound ... . In the digger the days go by pretty slowly ... .<i>Ibid.</i> 252 POUND (n) Detention unit. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,25</i>)

>  The tale about being in the "pound" is told and retold; the rebel has returned to the fold with stature increased. What isn't mentioned is the torturous difficulty the "hero" had in making it throught a few days on his own. <i>(Jun 22, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31</i>)

## PPP

 <i>n.</i> [possible distinction re prerogative of crown]

>  <b>MACDONALD</b> This was the interpretation put by the Governor (Sir George Grey) on the land clauses of the Treaty of Waitangi, commonly known as the `pre-emptive' right of Her Majesty under the Treaty. <i>(1910,Reminiscences,51</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> <i>(1930,Early Canterbury Runs,26</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) land purchased with a pre-emptive right.

>  All Mr Acland's houses are on preemptive right so he gets off all the taxes, ... a direct inducement not to buy freehold. <i>(Apr 19, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,132,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PINNEY</b> There was a house and woolshed on a pre-emptive right; there was also a seam of coal. <i>(1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,70</i>)

>  <b>PEACHE</b> That some of the pre-emptive rights may have to be bought up ... still the amount should not be much. <i>(Jul 4, 1876,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1876 July 4 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 47]

>  .. the law was plain enough as regards the exact or at all events approximate position of the 80 acre pre-emptive right. <i>(Dec 10, 1859,Hawke's Bay Herald,4</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> In eighteen months nearly all the run except the pre-emptives had gone. <i>(1946,Early Canterbury Runs,37</i>)

>  <b>PINNEY</b> There was a house and woolshed on a pre-emptive right. <i>(1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,70</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a right of a land purchaser to buy public land on condition that it be improved

>  "Your committee now proceed to state the principles which, in their opinion, should form the basis of a law to be enacted by the Imperial Parliament, for the settlement of the rights of property in New Zealand .. 5. That the holders of lands not in cultivation, whose titles shall have been admitted by the commissioners, shall thereupon have a pre-emptive right of purchase from the crown, at a price not less than 20.s per acre. .." <i>(Jan 2, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2</i>)

>  Mr Driver brought Mr Brunton's application for a pre-emptive right on run 62 before the board. <i>(Jul 3, 1875,Otago Witness,10</i>)

>  The natives in this district are preparing a petition against the Crown's resumption of the pre-emptive right. <i>(May 5, 1884,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  <b>WAITT</b> The largest run-holder has only a pre-emptive right <i>(1856,Letter,13</i>) [NOTES: 1856 Waitt Letter to Joseph Thomas 13]

>  As to the preemptive right, please send me the best description you can of what we should apply for. We have a right to <i>`80 acres at one of the stations and 10 acres at each of the other stations erected upon the run'</i> ... It seems, however, that there must be a station of some sort at the place where preemptive is applied for; but it would be easy to have a hut put up at any place where we wanted to take our land. <i>(Apr 20, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/37,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

>  <b>G M WILSON</b> The settler was allowed a pre-emptive right for every 50,000 acres or so which he could choose where he liked. In this way the owner of this station got about 4,000 acres pre-emptive right on this run at [pound]1 per acre. <i>(Feb 2, 1873,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 2 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 164]

>  A communication was received from the Surveyor-general in regard to the balance of pre-emptive right on pastoral run 208, Wairaki, the Otago School Commissioners having desired that the land be proclaimed an education reserve. <i>(Oct 31, 1900,Otago Witness,30</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> Every [Canterbury] run-holder has a preemptive right over 250 acres round his homestead, and 50 acres round any other buildings he may have upon his run. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,viii/115</i>)

>  <b>W.G. REES</b> Why shouldn't he, the first arrival, have the right to take up his pre-emptive option? ... he made the most of it when he appeared before the Waste land Board on February 11 and 13, 1863. `It was about four months ago,' he told the board ..., `that I realised I would be upset by gold-diggers. As a result I have been forced to apply for my pre-emptive rights sooner than I would otherwise have done.' <i>(Feb 1871,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1863 Feb W.G. Rees in 1971 Griffiths King Wakatip 97]

>  The runholder was also allowed a pre-emptive right of purchase on his run of eighty acres for his principal station and ten acres for each out-station. This concession ... proved later to interfere with the fuller settlement of the country, as the runholder, in his phrase, `picked the eyes out.' <i>(1898,Hocken Contributions,168</i>)

>  <b>EVANS</b> The pre-emptive right was the right of a lessee to freehold one square mile of land. This became the station headquarters. <i>(1962,Waikaka Saga,117</i>)

>  <b>SEWELL</b> The stockowners talk big about what they mean to do one of these days in return for those pre-emptive rights which they have secured to themselves. <i>(Mar 12, 1853,Sewell Journal 1853-1857,209</i>) [NOTES: in McIntyre (1980) Sewell Journal 1853-1856]

>  Every run-holder has a pre-emptive right over 250 acres round his homestead, and 50 acres round any other buildings he may have upon his run. <i>(1860,In Memoriam,95</i>) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

>  After selection most of the runholders were granted pre-emptive rights for residential purposes. <i>(1910,Tapanui Station,11</i>)

## Premier
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  The Premier was interviewed at 10.30 o'clock this morning by a deputation representing the flax milling industry. <i>(Apr 17, 1890,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  .. we ought to feel thankful that we are blessed with a Premier who has the courage to let the colony know his opinion of such meddlesome traders. <i>(Mar 23, 1895,Evening Post,4</i>)

>  At this meeting Lord Howick was the only minister present besides the premier, apparently as the organ of the colonial Office. <i>(Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,4</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> In the constitutional debates of 1854 during the first session of the New Zealand Parliament, the term `Prime Minister' was frequently used in a somewhat casual fashion. This explains in part why it was some years before the term `Premier' came into general usage. William Fox (q.v.) who took office in July 1861, was described in the <i>Gazette</i> as Attorney-General `with first seat in the Ministry'. In November 1864 Weld (q.v.) was gazetted as holding `a seat in the Executive Council and the office of Premier'. Stafford (q.v.) his successor, in October 1865 was termed `First Minister'. In June 1869, when Fox again headed a Ministry, he was described officially as `Premier and member of the Executive Council.' Thereafter the term `Premier' was regularly used. Nevertheless, in the Schedule of the Civil List Act of 1873, provision was made for the salary of the Leader of the Government `being the Prime Minister'. The first Premier to use the title `Prime Minister' officially was Richard John Seddon (q.v.). It was used in the <i>New Zealand Year Book</i> of 1900 and the Imperial Conference of 1903 confirmed the practice. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/868</i>)

>  Wellington. Interviewed the premier Sir John Hall ... Dined at Bellamys ... <i>(1880,Chudleigh Diary,289,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BAUCKE</b> ... they practise the mission which the Premier in jaunty abandon has mapped out for them, ... <i>(1905,Where the White Man Treads,227</i>)

>  <b>HULL</b> [a character Massey speaks] I want to be Premier, and wear a Windsor dress;/ <i>(1907,College Songs,26</i>) [NOTES: 1906 May in 1907 Hull College Songs 26]

>  Had a meeting with Mr Seddon at 2 p.m. Dr. Hugh Walter Pigeon introduced the Premier to all of us ... <i>(Mar 27, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,432,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <i>The Premier's Private Secretary</i> I was `grafting' in the office long after the `boss' had left; ... <i>(Sep 11, 1911,Triad, The,45</i>)

>  `Bob' Semple - dubbed `the Demon of Dissension' by those who want the mob tame flunkeys - said at Waihi that New Zealand's Premier was being gushed over by the `snobs.' <i>(May 26, 1911,Maoriland Worker,12/6/4</i>)

## presently
 
 <i>adv.</i> At directly this etym. comment: [OED2 6c dial and US 1851 `shortly' applies generally in NZ rather than 6 a. `immediately'. Compare the use ofpresently.] The following is moved from the DIRECTLY entry for check at PRESENTLY: presently. In NZ presently usually means `in a short while' (as OED 4), but I have heard it used occas. as immediately (OED 4). At <i>presently</i> 4, OED notes `In blunted sense (gradually weakened from 3): ... soon, shortly. (cf ANON 5, BY and BY 4, and colloq use of <i>directly, immediately,</i> and nearly all advbs of the same kind.) Now the ordinary use.'; W3] [The OED would seem to belie the citation from the Listener]

>  This was in the days when "presently" meant "later" - not "as of now" as it seems to today. <i>(Jul 26, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11</i>)

## press
 
 <i>v.</i> to compress wool into bales; to operate a wool press (See [wool press](../W#wool-press))

>  .. some merchants have them to press wool bales and save freight thereby. <i>(Sep 25, 1858,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)

>  My wish is to see a proper use made of all the natural resources, and I would even go so far as for instance to use the pressure of the water, before it is supplied to the ships, or before a street is filled with it, to press wool, or do some other service on the wharf. <i>(May 27, 1880,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  My employment was chiefly in packing the woolbales which is very heavy work. You put from 90 to 120 fleeces in a bail which way [sic] from 300 to 350 lbs. It is hard to press the wool into so small a compass. We sheared some 850 sheep to-day. <i>(Nov 24, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,67,1950 ed.</i>)

>  `Press' and `sweep' are technical terms for necessary operations in the woolshed at shearing time. The former refers to pressing the fleeces into tight-packed bales ... to facilitate the transport of an otherwise bulky commodity. The latter is the process of keeping the floor (the `boards'), on which the sheep are shorn, clear of loose ends of wool, dirt and excrement. <i>(1945,NZ Geographer,1/39</i>) [NOTES: (Pascoe `Canterbury High Country')]

>  <b>WILSON</b> At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed. <i>(1894,In the Land of the Tui,242</i>)

>  368 9548 sheep shorn, 139 bales pressed. I think sheep and wool will be up to last year; run sheep much better. Ewe and paddock sheep not so good. ## press noses
 
 <i>phr.</i> to hongi

>  <b>POLACK</b> Every one of them [sc. Maoris] came up to press noses, which I enacted with a few of the foremost; but respect for the shape and position of this ornamental member, made me abridge the ceremony, or I should never have retained its pristine form, so eager were these new friends to greet and welcome my arrival. <i>Ibid.</i> 85 Each presentation was accompanied by the pressing of noses (e'ongi) and expressions of `Friend, welcome; how are you all,' &c. `Ekoro airamai tenarakokoe[a2-acute],' in a whiningtone, as if each were about to condole for the loss of their entire generation. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/75</i>)

## pretties
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEITH & MAIN</b> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

## preventive detention
 
 <i>n.</i> an indeterminate sentence introduced by the Criminal Justice Act 1954 for offenders repeatedly convicted of certain crimes. [Jim Cameron writes : This replaced the previous sentence of <i>reformative detention</i> (1910) and <i>declaration as habitual offender</i> and <i>habitual criminal</i> (1906). None of these terms is recorded in DNZE. Its scope has been protean. In its present form (Criminal Justice Act 1985 as amended) it is a sentence of indefinite detention with no fixed maximum that may be imposed on persons aged 21 or more convicted of certain sexual and other serious offences. A sentence under the same name existed in England from 1908 to 1967.]

>  At the other end of the scale is the indeterminate sentence of preventive detention. A sentence of the same name existed in Britain from 1908 to 1967. Introduced in New Zealand in 1954 to replace the sentence of reformative detention (1910) and declaration as an habitual offender and habitual criminal (1906), it remains very much alive here. <i>(Jan 1999,NZWords,2</i>)

## Prime Minister
 
 <i>n.</i> . [[? date] G.H. Scholefield (ed) NZ Parliamentary Record [?p] [Mr Seddon was first Premier to assume the title, which he did in 1899. It was officially used in the N.Z. Yr Bk of 1900+5 the Parliamentary debates of 1902, it was used in the constitutional debates in the 1st session of the 1st N.Z. Parliament in 1854, + it appeared in the schedule of the Civil List Act of 1873.] [check this] The operative date for the introduction of this term to official documents was August 1900, although from context in NZPD in which it was used (more than once) by Prime Minister Seddon (who was still addressed in Parliament as Premier during the debate), it appears to have been in some general use before that date.]

>  PRIME MINISTER GIVES AN AT HOME. An at home at Hatfield House was attended by five hundred. <i>(Jun 21, 1902,Hawera & Normanby Star,2</i>)

>  `INFORMATION,' of South Otago, disputes `Snippet's' statement (April 26) that Richard John Seddon was New Zealand's first Prime Minister on the grounds that the term `Prime Minister' was not used officially till New Zealand obtained Dominion status on September 26, 1907. THE term `Prime Minister' was first used in New Zealand during a constitutional debate in New Zealand's first Parliament in 1854, and was subsequently used on many occasions during the late 19th century. In 1873, for example, in a schedule to the civil list, provision was made for the leader of the Government `being the Prime Minister.' The title `Prime Minister' was adopted officially in 1899 and Richard John Seddon was the first New Zealand Premier to use it. It was officially used in the New Zealand Year Book in 1900 and in Parliamentary debates in 1902. <i>(Jun 7, 1960,NZ Truth,42</i>)

## prison camp
 
 <i>n.</i> (historical) a low security prison [Jim writes: a historical form of penal institution in NZ. The first prison camp was at Milford Sound in the 1890s; subsequently there were <i>tree-planting camps</i> in the North and South Island. See annual reports in AJHR series H-20. Prison camp may be an international term in this sense as well as in relation to war prisoners.  <i>n.</i> a nickname for the Australian supporters of a pastoralist or sheepfarming regime in early Canterbury settlement as against those (mainly newly-arrived English 'Pilgrim' settlers who looked rather towards agricultural small-farming (See [Pilgrim](../P#pilgrim),[shagroon](../S#shagroon))



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a farmer from Australia, arriving in Canterbury after the earlier 'pilgrims' from Britain.

>  Gaily the pilgrim harnessed his plough, / When he had built up a roof o'er his head; / Singing, `From Albion hither I come;' / `Land of mine! land of mine! grow me some bread.' Proudly the prophet flourished his crook, / When he had landed his sheep from the west; / Singing, `From Philipland hither I come;' / `Silly men! silly men! wool pays the best.' <i>(Aug 9, 1951,Lyttelton Times,7</i>) [NOTES: (`Pilgrims and Prophets')]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> ...An old Australian squatter, who visited the Canterbury settlement in 1851, divided the inhabitants into pilgrims, shagruns, and prophets; the first were the original colonists, the second were people from other parts of New Zealand, and the last were settlers from Australia. <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/186-187</i>)

>  `Pilgrims and Prophets'. [title of Poem] <i>Ibid.</i> 9. The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart. [NOTE 1866] <i>Ibid.</i> 101 [Notes] During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of Sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria), who were regarded by the Settlers partly with admiration as successful colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonization and the `Canterbury System'. ... One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the <i>soubriquet</i> of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined ... The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nick-name their Port Philip visitors `prophets', and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. <i>Ibid.</i> 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders. <i>(1866,Canterbury Rhymes,5</i>)

>  <i>Prophet</i>.- Nickname of the Australian squatters who came down to Canterbury in 185(1) They were caled Ps. because they prophesied ruin for the farming pilgrims. It was they who finally persuaded Godley to authorise the squatting system here. See also <i>Shagroon</i>. (C.R., p. 5) <i>(Nov 18, 1933,Press, The</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

>  Not only did Australian sheep arrive, but during the 1850-60 period many Australian squatters (disgruntled by the fickle rainfall) also sold or abandoned their properties and migrated to New Zealand. These men arrived with capital to invest, with experience in colonial farming, knowledgeable of the peculiar habits of the Merino sheep, and with whole-hearted support of a `squatting' policy of land tenure based on the occupation of large areas of grazing country at low rentals. They became known as the `Prophets' because they forecast failure for the small-area arable farm plans of the established settlements. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/231</i>)

>  Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed, The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart .. Quickly the prophet bred up his flock. As he defied dogs, scab and catarrh. <i>(1851,BLANK ENTRY,5</i>) [NOTES: in REEVES Canterbury Rhymes (1883)]

>  <b>THOMSON</b> An old Australian squatter, who visited the Canterbury settlement in 1851, divided the inhabitants into pilgrims, shagruns and prophets; the first were the original colonists, the second were people from other parts of New Zealand and the last were settlers from Australia. <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,II 186</i>)

Atkinson)]

>  After all, the names `Centralist' and `Provincialist' do not in most cases give a truer impression than party nick-names generally convey. `Centralism', properly so called, is repugnant to all the political instincts of Englishmen. `Provincialism' is as repugnant their educated sympathisers who are called or erroneously call themselves Centralists are truer friends of local self-government than many of the defenders of `Provincialism', while some who find themselves classed under the name of Provincialists have the most profound contempt for the assumption and local tyranny that have distinguished one or two of our little centralisms. <i>(Sep 11, 1858,Lyttelton Times</i>) [NOTES: 1858 <i>Lyttelton Times</i> 11 Sept (Editorial) in 1971 Speeches and Documents 105]

The latter, on the other hand, insisted that the Imperial Parliament had established two independent governments in New Zealand, each for its own sphere, the provinces having exclusive jurisdiction in all provincial matters, and only under the control of the General Assembly on matters of general concern. <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,/223</i>)

## puffball
 
 <i>n.</i> one of several species of ball-shaped fungi which, though solid when young, are full of dust-like spores when mature.

>  <b>CROWE</b> Both the giant and common puffball are recommended as being amongst the best of the puffballs, so long as they are solid and white inside. <i>(1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,136</i>)

>  <b>CROWE</b> The Maori ate young puffballs.. after steaming. <i>(1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,136</i>)

>  <b>BROOKER et al.</b> <i>Calvatia caelata</i> (Bull.) Morg. Common name: <i>Puffball </i> Maori name: <i>Pukurau.</i> In Hooker's `Handbook ...', the name `pukurau' or `pukuvau' is <i>applied to</i> Lycoperdon fontanesei ... <i>which is now </i>known as<i> Calvatia caelata</i>. In Williams ... the name `pukurau' is identified as <i>Clathrus cibarium</i> ... a net-like fungus ... [C. caelata is found in Europe ...as well as NZ.] <i>(1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,23</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Tank Tarrant once led his gang across the paddocks ..., kicking the puffballs and the sheep turds, throwing the dry cow pats at any tarts he met. Chanting the gang haka. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,230</i>)

>  The common puffball is also finely flavoured. This is nearer a golfball size than a softball, and it has a stem. <i>(Jan 11, 2003,Dominion Post,F7</i>)

>  The giant puffball grows in any soil with high organic matter, often on bare earth and on back lawns, including my own. <i>(Jan 11, 2003,Dominion Post,F7</i>)

>  I well remember the strict warnings never to pick the puffball, and it was always a source of great satisfaction to trample the puffballs that had gone brown and watch the evil yellow cloud of spores spurt forth. <i>(Jan 11, 2003,Dominion Post,F7</i>)

>  <b>MARSHALL</b> Arthur picked up a large puff-ball and punted it high into the air. "One for the forwards," he cried, and laughed as the khaki dust drifted in the sky and the broken fungus dropped back to the ground. <i>(1979,Supper Waltz Wilson,23</i>)

 <i>n.</i>

## pug ring
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HISLOP</b> Some of the lads made their [sun-dried] bricks in what they called a pug ring, formed by driving the horses round in a circle as with the old-time chaffcutter, but Cecil made his on what they called a straight. A strip of ground about 30 yards long by four or five wide was scooped free of top soil, which was dumped on the garden nearby. It was then ploughed about ten inches deep, or according to the number of bricks required, and very well watered, which was usually done with a shovel from a tank on a sledge for even distribution, and left to soak all night. A good layer of chopped-up tussocks was then evenly spread over the top. After more watering a six-horse team was driven up and down the strip until the pug was well mixed. <i>(1943,Pure Gold,116</i>) [NOTES: [c1910, Otago]]

## puheretaiko
 
 <i>n.</i> also called senecio a New Zealand tree daisy

>  The traveller who visits Stewart Island in December or January will have his attention arrested by the blaze of crimson presented by the rata (<i>Metrosideros lucida</i>), often flecked with the pale racemes of the kamahi (<i>Weinmannia racemosa</i>), the deep green leaves of the puheretaiko and the tupari (<i>Senecio rotundifolius</i> and <i>Olearia colensoi</i>), and the grass-like leaves of the inaka (<i>Drachophyllum longifolium</i>), all of which form a fringe of greater or less breadth at the water's edge, and (except the puheretaiko) often expand into large masses ascending to the crests of the hills. <i>(1884,TrNZI,17/216</i>) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

>  <b>HOWARD</b> Along the coastal fringes [of Stewart Island] it consists of a characteristic scrub known locally as `Mutton-bird scrub', the principal constituents ... being Puheretaiko (<i>Senecio Rotundifolius</i>), Tete-a-weka (<i>Olearia Angustifolia</i>) and Daisy Tree (<i>Olearia Colensoi</i>). <i>(1940,Rakiura,xvii</i>)

## puia
 
 <i>n.</i> a geyser; a boiling spring

>  [From the Auckland Provincial <i>Gazette</i>.] .. The principal "puia" at Tokanu is called Pirori, an intermittent fountain, whose column of boiling water, of two feet in diameter, sometimes reaches a height of more than 40 feet. <i>(Aug 3, 1859,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,1</i>)

>  <b>BULLER</b> Hochstetter divides the steam jets into three kinds: 1. <i>Puias</i>, which are geysers, continuously or intermittently active. 2. <i>Ngawas</i>, which are inactive <i>Puias</i> - emitting steam, but not throwing up columns of water. 3. <i>Waiarikis</i>, which mean any sort of cistern of hot water suitable for bathing. <i>(1878,Forty Years in NZ,11</i>)

>  The word Puia is especially used in the Taupo country, to designate the intermittent, geyser-like fountains of Tokanu ... and of Whakarewarewa on Lake Rotorua. Puia has ... the more general meaning of crater or volcano, and is applied to active as well as extinct volcanoes. ... Ngawhas [is] a term specially used for non-intermittent springs, for the solfataras and sulphurous hot-springs on the Rotomahana, Rotorua, and Rotoiti. Finally, the springs suited to bathing purposes, the water of which never reaches the boiling point, and all naturally warm baths are called `Waiariki,' corresponding to the Laugar of Iceland. <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/171</i>)

>  In her passage underground she set fire to the world below, hence the hot springs, puias, fumaroles ... in the line of route. <i>(1903,TrNZI,35/172</i>)

>  ... strange to say, several large masses of waterworn gravel cemented by puia-deposit into a compact rock are to be seen a short distance below the bridge at Taupo. <i>(1905,TrNZI,37/459</i>) [NOTES: (Fletcher quoted by Hill)]

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> About three miles from this place I saw masses of white vapours rising in jets, and the natives told us that they were caused by the hot-springs (puhia). <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,1/327</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> I was told these were images of two ... men who some years ago were surprized by a hostile party in their own houses, and were cooked in one of these puias to form a repast for their savage murderers. <i>(Mar 1850,Journal,7/81</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> We caught a pig ... which is to be cooked in the puia. <i>(Feb 6, 1853,Journal,8/74</i>)

## pukaha
 
 <i>n.</i> a cloak

>  <b>LEDYARD</b> ... they add what they call the Bugabuga or the Toga, and sometimes both. The Bugabuga is a very coarse covering made with little trouble, and affords a good shelter from cold or wet weather : The Toga is different and is equally calculated for use and elegance : The Bugabuga is formed round and converging to the top where there is an apperture just sufficient to admit the head to pass through, and when on, covers the body as low as the hip : If it storms, or they have occasion to stop where they have no other shelter they squat down upon their hams, and then the bottom of the Bugabuga reaching the ground, forms a shelter to the whole body (the head excepted) which looks in that situation as if it had been severed from a human form, and fixed upon a hay-cock. <i>(Feb 1777,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1777 Feb in 1783 Ledyard Journal (1963) 14]

## pukahu
 
 <i>n.</i> any matted fibrous formation especially that found under kauri trees. [Maori]

>  The lake floor is formed of a species of pukahu, similar to that found in kauri forests, and termed "bukau" by bushmen. <i>(Sep 18, 1909,Evening Post,10</i>)

>  ... the floor of the kauri bush is covered with a thick coating of vegetable humus (<i>pukahu</i>), which is rendered highly inflammable by a mixture of dead leaves, particles of gum, and scales dropped from the resinous bark. <i>Ibid.</i> 493 Wherever the kauri-trees grow ... the ground is covered with a thick [493] layer of humus (<i>pukahau</i>), composed of vegetable fibre intemingled with fallen leaves, particles of gum, and scales from the resinous bark, the latter helping to form a solid bank, sometimes several feet in height, round the base of the trees. <i>(1899,TrNZI,31/479</i>) [NOTES: Walsh]

>  <b>LEVY</b> Really hot, white-ash burns of the felled forest were rarely secured, [15] which meant that large numbers of the felled trees did not burn, much raw pukahu was left merely blackened, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 94 In high humidity forests, ... pukahu - undecomposed dead forest litter - may accumulate on the forest floor, feet in depth. <i>(1951,Grasslands of NZ,14,1970 ed.</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> In early days the volume of the timber would not have warranted the time and expense involved clearing away the accumulated debris, known as pukahu (Maori: masses of rootlets), and usually referred to by the bushmen as `bookau'. <i>Ibid.</i> 208 The platform enabled a man to go from side to side, in order to pour <i>pukahu </i>down the face of the dam as a preventive of leaks in the planking. This pukahu (bookau to the bushman) was the matted, fibrous material which gathered at the foot of large Kauris. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,84</i>)

>  PUKAU Short for <i>pukahukau</i>. The mound at the base of mature kauri trees. syn. CONE <i>(1952,NZ Forest Glossary</i>)

>  Stumps can vary in height up to 3.2 metres above ground level ... When the stumps are covered by a pukahu - a mound of shed bark and other forestlitter - it is necessary to dig down to find the stump height. <i>(Aug 20, 1975,Evening Post,32/1-3</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to stop leaks in a dam with pukahu [(see 1 above, 1953 p.208)]

>  <b>REED</b> Some of the men were sent to pukahu it [the dam]. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,219 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>REED</b> `I have known these bookau fires to stay alight through fairly heavy falls of rain, and after a few fine days to get going again'. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,272</i>) [NOTES: (Thompson)]



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [Ma.] a matted fibrous material that accumulates on a forest floor.

>  <b>LEVY</b> Good burns were hard to obtain and most burns were not hot enough to consume all timber, so that much pukahu was left on the forest floor. <i>(1970,Grasslands of NZ,48</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a brightly coloured native swamp-hen; the pukeko is called TANGATA TAWHITO `old, ancient, original, primeval' (Williams 409), but it may have introduced itself from Australia <i>Porphyrio melanotus</i>, swamphen; also pook, red-bill, sultana bird, (swamp-)turkey; pukaki is a common mainly South Island mainly pl form; a Maori variant (of Ngati-Pukeko tribe) =pakura Besides having possibly the greatest number of descriptive names of any NZ bird, it has many chiefly oral, anglicised, variants of the original Maori <i>pu[u]keko</i>, based on these alternations: /p/ as [p] or [b] /u:/ as [u:], [ju:], [u], [ju], [?], [j?]; and after [b], [ou], [o] /e/ as [E], [ae] /o/ as [ou], [?], [i]

 <i>v.</i> (applied to sheep rather than cows)

## put (one's) pot on
 
 <i>phr.</i> to inform on, to tell on; cf. put (one's) weights up

The term is familiar, but is believed to have a highly respectable origin, `Put his pot on!' being the death warrant uttered by the chief when the early cannibals proposed having boiled missionary for dinner. <i>(Jun 13, 1908,NZ Truth,156/6/1</i>)

>  <b>SMYTH</b> Dalton has put your pot on. [i.e., told the boss] <i>(1928,Jean of the Tussock Country,59</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> Reliable news is <i>the dinkum oil</i>, to inform on a person is <i>to put his pot on,</i> ... <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,48</i>)

>  `If Mrs Moore and her child are living in the gully no one would put her pot on. They would just accept it and say nothing about it,' she said. <i>(Aug 4, 1974,Sunday Times (NZ),3/4</i>)

>  <b>MARSH</b> `Reckonin' she'll put my pot on with the boss.' <i>(1980,Photo-Finish,173</i>)

>  put his pot on with the boss <i>(Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <i>pot ... put a person's pot on NZ & Austral. sl. </i>inform on him. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,588</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>MITCALFE</b> The cheek of them! I didn't `put their pot on', ... <i>(1985,Hey Hey Hey,121</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>phr.</i> to do (one or oneself) a disadvantage; to ruin things (for one or oneself)

## put (one's) weights up
 
 <i>phr.</i> to inform on, tell on, expose; get (one) into trouble [possibly from racing or bookmaking referring to the putting up or publishing the weights to be carried by horses so that punters can read the facts for themselves; or perhaps, from raising the handicap weights carried so making things more difficult both for the horse and for the bettor who fancies it: perhaps (though very unlikely) from a general analogy of tipping the balance, making the true weight (or, metaphorically, character) of somebody known, as one finds out a true weight literally when one `tips' old-fashioned scales by raising the weights and the thing to be weighed off the surface into a weighing position; ca1952 June Wellington I'll put his weights up with his cobbers tomorrow about his flirting.]

>  <b>McGILL</b> weights, phr. -->putting your weights up putting someone in trouble; possibly from weights carried in handicap horse races; eg `I'd watch Monk if I was you, he'd put your weights up with the cops soon as look at you.' ## put (one) on the coat
 
 <i>phr.</i> to ostracise, excommunicate someone (in prison)

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> This is one of the reasons that informal social control mechanisms at Paremoremo are so strong. Anybody who deviates from the required standard of thought or behaviour - the criminal standard - is quickly observed and `put on the coat' by the rest of the community. At Paremoremo you have to learn quickly to conform to criminal norms or live the life of a pariah. <i>Ibid.</i> 130 A lot of my old mates ... disapproved totally of what was happening and put me on the coat. We remained on speaking terms, but it wasn't the same as it had been before. . <i>Ibid.</i> 246 Coat (n) Put on the Coat. Ostracise, excommunicate. In the sense of reprimand, British prison slang early in this century. <i>See also</i> JACKET. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,66</i>)



## put a ring around
 
 <i>phr.</i> (informal) expressing certainty, strong agreement, etc. [? from hoop-la; or from ringing e.g. a calendar or diary date; or marking off something as one's own] [esp. in 2nd person you can put a ring around it/that]
