## put one around
 
 <i>phr.</i> to trick, put one across

>  <b>RICHARDS</b> I did not intend to be caught with `roughies' left in my pen when the pressure was on. A shearer will always try to put one `around' his mate when he has a full pen of sheep to pick from. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,93</i>)



## put one on (someone)
 
 <i>v.</i> to punch

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>to punch; eg `One more squeak out of you and I'll put one on ya.' ANZ. </i> <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,89</i>)



## put one on the heavy jacket
 
 <i>phr.</i> exclude, ostracise (var. of put on the coat) [(prisoners')]

>  <b>NEWBOLD</b> Kapua ... had been put on the heavy jacket by the Maoris in the can, and was sitting at a table all by himself. <i>(1982,Big Huey, The,198</i>)



## put out
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to move rams into a paddock with ewes at tupping season.

>  During the month of April dipping should be concluded in the South Island, and the rams should be put out. <i>(Apr 1, 1920,NZ Farmer,439</i>)

>  Rams are put out towards the end of April ... <i>(Aug 16, 1948,NZ Journal of Agriculture,176</i>)

>  The rams are put out to ensure lambing from the middle of August. <i>(Apr 1956,NZ Journal of Agriculture,16</i>)

>  <b>GASCOIGNE</b> If too many rams are put out and the ewes are not coming into 'season' in numbers then the males fight amongst themselves and there is a waste of their powers. <i>(1965,From the Top of a Hill,48</i>)

>  Putting the rams out used to be a fairly simple art. If you put your rams out around March 10, you could expect to get lambs from around August 6 on. You may be like one of our friends up the coast who was asked when he put his rams out. <i>(Feb 10, 1966,NZ Farmer,29</i>)

>  Have you decided what date you are going to put the rams out? <i>(Feb 10, 1966,NZ Farmer,36</i>)

>  We used to put the rams out on April 10 but we put it back a week this year because September's still our pinch period for feed. <i>(May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,96</i>)

>  <b>SINCLAIR & TROTTER</b> One of the farmers said to me 'I suppose you'll soon be thinking of putting your rams out. ' <i>(1994,From Caithness to Southland,55</i>)



## put over
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stock breeding] to serve a cow or ewe with a bull or ram.

>  He began by putting Cheviot rams over his Romneys and then introduced Perendale rams to the crossbreds to cement in the genetic changes. <i>(May 27, 2004,Dominion Post,C5</i>)

>  Coopworths cut 4lb of wool off (the fleece weights of progeny of) any Romney they're put over and endanger meat production by encouraging Omega grade lambs. <i>(Sep 13, 1973,NZ Farmer,9</i>)

>  A Charolais bull is put over the cows and the calves are sold at the Culverden calf sales. <i>(May 24, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,16</i>)

>  Churchill is a beefy-type Dexter and putting him over our Dexter/Jersey cross heifers will breed some of the characteristics out of their offspring. <i>(Dec 2001,Smallfarmer, The,4</i>)



## put the acid on
 
 <i>phr.</i> (informal) [AND 1906: possibly f. acid test of gold.] to make a sharp (or final) demand on; to put the bite, juice on (a person for money, favours, etc). Cf. hard word.

>  Put the Acid On [title of a story of fake gold jewelry with a pun on testing it with acid aqua fortis, and puttingthe pressure on buyers with high-pressure sales tactics] <i>(Feb 24, 1906,NZ Truth,36</i>)

>  Gibson replied that both Golding and Goram were putting the acid on to a drunk, or a half-drunk, in the bar, other-wise `telling him a tale.' <i>(Jul 23, 1910,NZ Truth,265/6/1</i>)

>  <b>BAILEY & ROTH</b> But the bloke that puts the acid on/ Got up and shouted : `Bosh!...' <i>(Oct 1918,Shanties,116</i>) [NOTES: NZ Watersider (`The Mixer')[also c1926 Transport Workers' Song Book 141]]

>  `Too much acid,' Bill roared, `I'm telling you, you didn't put the acid on her enough.' <i>(Feb 10, 1920,Quick March,31</i>)

>  To put `the nips in' and `the acid on' are clear enough. <i>(Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18</i>) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

>  <b>CRUMP</b> A passing fisherman called in for a brew of tea and I put the acid on him for his spare spark plug. <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A,93</i>)

>  <b>HELMER</b> You could have knocked me down with a flagon when my mate Helmer put the acid on me for my opinion of a book he'd written about the time he spent in New Zealand with us. <i>(1964,Stag Party,5</i>)

>  put the acid on, hard word on, the nips in (Sl Phr.) ask for a loan or favour. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16</i>)

>  <b>MORRIESON</b> Instead he puts the acid on the Bramwells and they slung some gold to keep his mouth shut. <i>(1974,Predicament,73</i>) [NOTES: 1981 edition]

>  ENGLAND skipper Bob Willis yesterday put the acid on his batsmen to perform in the remaining two days of the third cricket test with New Zealand at Eden Park. <i>(Feb 14, 1984,Dominion,22</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> acid, phr. to put the acid on to demand something; derived from `the acid test'; eg `I see this new union joker's putting the acid on Lange and Douglas for more jobs.' <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,9</i>)

>  <b>CHERRILL</b> But although you had tickets and no mistake on Ju. at the time you didn't forget to put the acid on him proper afterwards. <i>(1950,Sheepfarm,99</i>)

>  <b>VIRTUE</b> You get it, sonny Jim, cripple boy, hundreds. ... I'm putting on the acid, get it, should've done it ages ago. <i>(1989,Then Upon the Evil Season,33</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>phr.</i> to treat acidly, to snub; ??to brush (a person) off (possibly confused with Brit. come to the acid to speakin an unpleasant or sarcastic way).

>  <b>CHERRILL</b> But although you had tickets and no mistake on Ju. at the time you didn't forget to put the acid on him proper afterwards. <i>(1950,Sheepfarm,99</i>)



## put the back up
 
<b>1</b> <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [saddle horses] to buck.

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> put the back up: to buck. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,64</i>)



## put the bite on
 
 <i>phr.</i> to borrow from; to pressure (a person) for money etc.

>  <b>IRELAND</b> 'I'm as good as broke and I'd just come all the way back from England; and what's the first thing that happens?' my father says to me years later. 'A homey comes up and puts the bite on me.' <i>(1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,41</i>)

>  Lola comes up and tries to put the bite on me because I am a stranger. <i>(1951,Landfall,17/21</i>) [NOTES: (Middleton)]

>  <b>SLATTER</b> So then it was Australia ... ending up door to door with an unopened attache case trying to put the bite on housewives. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,38</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> Tony would have the kale. But he did not like putting the bite on Tony. <i>(1965,Horse,43,1982 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Quick and the Dead)]

>  `You'd have more show trying to put the bite on the Pope.' <i>(1966,NZ Short Stories,131,1976 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Middleton `Doss House')]

>  He's come down to put the bite on me for a few thousand. <i>(1967,NZ Short Stories III,153</i>) [NOTES: Dibble `In It']

>  <b>BAXTER</b> [a down-and-out speaks] Who's going to put the bite on - who'll ... <i>(1982,Collected Plays,104,1968 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Band Rotunda)]

>  <b>68</b> From him I learned ... that it was smart to drop your swag in small towns and put the bite on the butcher, baker and grocer. <i>(1974,Loner, The</i>)



## put the boot in
 
 <i>phr.</i> to kick a prostrate foe, to kick (when down). [ca1951 R. Barraclough (Wellington) `especially in a fight, to use ungentlemanly tactics'.]

>  They have no notion of what is called British fair play, but like many Britons of similar disposition, such as Lancashire miners and Australian larrikins, the moment a man is down they put the boot into him and so doing willingly incur the risk of committing brutal murder. <i>(Nov 24, 1906,NZ Truth,75/5/2</i>)

>  A youth named Albert Beaumont was charged with inciting Helmling to resist the arresting copper. According to McCowan and Detective Osborn, he remarked, with vehemence, `Put in the boot low down; don't go any further.' <i>(Aug 26, 1911,NZ Truth,322/5/8</i>)

>  Raymond attacked him `putting the boot in'. <i>(Mar 3, 1953,NZ Truth,9</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> `Sonny's dead for ages. Flashing his roll after the shearing season. At a party or something. Some pakehas got him outside and into him with the boot.' <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,205</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> And then he dropped two of the blokes who butted in to stop him putting the boot into Ted while he was on the ground. <i>(1971,Bastards I Have Met,19</i>)

>  <i>to put the boot in</i>: to play rough or unfairly (rugby) <i>(1980,Lynfield College, Auckland</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>boot</i> in phrs. <i>put in the boot/put the boot in</i> to kick brutally, literally or metaphorically; eg `He put the boot into Happy's chances of becoming matron by spreading the old rumour about her youthful experimant with dope.' Mostly NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,18</i>)

>  His helmet was off, his baton had been taken from him, and the crowd was in the mood to put the boot in. <i>(May 1987,Metro,146</i>)

>  <b>CRANE</b> The police had found him sleeping out in one of the city gardens and had `put the boot in'. <i>(1986,I Can Do No Other,100</i>)



 
 <i>phr.</i> to treat unfairly; to attack a disadvantaged opponent

>  All of them keeping the worker down, by putting in the boot. <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,107</i>) [NOTES: [fig use]]

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> ... she had done him dirty. She had `put in the boot.' <i>(1929,Riven,293</i>)

>  <b>part</b> [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... <i>put the boot in,</i> to take an unfair advantage; <i>Ibid.</i> 287 In London, for preference; there I can have a mag to a tabby, or if any of you fellows put the boot into me in any way, I'll parade sick and join Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry at the base. <i>(1935,Slang Today,286</i>)

>  <b>LEE</b> <i>(Dec 10, 1980,John A. Lee Diaries,50,1937 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> ... all the half-pie pannikin bosses ordering me about because there's no-one like the working man for putting the boot into the working man. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,227</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>boot</i>: can be used for the things you hike in, and there is an expression `to put the boot in' which means metaphorically to kick someone, as `then he really put the boot in and sent him down the road' (fired him); or gave him the boot. How ever, the commonest use of boot refers to what you would call the TRUNK of your car. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,16</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> To aim a blow at the morale or the material position of him who is already at a loss. .in 4;`He's dropped the ball. The mug! Oh the useless bleedin' mug! They'd be better off without him.' `Well, he's not going too good today, but there's no need to stick in the boot. You didn't say that last Saturday when he went like a train.' -->to PUT THE BOOT IN means the same thing. <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],90 [987]</i>) [NOTES: (1962-63) 1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 90 [987]]

>  Lois puts boot into Union [heading] Rugby enthusiast Lois Henare is claiming foul play by one of the country's leading unions for selling expensive match tickets. <i>(Sep 14, 1986,Sunday News,29</i>)

>  In full evangelistic cry Marcus is likely to shout `hallelujah', and urge his audience to sink the boot into Satan. <i>(Oct 8, 1972,Sunday Times (NZ),2/7</i>)



## put the capper on
 
 <i>phr.</i> to put the finishing stroke or an end to (infreq.: cf. the more usual put the lid on, put the stopper on).

>  Mac's insinuation put the `capper' on it and fetched them inside. <i>(1905,Bush Boys of NZ</i>)



## put the fangs into
 
 <i>phr.</i> to press for a loan or handout; to put the bite on.

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> To put the fangs into. To request a loan of money or a donation. i .in 4;`Don't give him anything. He's always putting the fangs into someone.' <i>(1962,Half Caste,336,1974 ed.</i>)



## put the hard word on
 
 <i>phr.</i> to ask a favour or a loan; (to a woman, or homosexual) to ask for sexual favours; cf. put the bite on. [ca1949 (Wellington) The way they're wooing in the bedroom looks like he'll soon be putting the hard word across her.]

>  <b>DEVANNY</b> .. he thinks she is putting the `hard word' on him <i>(1927,Old Savage,144</i>)

>  <b>PARK</b> [in a context of an assumed US accent] ... a cinch to get into the big-time. But what I calculate you oughta do, bo, is to see this Thrush of Erin when he drops into this burg, and put the hard word on him [to help you]. Yeah, bo. <i>(1951,Witch's Thorn, The,24</i>)

>  <b>SYDER & HODGETTS</b> A request for a loan of money. .in 4;`So I said to him, `Well, what you want is enough cashto pay the deposit, and you'd be right from there on. Why don't you put the hard word on your father-on-law? I think he'd lend you that much without a murmur.' <i>(1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],890</i>)

>  (phrase) put the hard word on, to touch for a loan or favour. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),617</i>)

>  hard word n. firm request, demand; specific amatory proposal. <i>Ibid.</i> 16 put theacid on, hard word on, the nips in (Sl Phr.) ask for a loan or favour. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),10</i>)

>  I put the hard word on the man I believed to be the father and he arranged to get some stuff to take. <i>(Oct 17, 1972,NZ Truth,7/1</i>)

>  <b>MANTELL</b> `Difficulty was finding somewhere to live ... When he got back, he put the hard word on Siggy. Fixed that, too.' <i>(1978,Murder in Fancydress,134</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> hard word, put the: see PUT THE. . . put the hard word on: To INSIST that a difficult DECISION be MADE. Usually used in the context of pressuring someone to grant sexual favours or, `put their money where their mouth is' in the case of a business deal or an offer of marriage. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,83</i>)

>  <b>HOLDEN</b> So Morrie put the hard word on Hank [ ...who] hadn't the heart to refuse. - <i>(1982,Wild Pig,177</i>)

>  Ormsby spotted them as he headed back to Turangi after helping one of nine stranded trucks to get underway. ... He gave the driver the hard word and told him to head back to Rangipo, and take State Highway 4, which was still open. <i>(Jun 17, 1986,Evening Post,3</i>)

>  put the hard word on NZ & Austral. ask (person) for loan or (woman) for sexual favours. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,342</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 225]

>  I hummed and haa-ed for a couple of weeks [about having a cancer operation], then I really got the hard word [from the doctor]. <i>(Dec 24, 1987,Dominion,6</i>)

>  <b>McGILL</b> hard word, the demand, often for sex, often phr. put the hard word on; eg `Jimmy had been putting the hard word on Helen for years, but she wouldn't come across. It wasn't as if she had them queuing up outside her door, but she had her standards.' <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,55</i>)

>  <b>Owen Marshall</b> Michael told Rik that he'd thought he'd take in mainly women as flatmates, because if they got a bit behind in payments then he could put the hard word on them. <i>(2005,Watch of Gryphons,69</i>)



## put the needle in
 
 <i>phr.</i> to put the acid/juice on.

>  When one of our clients puts the needle in we have to do his job before outside work. <i>(Jun 1953,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: H.S. Gajadhar quoting a Hutt Timber and Hardware Co. contract builder]



## put the nips in(to)
 
 <i>phr.</i> to ask a favour; to ask for a loan (of money); (cf. put the acid on, touch)

>  I put the nips into one the other night 'n he come to light with a couple o' dener <i>(Sep 19, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,63</i>)

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> I put the nips into the fellow in charge for a feed <i>(1935,Slang Today,564</i>) [NOTES: A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge SlangToday]

>  <b>PARTRIDGE</b> Nips in(to), put the. To ask a loan (from a person): Australian and New Zealand: from ca. 1908. Cf. sting, q.v., and put the hard word on. <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,564</i>)

>  To put `the nips in' and `the acid on' are clear enough. <i>(Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18</i>) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

>  <b>PEARSON</b> <i>(1963,Coal Flat,190</i>)

>  Put the acid on, hard word on, the nips in (Sl Phr.) ask for a loan or favour. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),16</i>)

>  nip ... 11. put the nips in (to). Austral. & N.Z. sl. to try to borrow money (from). <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,761</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 507; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 328]]

>  <b>McGILL</b> put the nips in/squeeze on seek or extract money or a favour; eg `Watch out, lads, Badger's doing the rounds again putting the nips in/squeeze on.' NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,89</i>)

>  And it's anybody's guess what Japanese tourists make of such Kiwisms [sic] as `She's apples `put the nips in' `feeling crook' or `give him some curry'. <i>(1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13</i>)



## put the red collar on
 
 <i>phr.</i> (Rural) to condemn or slit the throat of an animal.

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> I've heard a head shepherd say to a man "go down to the shed and put the red collar on those two dog tuckers in the yard." He meant the man to cut the throats of the sheep and skin them for the dogs. <i>(1951,NZ High Country,42</i>)



## put the set on
 
 <i>n.</i> to straighten a person up; to set a person to rights (See [set](../S#set))

>  <b>COTTLE</b> It took the parson to `put the set on him' <i>(1891,Frank Melton's Luck,147</i>) [NOTES: -]



## put the wood in the hole
 
 <i>phr.</i> to close the door

>  <i> to put the wood in the hole</i>: to shut the door <i>(1980,Lynfield College, Auckland</i>) [NOTES: <i> to put the wood in the hole</i>: to shut the door]



## put through
 
 <i>v.</i> to complete a milking (of a dairy herd) [dairy farming, milking]

>  Mr Linn expects to put through a herd of 100 Jersey cows in ninety minutes. <i>(Oct 12, 1909,Hawera & Normanby Star,4</i>)

>  <b>ANTHONY</b> Being but an indifferent milker it used to take me quite three hours ... to put my herd through. <i>(1924,Follow the Call,9,1975 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> sc. proceedings for bankruptcy [legal process]

>  Former top telly cop, Don Selwyn, has been adjudged bankrupt over an alleged $8000 maintenance bill. The actor who starred in Mortimer's Patch as the popular Sergeant Bob Storey was `put through' on July 2 on an application by Auckland lawyer, Pauline Kingi. <i>(Jul 20, 1986,Sunday News,18</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to process stock through a dip, drafting yards, shearing board. [cattle, dairy, sheep farming; ie any animal stock]

>  The number of sheep and lambs put through the Waingawa freezing works for the past year was 260,957, which was an increase of about 6000 on the previous year. <i>(Jul 4, 1914,Evening Post,9</i>)

>  [Photo caption] Interior of the Slaughterhouse, In which 1000 sheep a day is often put through. <i>(Aug 7, 1901,Otago Witness,40</i>)

>  The Undersigned having enlarged and improved his Plant for "Boiling Down," begs to intimate to Sheepowners that he is now a PURCHASER OF FAT OR LEAN SHEEP FOR BOILING DOWN PURPOSES, or will "put through" Sheep for the owners on terms which may be ascertained on application. <i>(Mar 17, 1887,Southland Times,1</i>)

>  Principally hoggets have been put through the sheds, but in a couple of weeks shearing will be general throughout the district. <i>(Nov 21, 1902,Bruce Herald,5</i>)

>  Put about 5000 sheep through the yards of which nearly 3000 must have been ewes. <i>(Mar 8, 1878,Chudleigh Diary,267,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>AYSON</b> They got a good muster of cattle, took them to the yards, put them through, kept those that were to be tamed in the paddock, and let the rest out in a mob, each to find its way to its own beat. <i>(1937,Thomas,86</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> He had been overseas and he had been up and down the island picking up jobs ... Crayfishing and scrubcutting. Contract fencing. Poisoning rabbits. Even collecting agar. On the chain at Whakatu [166] when they put through 13,000 lambs a day. Share-milking for a while. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,165</i>)

>  An effective remedy that is being used by some farmers is a bath of sheep dip. After being put through this, the sheep are run into a pen that has been well sprinkled with dry unslaked lime, the mosture [sic] on the sheep's feet causing it to slacken and effect a cure in conjunction with the dip. <i>(Jul 12, 1909,Feilding Star,1</i>)

>  <b>PEAT</b> .. he is putting sheep through every bit as quick as the others ... <i>(1992,Falcon and the Lark, The,50</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to mate or tup. [sheep breeding]

>  <b>TAIT</b> One cross of Lincoln has been put through the ewe flock. <i>(1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,22</i>)



## put to bed with a shovel
 
 <i>phr.</i> to bury

>  <b>SANSOM</b> I can hear my grandfather saying; `Do something. Don't give in or the next thing you know we'll be putting him to bed with a shovel.' <i>(1982,In the Grip of an Island,100</i>)



## put up
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to prepare a paddock lunch or crib.

>  <b>HOSKEN</b> No-one had mentioned lunches to me and I had none put up. <i>(1968,Turn Back the Clock,52</i>)

>  <b>SPENCER</b> Eva, Nancy and Jean decided to accompany Alick and put up lunch to enjoy a picnic at some chosen place. <i>(1992,Waioeka Pioneering Saga,114</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to hold up and rob, to stick up

>  <b>BURGESS</b> While we were at the township [in Otago, c1862 March], one of our acquaintances came to me and told me there was a man in a disreputable shanty, that had plenty of money and would I come and put him up? Now the Wetherstone diggings were very quiet, so that I objected to men being put up and let go to alarm the place - for I anticipated robbing this banker sooner or later, and that would do me. <i>(1866,Confessions,76,1983 ed.</i>)

>  Sullivan [the bushranger] said, `Here's a young fellow and a woman carrying a swag; I'll put them up.' <i>Ibid.</i> 18 `I'll put them [the victims] up and you give me your gun while you tie them.' <i>(1866,Maungatapu Murders,17</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to have up (before court), to charge with an offence

>  <b>SARGESON</b> He's been sacked and put up for it. <i>(1945,When the Wind Blows,75</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> Anyhow he'd been sacked and put up for it, and he'd only got six months probation, but there'd been a bit in the newspaper. <i>(1949,I Saw in My Dream,67,1974 ed.</i>)



## put up (a) smoke
 
 <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [mustering] to light a tussock to signal readiness to muster off or to signal one's whereabouts.

>  [?1951 ECR OEDS] <i>Put up a smoke.</i>- To light a snowgrass bush, etc., as a signal when mustering. <i>(Nov 18, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> put up smoke: musterer's means of signalling his whereabouts. For example, the top-beat man would set light to a tussock to indicate that he was in position and the muster could begin. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,64</i>)



## put up a blue
 
 <i>phr.</i> to make a mistake

>  <b>CHARLES</b> Young Bradshaw's the boy who is flying this plane,/ She is as full as a tick and it's pouring with rain./ Things are not going good - his donk's on the blink* -/ Then he puts up a blue and she dives in the drink./ [fn] *his donk's on the blink: his engine is giving trouble (airman's slang) [Charles had served in the RNZAF in WW2] <i>(1981,Black Billy Tea,89</i>)



## put up a run
 
<b>1</b> <i>phr.</i> (Rural) [mustering and trial dogs] to hunt or head sheep.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Rock had put up a run in which he fairly excelled himself ... <i>(1947,Wayleggo,27</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> At Lake Coleridge also I witnessed the most extraordinary run I have known a dog to put up. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,50</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> During that trip Flirt put up a run that was the equal of any head I have seen. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,61</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> But for the fact that his out-run was excessively wide he put up a good run ... <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,195</i>)



## put-in
 
 <i>n.</i> (Sport) entry point on a river (in kayaking)

>  With a few eager multisporters and newer paddlers keen to experience some grade 2-3 whitewater, we thought that a weekend at the Raukawa Adventure Centre (RAC) would be ideal. Most of us headed up on Friday night for an early start on Saturday. ## pygmy pine
 
 <i>n.</i> a sprawling shrub related to the rimu [aka dwarf-pine, dwarf pine; <i>Lepidothamnus laxifolius</i> previously <i>Dacryidium laxifolius</i>]

>  New Zealand's wet alpine areas are home to what is thought to be the world's smallest conifer, the pygmy pine, Lepidothamnus laxifolius. This "pine" doesn't even make it as a shrub, let alone a forest specimen, but spreads in a cushion. <i>(Aug 25, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,10</i>)

>  <i>Dacrydium laxifolium</i> pigmy pine <i>(1908,AJHR</i>) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

>  <b>MARK & ADAMS</b> Small trailing shrubs - the pygmy pine (<i>Dacrydium laxifolium</i> ), creeping heath plants -dracophyllums (<i>D. prostratum, D. politum), Pentachondra pumila, Cyathodes pumila </i>and <i>C. empetrifolia,</i> also <i>Coprosma pumila</i> are typical of peat bogs. <i>(1973,NZ Alpine Plants,22</i>)
